HEADLINE: The View From/Yonkers;
As Bells Toll, a Church Celebration Takes Its Place in a City's Rebirth

BYLINE: By LYNNE AMES 

DATELINE: YONKERS

 BODY:
IT was Dec. 8, the feast of the Immaculate Conception, and John Cardinal O'Connor was at St. Mary's Immaculate Conception here to consecrate an altar at the 150-year-old church.
At 7 P.M. just before the Mass, the bells in the Romanesque church's tower began to toll. Over and over they echoed throughout the canyon of South Broadway, the sound reverberating between City Hall and the high-rise office and apartment buildings and the old stone church itself. In each of the rectory's many windows shone a green wreath studded with tiny red lights. On the church steps parishioners and guests and a handful of police officers awaited the arrival of the Archbishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York. An air of festivity and something more prevailed. 
 For this was not only the consecration of an altar made of black stone mined at the DiRienzo Quarry a few miles to the north. (Yes, there is a quarry in Yonkers, right on Fullerton Avenue.) This was also part of a rebirth of a city beset in recent years by economic and other woes, a city whose downtown is only now experiencing a spark of new energy. St. Mary's, said its pastor, Msgr. Hugh Corrigan, is a microcosm of Yonkers itself. The parish, which covers five square blocks around Getty Square, was originally made up of immigrants from Ireland and Italy and Eastern Europe and was then largely populated by their descendants and finally saw a wave of newcomers from Latin America and the Middle East.
"Our last 30 years are like our first 30 years," Monsignor Corrigan said. "We have always been known as a warm church, a friendly church in which to pray. Our first parishioners were Irish, fleeing from the terrible famines in 1845 through 1852. They did hard manual labor, built railroads and crushed rocks in Yonkers. We still have their great-grandchildren and great-great-grandchildren. Our newest members are Hispanic and Arabic; many of them own small businesses and are a vital part of downtown life here. Our 9 A.M. Mass is in Spanish; our 1:15 Mass is in Arabic.
As for the Cardinal, he was resplendent in white robes and, during the procession, a miter. His sonorous voice filled the sanctuary; his graceful, long-fingered hands gestured with a language of their own as he rubbed oil into the new altar's bare stone surface. "Consecrating an altar is virtually a mystical experience," he said. "Let us give ourself totally and unconditionally to this revelation of mystery that unfolds before our eyes. Had there been no Mary, there would be no altar. Every altar is Mary's altar. Let us join with Mary in consecrating this one."
Nor was the altar -- a simple, table-like structure of dark stone -- the only object of the Cardinal's attention. He pronounced the entire church magnificent, and indeed it is. Termed American Romanesque by Monsignor Corrigan, it is made of hewn stone and features arches, vaulted ceilings, pristinely restored details and walls and ceilings painted in peachy, terra cotta tones and a blue suggestive of the blue of Mary's robes. The original church, completed in 1848, is now used as St. Mary's school; the current sanctuary and rectory were built in 1892. The old altar is intricately wrought white marble, with tall, carved, dramatically backlighted statuary.
"This church is very, very beautiful," Cardinal O'Connor said. He added, however, that amid the beauty, one should never forget suffering: the "terrible, terrible conditions" that the early Irish immigrants endured as they cut stone similar to the ones used in the new altar, the suffering of Christ on the cross.
As the Cardinal performed the ritual for the new altar, he gave a kind of running commentary, much the way a member of the archdiocese narrates the action at St. Patrick's Cathedral, which is televised for the Midnight Mass on Christmas Eve.
He began talking about the Virgin Mary, saying that God made her "totally free of sin -- you couldn't even use the word sin in the same room as Mary -- because she was going to be the altar of His Son; she was going to conceive His Son on the altar."
The Cardinal took a small pitcher filled with olive oil and five times poured some on the altar. "Now we pour oil in five places onto the altar," he said. "It represents the five wounds of Christ. Then I will rub it in." He circled the structure, ran his hands over the surface, then looked at them. "One is touching the body of Christ in the womb of Mary; one is touching Christ in the tomb. I feel this all as I rub the sacred oil in with my hands."
Next came the lighting of incense -- "We see the smoke as prayer, ascending into heaven," he said -- and the laying of a cloth on the altar and the placement and lighting of candles on it. Together, Cardinal O'Connor and the congregation prayed.
Among them was Mary Delaney, 81, who lives with her daughter and son-in-law in northern Yonkers. She grew up near St. Mary's and still attends Mass there every Sunday. "Even though I don't live that near here anymore, I come every Sunday," she said. "I come in a cab and go home in a bus."
Also at the service was Dr. Bernard McGinn, professor of theology at the University of Chicago Divinity School. Dr. McGinn came to see the altar consecrated. "I grew up in this parish," he said. "I was an altar boy here. This church is very beautiful. Religion is more than esthetics, of course, but esthetics -- beauty -- are important."
Walter J. McLain, a retired police officer and usher at the church, agreed. "I've been coming to St. Mary's since I got out of the Army in 1946. It's not my parish anymore, but I still come here. It's a real beauty. And, it gives me a sense of stability."

HEADLINE: Q&A/John Weichsel;
Municipal Manager With Tenure Plus

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
JOHN WEICHSEL has been a municipal manager for 43 years, and the Town Manager of Southington for 31 years, a record that gives him more tenure than 99 percent of his peers across the country. This year, he also became the first appointed official to be named president of the Connecticut Conference of Municipalities, a post that has traditionally gone to elected officials.
Mr. Weichsel was born in Germany, and immigrated to this country in 1934, at the age of 1. He attended the the University of Pennsylvania, then earned his master's degree at the Fels Institute of Local and State Government there. After stints in Kalamazoo, Mich., and Ellenville, N.Y., he was hired as the first town manager in Southington on Oct. 11, 1966. 
 A tireless advocate for more state funding for towns, Mr. Weichsel also argues strongly that the legislature should impose fewer mandates that require expensive programs.
Among the areas where he has become a recognized expert is the so-called heart and hypertension law, which provides for automatic disability payments to police and firefighters who develop heart problems, under the blanket presumption that those conditions were related to their employment.
He is known as an outspoken town manager -- he once suggested that computer programmers all over the world should be assassinated for not recognizing and addressing the so-called year 2000 problem long before the late 1990's.
In a recent interview, Mr. Weichsel answered questions about his longevity as town manager, and the changes that he has observed. Following are excerpts from that conversation.
Q. What made you decide to become a city manager?
A. My father was a very dedicated physician and I grew up with the idea of public service. When I went to the University of Pennsylvania, I had in my mind a legal career. But I took some political science courses in my sophomore year, when I was still 16, and I was fascinated by government management. It seems to have been a good choice.
 Q. When you came to Southington did you expect to be here more than 30 years?
 A. No. I was asked how long I expected to stay, and my kids were 7 and 3, so I said until my kids get through school. So about 10 or 12 years was the goal. About the middle of my time here I made applications to a larger city. It got out that I had applied, and the community was thrilled that I didn't get the job. That sort of influenced me to not give much more thought to moving on.
 Q. Don't you lack an advantage of other town managers? You can't blame anything on a predecessor.
 A. That's right, On the other hand, they have nothing to compare to. I like to say, I'm the best town manager Southington has ever had.
 Q. How have you managed to last so long?
A. At the risk of being more immodest than usual, I think intelligence is pretty important. You've got to be pretty smart, otherwise you're going to be crushed. My training in graduate school was very strong. Every day we did field work for Philadelphia city departments. When our academic work was done we got a six-month internship. So I got a very good start.
And I think my personality was probably helpful. You can't be a Casper Milquetoast if you're the first manager. If you're too soft, you're going to go nowhere. Now I don't mean to suggest you take over the government -- I'm an employee, not a boss here. But you've got to be forthright, and that's the way I am.
 Q. Has your reputation for being outspoken hurt you in this era of political correctness?
 A. No, because I follow the city managers' code of ethics, and stay out of partisan matters. When I speak out on public issues, I make very sure I am speaking for the council. One of the ways I have survived is not to challenge my bosses. There are times that I make recommendations, and they don't agree. And there are times when I have been wrong.
 Q. How has Southington changed since you arrived?
 A. When I came it was a town of about 27,000, and now it's about 40,000. It was viewed as a totally blue-collar town, a place you would look for a starter house, and then when you got a little better off you would move to Simsbury or Avon or Farmington. Now Southington is a very desirable place for housing. When I came 5 percent of the people in town were college graduates, now it's 48 percent or something like that. We've lost Pratt & Whitney, which was our largest employer. But we've made up for it -- we now have three buildings of the Hartford Insurance Group, for instance.
 Q. Have the problems also changed?
 A. Labor relations were very difficult when I got here, and while they still can't be ignored, they've gotten better. In the last decade, environmental problems have become more important. When Pratt & Whitney left, economic development problems were at the forefront. Those changes keep the job interesting.
 Q. Are there aspects of the job that have gotten more difficult?
 A. Environmental areas. In my view, we've gotten into an overkill situation. There are people in charge of the environmental area who are excessive.
 Q. You've clashed with Southington's state legislator over an acquifer protection law. That would seem to be politically dangerous -- is that a good idea for a town manager?
 A. I haven't said the law is wrong, but we're very worried. We have an industrial zone in the northwest part of town, an enterprise zone. The indications I'm getting are that we wouldn't be able to have any development in that area under that law.
If we can have normal development over an acquifer, fine. But if they've taken the position that every industry is a polluter, that's wrong. You can have an industrial building that has zero pollution into the ground.
 Q. Southington's state senator also questioned the value of the city's participation in the Connecticut Conference of Municipalities. How would you respond to that?
 A. That was one of the most obtuse statements I have ever heard in my life. The C.C.M. municipal revenue collection program will collect $17,000 or $18,000 this year, which is about what we pay in dues. We have our workers compensation insurance, run by C.C.M., which has saved us thousands and thousands of dollars. There are training programs, some of them required by law, such as sexual harassment training. If you didn't get them through C.C.M. you'd have to hire some Ph.D. to do them, at much greater cost. They enter electric rate cases to make sure our interests are represented.
And finally, C.C.M. is the voice of the cities in lobbying. In towns, we take the long view -- we will pay a little bit of money up front to save a lot of money in the long run. We're going to be here forever. There have been bills that would save money up front, but cost us a lot in the long run. If we didn't have C.C.M., we would have some pretty horrible legislation. As it is, we do -- C.C.M. is not totally effective -- but the value of C.C.M. is tremendous.
 Q. What has been the high point of your career?
 A. Helping to create the Bristol trash-to-energy plant. You may remember the Islip barge, which went all over the place looking for a place to dump their load of trash. Our own landfill had been closed, and we had been exporting garbage to a landfill in East Windsor, and they kept doubling rates.
I saw this as a tremendous environmental benefit. It would give us volume reduction, we would create electrical energy from the garbage, and have sophisticated air pollution controls. Then the question was, how do you do it? That plant cost $90 million. Well, New Britain and Berlin were also wondering what to do with garbage. Then I talked with Plainville, and they got interested.
But we still lacked two things: a place to build the plant, and a place to put the ash. Bristol had a 63-acre landfill, and room to build the plant. Bristol agreed to go with us. Then a few other towns also joined. Getting those towns together, and getting the financing, I view as my greatest personal accomplishment.
 Q. If you had a child going to college this year, would you recommend government management?
 A. Absolutely not. It's a very difficult profession. Of course, if you ask an architect what his son should do he'd say, "anything but an architect." An engineer? "Anything but an engineer." But I tell people there are fewer professional city managers than there are professional athletes -- only 2,500 of us. And you know how hard it is to be a Tiger Woods or a Michael Jordan.

GRAPHIC: Photo: John Weichsel, Southington Town Manager. "I'm an employee, not a boss here. But you've got to be forthright." (George Ruhe for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Failed Shopping Plaza Becoming a Town Center

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
OVER the last decade the 614,000-square-foot Willingboro Plaza went from a vibrant regional shopping center to a ghost town -- 13 shuttered buildings spread over 56 acres at the western edge of the Burlington County Township of Willingboro.
An open-air mall, it fell victim to enclosed malls and big-box retailers. Now, Renewal Realty L.L.C., a Manhattan-based developer, plans, in partnership with the township, to transform the derelict property along Route 130 into a mixed-use development that will double as the town center for this community of 37,000. 
 The development, called Willingboro Town Center, will have up to 1.2 million square feet of new and renovated retail, light industrial and office and civic space and up to 240 town houses, as well as 3,000 parking spaces. Twenty-five percent of the project will be open space.
The 7.5-square-mile township is considering running a minivan service around town to the site and the state plans to construct light-rail line along the nearby Delaware River from Trenton to Camden.
Willingboro Plaza "was a blight that implied the rest of the town was decaying," said Lavonne Bebler Johnson, the acting Mayor.
Its redevelopment will change that and provide an "environment where people can live and work, and not shut down at night," she said.
The project is part of a larger redevelopment plan by Burlington County to revive the Route 130/Delaware River commercial corridor, which sits in the northwestern sector of the county and extends along the river and the highway through 12 towns, from Florence 16 miles south to Cinnaminson.
The corridor has suffered from blight and economic decline, leaving it pockmarked with empty buildings like those at Willingboro Plaza, which is one of four key sites the county has identified in its renewal effort.
The overall plan, which takes a regional approach to redevelopment, was devised after two years of discussions among state and county officials as well as the leaders and residents of the 12 corridor towns.
The corridor plan in general, and the Willingboro development in particular, also reflect the goals of the state's Development and Redevelopment Plan, which encourages growth in areas where sewers, highways and mass transit links are available. In less developed areas, where those facilities are lacking, the plan tries to manage growth by encouraging mixed-use and compact development.
At its heart, the corridor plan calls for reinventing the highway strip, now a dying retail hub, into a patchwork of light industrial, office and retail uses as well as housing.
"The market says that Route 130 is no longer the region's retail center and that its heyday is not coming back," said Mark Remsa, principal planner at the Burlington County Office of Land-Use and Planning. "But without making significant changes in the four targeted areas, nothing in the corridor can be preserved."
Willingboro Town Center will be developed in phases over the next five years at an estimated cost of $60 million to $70 million, including the $2 million needed to clean the site of low levels of hydrocarbons and rid the buildings of asbestos. The initial $20 million phase of the project, which includes the cleanup, began last month and last week demolition started on the first of the empty buildings -- 10 of which will be razed by the spring. The remaining three will be recycled into other uses.
THE first phase also calls for the construction of some 50 residences and 65,000 square feet of commercial and light industrial space in two buildings, as well as the renovation of an existing 100,000-square-foot two-story building for use by public institutions.
Negotiations are under way with the local library and Burlington County College to relocate from elsewhere in the township to the development, said Robert B. Stang, managing director at Renewal. The college and library are expected to open within the development in mid-2000, he said.
The first phase will be the anchor to get the project started, "creating enough of a catalyst that the rest will follow," Mr. Stang added.
Renewal will develop most of the property itself but will join other developers for certain components of the project, particularly the housing, Mr. Stang said. While he said the prices and styles of the units had not yet been set, they are expected to be a mix of rental and for-sale residences designed for professional couples and older households.
Explaining the significance of the Willingboro Town Center project, Theresa Brown, director of the Burlington County Board of Freeholders, said: "It sends the message that we are serious about the corridor plan and when the first buildings there come down it will be proof that something is going to happen."
Redeveloping the property is also important for Willingboro, which saw its tax base erode with the demise of the old shopping center. The loss of jobs as businesses closed also took a toll on this old farming-turned-bedroom community, which started its modern life in the 1950's as the nation's third Levittown, and the community briefly bore that name. The 11,000-house development built from 1957 to 1972 included Willingboro Plaza, which, like other retail outlets along Route 130, thrived through the 1970's.
In the early 70's, a section of Interstate 295 cutting through the county opened, shifting growth eastward to the south central portion of Burlington County. Within a decade, enclosed malls began popping up along I-295, drawing shoppers and businesses away from Route 130 and, Mr. Remsa said, "sapping the life" out of the corridor, including Willingboro Plaza, the largest portion of the more than a million square feet of vacant space along Route 130.
THAT set off alarms two-and-a-half years ago, prompting the county to come up with the corridor plan, which Mr. Remsa called "a roadmap for developers." The county has submitted the plan to the Office of State Planning for approval. If approved, he said, it would give all 12 corridor towns priority from state agencies for approvals and financing for physical plant and road improvements.
"It is one of the best regional planning efforts I've seen in the state and was done with widespread public and municipal support," said Herb Simmens, executive director of the semi-autonomous planning agency, referring to the corridor plan.
"It reinvests in existing places and it will be a model for redeveloping other obsolete highway strips."
In the last two years Willingboro also stepped up efforts to work with the former owners of Willingboro Plaza to turn it around -- all to no avail, said Mayor Belber Johnson. In 1997, she said, "we got tough with the owners," by enforcing municipal and fire codes, resulting in $900,000 in fines against them.
Last January the two parties struck a deal, under which Willingboro waived the fines against the owners. In turn, the plaza owners dropped their pursuit of a $98,000 tax reduction on the property and agreed to deed it over to the township. For its part, Renewal gave $175,000 to the owners and $25,000 to the township, the latter for costs in processing the fines, said William J. Kearns Jr., the township's attorney.
The township then entered an agreement with Renewal to redevelop the site. Under it the township sold $2 million in bonds to pay for cleaning up the site, which Renewal will repay, plus interest; declared it a redevelopment area and rezoned it to its current use. The township also agreed to phase in taxes over the next five years on any improvements to the site, Mr. Kearns said, adding that after Renewal cleans the site it has the option to purchase it.
Mayor Bebler Johnson said the township "took the risk" in taking over the property and selling the bonds "to prime the pump" for redevelopment. "If nothing was done the fear was that residents, "would start moving away," she added.
The project is "off to a good start because of the state, county and local support," said Mr. Stang of Renewal, adding that the reasonable land and cleanup costs along with the tax abatement "will enable us to be competitive."
"The site was once the center of town," he said, "and it will be again -- only different."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Willingboro Plaza, above, with Sears building at right. The first building to be demolished for the Town Center is the Fox Movie Theater, left. (Renewal Realty)

HEADLINE: High Expectations Await Airline Arrival

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

DATELINE: RONKONKOMA

 BODY:
WHEN Southwest Airlines announced earlier this month that it will begin daily service from Long Island MacArthur Airport in mid-March, it signaled a new era for Long Island air travel.
For executives, budget-conscious flyers and Florida snowbirds, Southwest's promise of more flights to more places at low fares suddenly catapulted the regional airport in Ronkonkoma to what could be an important travel hub for Long Islanders and raised the possibility that Southwest's competitors would have to lower their fares. And a stronger airport could also have a measurable effect on the Island's economy. 
 "The potential for adding to the economy is enormous," said Lee. E. Koppelman, the executive director of the Long Island Regional Planning Board.
The Southwest announcement, which capped weeks of speculation, came when the chairman of Southwest, Herbert D. Kelleher, announced 12 daily nonstop flights from MacArthur to four cities beginning on March 14.
The initial service will be to Baltimore-Washington International Airport, Midway Airport in Chicago, Orlando and Nashville. More flights and cities may be added later, Mr. Kelleher said, if the new service is successful.
The airport, which is used by more than a million passengers a year, is currently served by seven airlines offering a total of 60 flights a day, 10 of them jet service to various cities, but with an emphasis on leisure travel to Florida. The other airlines are American Airlines, Delta Express, Comair, Spirit Airlines, U.S. Airways Express, Sunjet International and Business Express.
Almost immediately, some of those competitors hinted at added service and fare cuts to meet the Southwest challenge. Others, including Spirit, said they expected that Southwest's presence would help fill their seats.
The reaction to the Southwest announcement from travelers, travel agents, businesses and Long Island officials was not quite thunderous applause, but close to it. Only neighbors sounded an alarm about expansion of the airport in a densely populated suburban area.
But for others there were enticements. Flights on Southwest's fleet of Boeing 737-700 jets, which can carry up to 149 passengers, will connect to Southwest flights to 29 other cites, lacing geographically adrift Long Island into a country-wide budget air service as never before.
What drew Southwest to Long Island, Mr. Kelleher said during a telephone news conference following the announcement, was an absence of low-fare service and what the company saw as a latent demand that Southwest would trigger.
"Our whole premise in opening up Islip is that we are going to do just fine with Long Island traffic," he said. He dismissed reports that MacArthur would be the first in a ring of airports around New York City where Southwest would locate, saying Southwest's focus in the region would be MacArthur.
The move by Southwest raised expectations that MacArthur, a 1940's-vintage Islip Town-owned airport that has had up-and-down experiences with other carriers, had at last been anointed a bona fide regional air hub.
"I am one happy camper," said Pete McGowan, the MacArthur supervisor, who began meeting with Mr. Kelleher two years ago to promote the airport. The town, he said, would earn an additional $500,000 in annual revenues because of the Southwest service.
The town sweetened its overtures to Southwest with a $13 million airport project now in progress to add parking and new baggage carousels, modernize ticketing areas, reconfigure terminal security and enlarge an airport restaurant.
Matthew T. Crosson, the chairman of the Long Island Association, the region's largest business group, said it was "a bit early to tell" whether Southwest would thrive at MacArthur. But if it did, he said, it would surely draw passengers from western Nassau eager to avoid city airport congestion.
"Everybody east of Route 110 is going to use MacArthur now," said Larry Austin, chairman and chief executive officer of Melville-based Austin Travel, a travel agency. "It's great for the airport and great for Long Island."
Some Long Island companies were ecstatic over the possible savings on travel budgets. "We are very excited about this; for us it's very important," said Lisa Mars, a senior vice president at Computer Associates in Islandia, where the annual travel budget is more than $20 million.
The computer software company has 2,400 employees at its Islandia world headquarters, a destination for clients and for others of the company's 12,000 employees worldwide.
At Symbol Technologies in Holtsville, which spends about $11 million on air fares annually, Austin Travel's in-house manager, Scarlett Green, was also enthusiastic.
"These fares are terrific and people love to go to MacArthur," she said. "It's so much closer to home for them."
MacArthur is located off of Veteran's Memorial Highway at exit 57 of the Long Island Expressway and is also near the Long Island Rail Road's Ronkonkoma station.
Ms. Green said the Southwest service would especially appeal to business travelers who went to LaGuardia to avoid using the small commuter planes that fly to some regional routes from MacArthur.
Dr. Koppelman said benefits were still broader. "It's not just the high-techs," he said. "It's the consulting firms and all those other businesses that have regional offices all over the country."
In its first foray into the New York region, Dallas-based Southwest will use the same formula that has worked in the 52 cities it serves.
It features deeply discounted fares, no frills and no-meals service, and quick airport turnarounds to keep a fleet of 276 Boeing 737s airborne.
For Long Island, it will mean eight daily direct flights to Baltimore-Washington International Airport for $79 each way with seven-day advance purchase, and similarly low fares on two daily flights to Chicago's Midway Airport and single flights to Nashville and Orlando. American Airlines, for example, last week quoted a round-trip, seven-day advance purchase fare to Chicago's O'Hare Airport of $300.
Southwest, which has 26,000 employees and more than 2,350 flights a day, will add 44 new jobs at MacArthur for baggage handlers, ticketing agents and other positions. The largely unionized company said current employees will be allowed to bid for the jobs and will have preference.
Mr. Kelleher, a New Jersey native who studied law at New York University, vowed that Southwest would succeed by developing a new customer base at MacArthur.
"When you are charging $39, 7-day advance purchase one-way fares to Baltimore, you tend to develop more travelers than when you are charging $250," he said. "It's funny how people respond to those things."
Competitors said they would probably respond to Southwest's fares. "We do compete with Southwest Airlines in various airports, and while we can't discuss future fares, we do intend to remain competitive," said a Delta Air Lines spokesman, John Kennedy.
At American Airlines, a spokesman, Tim Smith, said the company was "looking at some service enhancements out of MacArthur, but the details have not yet been finalized."
An airline analyst, Brian D. Harris of Salomon Smith Barney, said the Southwest move "fits their model."
"Instead of going right into the thick of things, they picked the most closely located airport, and now they are going to try to pick off traffic from the sidelines," he said.
Mr. Harris predicted that Southwest service would draw travelers who now used LaGuardia. "The obvious base are those folks living between the two airports," he said.
The MacArthur airport manager, Al Werner, said the airport had adequate capacity for the Southwest flights and any service expansions. He said there were no plans for adding or extending runways,
Mr. Werner said the 24 commercial jet flights the airport would handle daily when Southwest service began on March 14 was still below the 26 commercial daily flights it handled in the mid-1980's, the previous peak period for airport use.
At the time, complaints from airport neighbors in Bohemia, Holbrook and Ronkonkoma led to a voluntary agreement barring flights between 11 P.M. and 6:30 A.M.
But last week a Suffolk County Legislator who lives in Holbrook, Steve Levy, said complaints were mounting about "planes coming in from all angles, at all hours."
He said neighbors were alarmed that the town kept fire rescue crews on duty at the airport around the clock, reversing an earlier policy in which they departed at 11 P.M., thus precluding takeoffs or landings after that hour. "No jets after 11 P.M. was all that maintained people's sanity," said Mr. Levy, the senior Democrat in the legislature.
"We are not a bunch of Nimbyites seeking to close the airport, we are just trying to maintain the traditional late-night cut-off," Mr. Levy said. "If Southwest lives by the old standard, everyone can get along. If not, they are going to wake a sleeping giant."
The town disputes the charge, saying that rescue crews leave the airport at midnight.
A resident of Holbrook Estate, Ronald Falcone, said sound barriers similar to those erected along the Long Island Expressway were needed on the borders of the airport to buffer the sound of jet engines.
"Everyone is saying that having Southwest at the airport is a wonderful thing, but they are looking at it through rose-colored glasses," said Mr. Falcone.
"There has to be some consideration given to preserving the neighborhood and its quality of life," he said. "They are adding 12 flights, but Southwest says they don't see any reason why they shouldn't add more. When does it stop? When do we address the downside?"
Mr. Werner said the last arrival at MacArthur was at 10:35 P.M. Town officials said Southwest would abide by the curfew.
Airport officials and Southwest said 737-700s were quieter than older-generation jets. "It is a very quiet and fuel-efficient jet," said Kristie Kerr, a spokeswoman for Southwest.
Thomas Conoscenti, associate senior economist at the Center for Regional Policy Studies at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, said the move by Southwest could only help the Island and would likely strengthen the area's business links to other regions.
"It means greater exchange of goods and services, and of intellectual products that involve marketing and sales people," he said. "With the kind of route structure Southwest has, it opens up Long Island to other parts of the country and facilitates exchanges for the business community."

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Offstage Drama Of 'Wit' Goes On

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN 

 BODY:
THIS year, the singularity of the professional nonprofit theaters' best work in the state went on informing the nonprofit theater in New York, reflected the continuing double standards of the lords of the commercial sector and converged with other theater events, in Connecticut and elsewhere. Here's how some winners did it.
Although Long Wharf's Stage II in New Haven gave life to Margaret Edson's triumphant play, "Wit" in November 1997, when theaters countrywide turned it down, its offstage drama goes on. 
 Now that "Wit" happens to be the most acclaimed new play of the season in New York, it has become a cause celebre in all aspects of the New York theater: the institutional and the commercial, Off Broadway and Broadway. After "Wit" went as far as it could go in the M.C.C. Theater on West 28th Street -- the New York equivalent of a regional theater -- a move to Broadway was expected. For the 99-seat house had to make room for another play and "Wit" was still doing turn-away business after three extensions.
In step with the shortsighted second-guessing mentality of the commercial theater landlord in a seller's market, the owner of one available theater rejected "Wit," reasoning that there was no room for a play about a woman dying of ovarian cancer on the street where "Phantom of the Opera" and "Chicago" thrive, and "Fosse" and "Civil War" are moving in.
And so "Wit," not unwelcomely, moved to the Off Broadway-designated Union Square Theater last Friday. It seems a shoo-in for best play awards and its honored star, Kathleen Chalfant, for acting prizes -- but not the Tony, which retains Broadway exclusivity.
Given the inseparable politics and economics of the theater in New York, the schism between Broadway and Off Broadway, which is not geographic but a symptom of the theater's and television, in its selective coverage of theater, disguised class system, misguided snobbery and false elitism, is merely widened by the divided theater world's ambivalence toward a literate play of truth and gallantry.
If Long Wharf was brave and prophetic in lavishing Ms. Edson's play with a world-class premiere -- a memorable reopening for Stage II -- it is now positively heroic.
Of course, many theatergoers remain steadfast in refusing to attend a play on ostensibly downbeat themes. English grammar is one. To assure them that "Wit" is exhilarating is like talking of catharsis in ancient drama to those who line up for "Footloose."
Is it mere chance that contemporary theater's most life-affirming plays about death have emanated from Connecticut?
Remember that "Marvin's Room" moved from Hartford Stage to Off Broadway's Minetta Lane Theater. By contrast, the heavy-handed, high-minded "Shadow Box" transferred from Long Wharf to Broadway in the 1970's. But that was then.
If end-of-the-year awards were doled out for "best bio," Bernard Telsey Casting Inc., as described in Long Wharf's program, would be the winner, no contest. Mr. Telsey, the executive director, with Robert LuPone, of M.C.C., is also in charge of casting for Long Wharf, as well as for other theaters.
In the credits for the casting company, its five members thank a long list of clients and supporters in alphabetical order (E. Albee, E. Bogosian, D. Hughes, M. Lamos, D. Mamet, J. Tillinger, M. Wilson), theater organizations by initial only (H.S.C., L.W.T., M.C.C.) "for trusting us." And then one sentence: "Although we have our price, we have been known to cast for food."
A distinct Connecticut theater event of 1998 bore a serendipitous connection to another show in another state. In a remarkable confluence of life and art, June Havoc, a one-woman testament to survival, valor and vivacity, gave a solo reading of her new play in progress, "Baby June Remembers: A Love Story" at Lucille Lortel's White Barn Theater in Westport in September. Ms. Havoc's appearance had been delayed, but only briefly, after a fall, hip surgery and rehabilitation in a Stamford hospital. Her performance, of a play about the women in her celebrated life, up to age 9, including, of course, the notorious Mama Rose of "Gypsy," was followed by acharming question and answer session. Ms. Havoc was making peace with a fabled and widely misunderstood "monster mother."
Meanwhile, some 80 miles away, an extraordinary production of "Gypsy" was being produced at the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn, N.J. Although Ms. Havoc has famously denounced the classic musical precisely because it is the fable it advertises itself to be, she admits it is a great piece of craftmanship, however falsely it presents the facts. No Mama Rose has been close to the real thing -- Tyne Daly came closest -- in her estimation. But Betty Buckley's killer performance in the summit role of musicals was the real thing, not the art that conceals truth but the art that reveals or, more importantly, transcends it. Somewhere between the artifice and showiness of the role's stellar interpreters -- Merman, Lansbury, Daly, Midler -- and Ms. Havoc's published and unpublished memories, there was Ms. Buckley, home free, in a style that must surely have startled, if not threatened, the role's creators.
Lucky theatergoers in Hartford were the beneficiaries of a convergence of another sort: the coincidental bravura performances of Estelle Parsons (in "Happy Days" at Hartford Stage) and Tovah Feldshuh (in "Full Gallop" at Theaterworks), both last month. Each player capped an adventurous life in the theater.
One hopes Hartford Stage audiences responded to Beckett's masterwork, though to some, it may have seemed too extreme a departure after the wildly popular, overproduced and overrated "Streetcar Named Desire."
And it must be emphasized that Ms. Feldshuh, after Mary Louise Wilson's indelible imprint on a role she herself wrote, succeeded smashingly where others (Elizabeth Ashley in an aborted tour that made a stopover in Stamford and Brenda Vacarro in Los Angeles) failed.
And while it is too early to measure the commercial success or failure of the overwrought, overamplified and otherwise beleaguered Broadway revival of "On the Town," it is important to chronicle the fine 1993 Goodspeed Opera House staging of the Bernstein-Comden-Green collaboration, their first, directed and choreographed by Marcia Milgrom Dodge. It is never surprising but ever renewing to know that Connecticut theatergoers get there first.

HEADLINE: Substitute Teachers In Demand All Over The State

BYLINE: By RICHARD WEIZEL 

 BODY:
A SHORTAGE of substitute teachers across the state is forcing school administrators to find creative ways to fill hundreds of classroom positions each day -- using retired teachers, college students and even parents.
"This is a problem that is definitely reaching a crisis level and has been building for the past few years, but this is the worst I've ever seen it," said the Bridgeport School Superintendent, James A. Connelly, who heads the state's second largest school system. "There are days when we have 20 to 30 classes that we cannot fill with substitute teachers." 
 On many days, Mr. Connelly said, art and music teachers and even administrators are forced to teach regular classes. When those stopgap measures are not enough, students have to be sent to study halls. A strong state economy, rising student enrollments, increasing teacher absenteeism and a high number of teacher retirements are all contributing factors, say officials in the State Department of Education. In some places, teacher retirements are not just part of the problem, they are also part of the solution.
Eleanor Walker thought her classroom days were over when she retired in June after 21 years as an elementary school teacher in Trumbull. That has not turned out to be the case. In fact, she recently finished up a 10-week stint filling in for a third grade teacher on maternity leave at Middlebrook Elementary School.
"It's ironic that when I broke into teaching 25 years ago it was nearly impossible to get a regular job and you were lucky to even have steady work as a sub," said Mrs. Walker, who spent six years as a substitute before being hired in a full-time position.
"Of course I had no idea I would be back here so soon" or, she said, "that I would be filling in for so long. But I felt I had to do it for the children and for the school because I knew they were in a real bind."
School districts are, in fact, so desperate to find qualified substitute teachers they have devised all kinds of solutions. Among them are using administrators in the classroom, hiring and even paying tuition for graduate students who commit to long-term substitute assignments, hiring an increasing number of undergraduate student interns and retired teachers, and even hiring parents.
"We have a lot of parents who were already volunteering as aides in our schools, and as long as they meet the requirements to be in the classroom we decided to use them as substitutes," said the Bristol School Superintendent, Ann Clark. About a dozen parents are now on the school district's substitute teacher list, Ms. Clark said.
"We also find that students make excellent substitutes," she said, "because they are trying to line up work for after they graduate, and are energetic, creative and dedicated."
State education officials say the comparatively low pay for substitute teachers -- daily rates can range from $40 in interior parts of the state to $80 in affluent Fairfield County -- is another factor that has reduced the pool of available substitute teachers. Temporary services agencies are paying as much or more to lure workers, particularly women with young children who have to earn enough to justify working and offset high day-care rates, according to state officials.
A spokesman for the state's Education Department, Tom Murphy, said there were several factors "seemingly all coming together at the same time, and the result is that this is a problem that has reached the crisis stage in many districts, and is approaching that in many others."
"Student enrollments are going up," he said, "more teachers seem to be reaching retirement age than every before, and the labor pool is shrinking. That means we don't have enough substitute teachers most days to fill all of the classrooms in the state."
School officials throughout Connecticut say the problem is getting worse. "This year is without question the worst I've ever seen it," said the New Haven School Superintendent, Reginald Mayo, a 32-year veteran who presides over the state's largest school system with more than 20,000 students and 1,400 teachers.
Mr. Mayo said New Haven has taken the lead in taking advantage of the state's decision to grant waivers on a case-by-case basis of a requirement that substitutes have a college degree. The waiver is allowing college students in training to become teachers to fill in as substitutes, and about 25 students are working as regular substitutes in New Haven, Mr. Mayo said.
"We have contracts with Quinnipiac College and the University of New Haven to allow juniors and seniors in their education programs to work as regular substitutes in our schools," said Mr. Mayo, who has also appointed a committee of teachers, administrators and school board members to suggest other solutions.
"We've got to start finding fresh alternatives," Mr. Mayo said. "The problem is not going to go away any time soon."
Some school districts are banding together to address the problem. A six-town consortium -- which includes Wethersfield, Newington, Berlin, Glastonbury, Manchester and Rocky Hill -- has been formed for a pilot program to hire a pool of substitutes who will be guaranteed full-time work beginning in January.
"To me, giving people a commitment of full-time work is one of the best solutions I have heard of," said Patrice McCarthy, deputy director and general counsel for the Connecticut Association of Boards of Education, which represents 144 of the state's 166 school boards.
Some districts, such as Trumbull, are proposing that their substitute teachers be paid more beginning next school year, and are recommending that the staff cut back on the number of days taken for professional reasons so that fewer substitutes are needed.
"This is a problem that has been getting so much worse the past few years, but this is the first year we are actually having a lot of difficulty finding all the substitutes every day that we need," said Ralph Iassogna, the Trumbull associate superintendent. "It's a problem many school systems are facing, and here in Fairfield County it's a particular problem because during a strong economy a lot of the substitutes either have other jobs or don't need to work."
Mr. Iassogna pointed out that being a substitute in 1998 "is also a lot more complex and involved than it was years ago because of the increasing numbers of special students, and because of technology."
He said that part of the problem is that other nearby towns that draw on the same daily pool of about 80 substitutes pay more than the Trumbull rate. "To stay competitive we feel we need to raise the amount we pay and I think other districts are also finding that to be true," Mr. Iassogna said.
In Plainville, the School Superintendent, Max Riley, said there were 93 school days last year when administrators were forced to teach classes because there were not enough available substitutes.
"This is a growing crisis around the nation because so many people who became teachers during the 1960's are now retiring, and with the economy so strong most of the new teachers are getting full-time jobs right away," said Mr. Riley. "In the past, there were plenty of young teachers who were satisfied with just being a substitute for a few years," he said. "Now, they don't have to do that and as administrators we're going to have to make adjustments."

HEADLINE: New London's Feisty Newspaper, The Day

BYLINE: By ANDI RIERDEN 

 BODY:
TWO and a half years ago, when the staff of The Day newspaper in New London showed up at Foxwoods Casino in Ledyard to do the daily drop off, they were promptly escorted off the reservation, newspapers and all.
Saying the paper had written untrue and damaging stories about the tribe being linked to organized crime, the Mashantucket Pequots, who run the nation's largest casino, yanked their advertising and ordered a freeze on any comments to reporters from The Day. 
 The tribe also took out a full page advertisement in The Norwich Bulletin, The Day's competitor, blasting The Day's coverage and proclaiming the tribe's "zero tolerance" stance on organized crime.
Reid MacCluggage, The Day's editor and publisher, shot back with an editorial defending his paper's reporting methods and reprimanding Foxwoods executives for not being more circumspect when hiring employees, particularly those documented in Federal and state records as having ties to organized crime. He wrote that the Mashantuckets deserved credit for dismissing most of the people in question, but added that if he were the tribe's chairman, "I'd want to know how they got on the payroll in the first place. Don't they run background checks?"
Mr. MacCluggage also issued a statement saying he regretted the ban, but that "any attempt to use economic pressure to influence coverage will be unsuccessful." The boycott meant the loss in sales of some 400 papers a day. "They killed us on circulation and advertising," Mr. MacCluggage said. Even so, The Day has rarely shied from controversy. Over the years, everyone from blue-chip corporations to hometown officials has lambasted the newspaper's coverage. As one of a fast-shrinking group of independent daily newspapers, The Day prides itself on its autonomy and willingness to uncover facts, regardless of how unpopular they may prove with major advertisers or subscribers.
This may seem like risky business, especially for a paper that, because of a larger-than-life publisher who took over in 1888, hands over its excess revenues to a nonprofit charity foundation and receives no corporate backing.
But it is that set-up, say Day staffers, that allows the paper to maintain close ties to its community and at same time focus on vigorous journalism instead of stockholders' demands.
Despite Foxwoods' shunning of The Day, the newspaper apparently had plenty of sources to draw from within the casino's ranks and continued to run articles on the casino. A year and a half went by. Then Foxwoods renewed its subscription and advertising and the two parties sat down to air their differences.
"The tribe now has a better understanding of our commitment to the First Amendment," Mr. MacCluggage said, "and we have a better understanding of their sovereignty."
The Foxwoods boycott was certainly not the first time a major power broker in the region shut out the newspaper. In the early 1980's, P. Takis Veliotis, the head of the Electric Boat Company in nearby Groton, ordered employees not to speak with Day reporters after the paper ran articles on cost overruns on a submarine construction project and the company's internal squabbles. (In 1983, Mr. Veliotis fled to his native Greece to avoid prosecution for an unrelated kickback scheme.)
In recent years, Northeast Utilities has taken out full-page advertisements in The Day castigating its coverage in articles beginning in the late 1980's about safety concerns at the company's four nuclear power reactors. Still, the stories and editorials poured forth. In 1996, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission ordered the company to shut down the reactors and later imposed a $2.1 million fine against Northeast Utilities for violations that had occurred for years at the Millstone Plant in Waterford.
Maura J. Casey, whose acerbic musings about the company and the commission on the editorial pages of The Day prompted American Editor magazine to brand them "editorials with fangs," continues to monitor the situation closely. "I'm just doing my job," she said.
In recent years, The Day has twice received the Newspaper of the Year Award from the New England Newspaper Association and the coveted New England Press Association's Horace Greeley Award for "courage and outstanding effectiveness in serving the public."
Although the paper has provoked criticism from town officials and other residents in New London who say its often negative coverage reflects poorly on the city, readers also applaud the paper for tackling touchy issues and saying in editorials when a problem is being mishandled or ignored.
Lucas Held, who has been the director of community relations for Connecticut College as well as editor of The Middletown Press, called the friction between the town and the newspaper healthy and necessary.
"The Day has been pretty supportive of the community," he said, "but at the same time, it maintains a separate voice, which is the highest calling a newspaper can have."
Readers attribute the newspaper's often feisty coverage to Mr. MacCluggage, a former reporter and managing editor of The Hartford Courant. Sitting in his fourth-floor office with his back against a stunning panorama of the Thames River and downtown New London, he exudes commitment to a stubbornly skeptical outlook. An engaging storyteller, he is proud of The Day's independent status, but adds that the paper is no renegade.
"We're actually pretty conservative," he said, noting recent editorials calling for President Clinton to resign from office and The Day's endorsement of Republican candidates. "But we're not afraid to cover the issues."
Raised in Norwich by parents of Irish and Scottish descent, he graduated from the University of Hartford in 1961 and for the next 18 years covered the city and state desks for the Courant. He became managing editor in 1981, not long after Times Mirror Inc. acquired the Courant and appointed Michael J. Davies its editor and publisher.
Mr. MacCluggage called the acquisition good for the paper, but found that Mr. Davies's management style, "was not the kind I could work with." In 1984, he heard about the opening for an editor and publisher at The Day and applied.
The Day had been founded in 1881 by Maj. John A. Tibbets, a politician and Civil War veteran who used the paper as a platform for his Republican ideology. In 1888 the newspaper was sold to Theodore H. Bodenwein, a German immigrant who had dropped out of school at age 12.
Aggressive and inexhaustible, Mr. Bodenwein took charge at an auspicious time. Still recovering from the decline of the whaling industry, New London had found new life in the industrial economy. During the 1890's the city prospered from the new industries and as a summer colony for wealthy New Yorkers. The combination helped boost the readership of The Day as did people's interest in the Spanish-American War.
Mr. Bodenwein modernized and added political zest to the paper through World War I, the Great Depression and the hurricane of 1938. To protect the paper from falling into the hands of a publishing chain, he wrote a will that would have The Day operate under a public trust and the paper's net income be distributed to the Bodenwein Public Benevolent Foundation. To this day, the paper's net income is handed over to the foundation, whose sole trustee is Fleet Bank.
Sheilah Rostow, the director of planned giving for Fleet, said the foundation maintained an advisory board of local citizens that made recommendations to the bank before the money is distributed to community groups. In the past two years, she said, the foundation donated about $600,000 to charities and nonprofit organizations.
"It was very unique and farsighted for Bodenwein to set things up the way that he did," she said. "The foundation has been a major funder in southeastern Connecticut." After Mr. Bodenwein's death in 1939, The Day went through a string of editors and publishers, all of whom had close ties to the newspaper as reporters or managers. When Mr. MacCluggage was hired in 1984, staffers say he infused the paper with an energy it hadn't experienced for years.
To allow readers earlier access to the news, The Day began publishing in the morning instead of the afternoon. Mr. MacCluggage expanded the business, sports and editorial sections and added an arts and regional section.
In recent years, The Day has increased its coverage of national and international news. In the middle of the 1980's the newspaper's weekday circulation jumped to 42,000 from 36,000, with a Sunday circulation of 48,000. To keep pace, Mr. MacCluggage has increased his news staff to 80 from 55, well beyond the rule of thumb that calls for one editorial staff member for every 1,000 subscribers.
As a native of southeastern Connecticut, he said, moving back to the area 14 years ago, "was like coming home." He added, "What I like and dislike about the area is it's smallness. At The Courant I'd walk outside and no one knew who I was. Here people know my face and often come up to me to on the streets. It's more parochial here, but the cultural life is good and it's a great news area."
At the heart of The Day is a cadre of longtime staffers and New London natives who never left. Morgan McGinley, a veteran of 33 years and the president of the National Conference of Editorial Writers, is the editorial page editor and the grandson of John McGinley, The Day's first reporter. John McGinley's sons often played with the young Eugene O'Neill who frequented the McGinley home to escape his drug-addicted mother. O'Neill later wrote the play "Ah Wilderness!" based on the McGinley family.
Gregory N. Stone, a native of nearby Niantic, has worked at the paper 31 years as a reporter and an editorial writer. His book chronicling the history of the newspaper is to be published by The Day Publishing Company in 2000.
As with any other newspaper its size, Mr. Stone said, reporters often use The Day as a stepping stone to a larger metropolitan newspaper or magazine. Yet the paper maintains a long tradition of retaining journalists familiar with the history and people of the region. "Bodenwein always made a point of hiring local reporters right out of high school out of the conviction that they'd make better reporters," he said. "Having this collective memory keeps The Day firmly rooted as a community newspaper."
Even so, readers take the paper to task for printing too much gloomy news and not recognizing the region's positive points. Hard hit by cutbacks in the Pentagon's budget in the wake of the Cold War's demise -- which resulted in thousands of layoffs in the military and related industries -- southeastern Connecticut is on the rebound.
The Foxwoods and Mohegan Sun casinos, which employ about 17,000 people, are open. And, last spring, Pfizer Central Research in Groton announced that it would build a new research laboratory abutting the Thames River in New London, which will eventually employ 2,000 people. The package includes public financing to revitalize New London's downtown and harbor front.
Overall, said Reid Burdick, a city council member who has worked in local government for 30 years, the mood in the city is buoyant -- yet you would never know it by reading The Day. "The Day has become complacent and out of touch with the citizens of New London," he argued, adding, "Here the city is going through this great renaissance and we can't get our hometown paper on board. The paper should be championing the city, yet it's not."
Mr. MacCluggage has heard the complaints before. In a 1996 article under the headline "Newspaper Accused of Negative Coverage of City Issues," several city officials echoed Mr. Burdick's sentiments. Mr. MacCluggage pointed out then and more recently that the paper has been supportive of the city in any number of editorials and articles. But, he added, it is also the newspaper's role to scrutinize newsworthy developments, regardless of public advocacy.
In 1920, when Theodore Bodenwein was at the helm of The Day, 1,650 dailies in the country were independently owned. Today that number has shrunk to 300. Of the 20 dailies in Connecticut, just 6 remain independent. But staff members at The Day say they can not imagine a corporate takeover of their newspaper.
"The board of directors would never let that happen," Mr. MacCluggage said.
"If that ever happened it would cause a tremendous outcry."

HEADLINE: New Chronicler of the Rich and Famous

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA ROWE 

 BODY:
THERE is a certain type of person who routinely sends urgent E-mails at 2 A.M. and insists she cannot think unless she is wearing black. In this particular case, she is a magazine publisher.
The vocabulary of high-end trend-setters may not have been Mary Ann Liebert's prime concern when she brought out The Westchester Wag last October. But her magazine has already attracted attention as much for its name (which refers to gossip, not dogs) as for the celebrity interviews, social events and ratings of take-out places that fill its pages. 
 "People are starting to give me 'the wag' about something," Ms. Liebert said with a laugh. "They say, 'Oh, Mary Ann, let me tell you the wag about this'."
No matter. Getting a new life-style magazine noticed is no small feat and almost any method is fair game.
In an economy where increasingly only the behemoth survive, Ms. Liebert, who owns a 70-employee medical publishing firm in Larchmont, is something of an anomaly.
She dreamed up the concept for a glossy Westchester magazine, paid for the project and specially selected the 350 coffeehouses, beauty parlors, health clubs, doctors' offices, banks and other drop-off points where her free monthly is available. It also comes by subscription, upon request, also free of charge.
Starting a magazine, even one like The Wag with a staff of 10, typically means hemorrhaging thousands, if not millions of dollars, and folding within the first year -- so skeptics might well wonder at Ms. Liebert's sanity. But she and the editor in chief, Diane Straus Tucker, appear unfazed. With almost 31 years of Westchester residency between them (Ms. Liebert moved up from Manhattan in 1983 and Ms. Tucker in 1982), they are confident that what the county needs is a publication devoted to its movers and shakers." To put it bluntly: a magazine that covers the rich.
"I heard about one reader who was negotiating on a car, and the dealer said: 'Oh, you can afford it. I saw your picture in The Wag,' " Ms. Liebert said proudly.
No existing publication reflected what both women called the sophistication of the county's highly educated, affluent residents, those people who might enjoy reading about the home life of the television news interviewer Catherine Crier, gleaning paddle tennis tips from President Kennedy's former adviser, Theordore C. Sorensen, or looking at pictures of their friends at parties and benefits. That type of feature filled the first two issues along with real estate advertisements for houses costing more than $1 million, and social pages filled with black-tie events.
The Wag has a distinctly clubby feel. Celebrities filled the first three issues, most of them people whom Ms. Tucker knew through her career at New York magazine as an assistant editor. The Village Voice as arts editor and and as the publisher of Trader Publications for 13 years.
Future features will include contributions from Seema Boesky (the former wife of Ivan) and Lucie Arnaz (the daughter of Lucille Ball and Desi Arnaz). And despite The Wag's fiercely local bent, Ms. Tucker has written a personal column about Monica S. Lewinsky, her stepsister, for the December issue.
"People want to know about people," Ms. Liebert said. "They want to know how they live, how they play, how they dress. What they do. People are intrigued by celebrity. They're intrigued by success, and they want to be part of that."
Regarding Westchester itself, however, the publisher was not always so smitten.
"I moved up from Manhattan under protest," she said. "My husband's pediatric practice was here, but I went kicking and screaming. I didn't give up my apartment in Manhattan for years because I was sure I'd have very few friends; I'd be intellectually unhappy, and I'd do all of my shopping in city."
To her surprise, Ms. Liebert said she found a community of active cosmopolites. They were involved in politics. They enjoyed the arts. And most of all, she said, "They were people who loved to shop."
In short, they were just her type. Yet she said she rarely read anything about her interesting neighbors, nothing that connected her to a county full of people with similar life styles and interests. Thus was born the idea that became The Wag.
Certainly, some residents will feel left out of the magazine's orbit. A woman in Ossining wrote to lambaste The Wag for its "fairly unrealistic viewpoint of Westchester women and their shopping habits." She continued: "Obviously, you prefer to photograph those who can own their formal wear, rather than rent."
Ms. Liebert is unapologetic. "The Wag will never be all things to all people," she said. "It is definitely upscale."
Though she declined to say how much had been spent on the first three issues, the publisher conceded that with its large format and full color, celebrity-anchored covers, costs had been considerable.
"No effort is being spared to make The Wag a success," she said. "And I can see that people are reading it. People love it."
Random phone calls to Westchester residents in various towns found that while many residents had not yet seen the magazine, those who have have applauded it.
"I like the magazine very much," said Edward Timper, co-owner of the low-key but chic Scarsdale Avenue Cafe. "It's kind of upscale and it's very well put together. My partner and I were just looking at the party pages together a couple of weeks ago. We do like it, very much."
That is sweet vindication for Ms. Liebert, whose dreams were curbed for years by her family and accountant's insistence that she stay focused on her less colorful, though successful, medical publishing projects. Ms. Liebert was not dissuaded.
"The Wag was sort of evolving in my mind," she said. "I could actually see it in my head, see its size and how it should look, all the elements. And I am somebody who's a mountain climber by nature. If I see a mountain, I've got to go up. Anyway, I knew that if we did it right and found the right tone, it would work."
Still, Ms. Liebert cannot keep herself from snapping photographs of readers she sees on the street or occasionally approaching others for reaction.
"I'm very hands on," she said. "Very."
So much so that she hurried off the phone after a recent interview to shop and distribute magazines herself. "I'm running out now with a bunch of Wags under my arm," she said, "because you just never know who you're going to meet."

HEADLINE: ARTS IN AMERICA;
The Dark Side

 BODY:

To the Editor:
 There is an odd yet appropriate conjunction between Michael Kimmelman's article on Steve Wynn's Las Vegas, "In an Unreal City, Real Masterworks Beat the Odds" Dec. 6 , and Edward Rothstein's article "A Shifting American Landscape: Downtown, Theme Parks for the Arts" Dec. 6 . Both essays, though in very different ways, examine what is fast becoming the most significant and potentially most troubling aspect of the arts in America, and that is the realization that they are not only good for business but a vital component of the life of our cities. 
 On the surface, of course, this recognition is nothing short of a triumph, especially in the face of the polarized and decadelong battle over the National Endowment of the Arts.
There is, however, a darker side to this. What happens to the arts when they are understood not as an end unto themselves but as either a marketing ploy, as in the case of Mr. Wynn's Bellagio, or as urban renewal, as in the case of Tulsa, Louisville, Houston and the other cities referred to by Mr. Rothstein?
While it is easy to admire the enriching effect of arts centers on our cultural life, it is less clear what the long-term impact of these will be, as the necessities of filling the house in order to justify ambitious economic expectations result in putting spectacles over programming, commercially successful events over intellectually significant ones.
Similarly, it is impossible not to be impressed by the collection of masterworks that Mr. Wynn has assembled in just a few short years. Yet one has to be concerned about what happens to these objects, and the aura of the artists who made them, when they are reduced to advertising Mr. Wynn's casino. Modigliani's portrait may never have looked better than it did over Bellagio's baccarat table, but that does not mean that it was intended for this use or that the hotel's marquee proclaiming, "Coming Soon -- Van Gogh, Monet, Renoir and Cezanne, With Special Guests Pablo Picasso and Henri Matisse," does not trivialize the artists who made these objects.
Mr. Kimmelman may well be right that the only difference between Mr. Wynn and other collectors, in terms of how they treat their collections, is that Mr. Wynn is more public about his activities. But most collectors, I would argue, are not in the business of simultaneously selling their enterprises by promoting their art and selling their art by promoting their enterprises, to paraphrase Mr. Kimmelman. At the risk of sounding like an elitist curmudgeon, which my children assure me comes naturally, I wonder if there is not something deeply disturbing about our cultural life when our arts centers become theme parks, and collectors are admired for their ability to commercialize and parody the objects they acquire.
 
GLENN D. LOWRY
New York
 
The writer is the director of The Museum of Modern Art.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
The Privatization of Public Housing in Stamford

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

DATELINE: STAMFORD

 BODY:
LAST year a private developer bought one of the Stamford Housing Authority's most distressed properties; next year another one will be sold to a different developer. The first is now being rehabilitated and the second will be replaced.
Ninety-four buildings with 430 two-story apartments at Rippowam Park are undergoing redevelopment and 500 units at Southfield Village will be demolished and replaced by 330 apartments and town houses. 
 The program under which Rippowam Park is being redeveloped represents a departure in the financing of public housing. It was approved by the State Legislature last year as a two-year pilot program introduced by Representative Christel H. Truglia, a Stamford Democrat. Up to three municipalities may participate. So far Stamford is the only one to do so.
The $36-million cost of the project was raised through $16 million in tax-exempt bonds issued by the Housing Authority, a $6.6 million low-interest loan that the developer will repay to the city and the rest from private investment in low-income housing tax credits.
Under the pilot program, developers and housing authorities may apply as partners to the state's Department of Economic and Community Development for approval of plans to renovate deteriorated public housing. Once approval is granted the developer takes over ownership of the buildings and proceeds without further oversight by the state or the housing authority on construction, maintenance, management and rentals.
The housing authority retains ownership of the land through a 99-year ground lease, which restricts its use to low- and moderate-income housing for the entire term. After that the buildings revert to the Housing Authority.
The terms of the tax-exempt bonds also insure that the low- and moderate-income status of the project continues for 99 years in the event that the developer, in this case Rippowam Park Associates L.P., a division of the Richman Group of Greenwich, exercises its option to buy the entire property within three years, provided that the renovations are complete.
Mayor Dannel Malloy calls the rehabilitation of the complex, now a third of the way completed with 150 refurbished two- to four-bedroom apartments rented to former tenants or newcomers, "trail-blazing."
"This is the trend," he said. "The state won't put the money in that's required to rebuild public housing, which has been allowed to decline over a long period. Rippowam Park has been very successful. The crime statistics have dropped through the basement. Resident satisfaction is high, and people who never would have considered living there are renting apartments."
He said he preferred the state program to Hope VI, a 1993 Federal Housing and Urban Development program that is helping to finance the demolition and reconstruction of Southfield Village. "It's a big country," said the Mayor, "and there's a limit to the number of Hope VI grants." Only 20 a year are awarded nationwide in a highly competitive application process.
BY next August the transformation of Rippowam Park -- a state-subsidized moderate-income housing project formerly known as Ward Homes that was owned and operated by the Housing Authority for 45 years -- is expected to be completed. To date, 20 of the former Ward Homes tenants have been evicted for nonpayment of rent and disqualified from renting one of the new units.
The plans for Southfield Village, which is a federally financed low-income complex, will take at least five years to complete. The result will be a mixed-income, garden-apartment and town house neighborhood with backyards and parking areas, a community pool and a fitness center.
Beacon-Corcoran Jennison Partners, a joint venture of the Beacon Companies and Corcoran Jennison of Boston, will develop half of the 330 new units as federally subsidized rentals for low-income tenants. The other half will be rented to moderate-income tenants, except for 15 town houses, which will be sold.
The 24-acre project received a $26.4 million grant from the Hope VI program, which, like the state plan at Rippowam Park, allows housing authorities to redevelop deteriorated properties by forming partnerships with private developers. The housing authorities turn over ownership, rehabilitation and management of the properties to the developer, but retain the land on a 99-year lease. Other Hope VI projects are under way in Hartford and New Haven.
According to Edward Schwartz, executive director of the Stamford Housing Authority, H.U.D.'s grant will provide leverage for the $80 million that the project will cost. The city provided $3 million as leverage for the Federal grant and, according to Peter Wood, area redevelopment director for Beacon-Corcoran Jennison Partners, "we are applying for low-income housing tax credits and seeking some gap funding from the state."
"Since there is no purchase option for Hope VI projects," added Mr. Schwartz, "we are obligated to supply rent subsidies for the low-income units during the entire 99-year term of the ground lease."
His office oversees 18 public-housing properties in the city, some federally subsidized, others, like Rippowam Park, whose tenants' income may not exceed 60 percent of the area median of $89,300 for a family of four. "People pay 30 percent of their income or the minimum rent, whichever is higher," said Mr. Schwartz. "There are no rent subsidies."
Typically, a single individual earning a minimum of $17,550 pays $508 a month for a two-bedroom apartment, or $585 with a maximum income of $21,875. A family of four at Rippowam Park may earn between $46,620 and $53,580 and pay the minimum $1,415 or the maximum $1,554 a month for a four-bedroom apartment. A two-bedroom market rate apartment in Stamford rents for $1,800 to $2,200 a month.
"We saw nothing in Stamford that was as nice as this that wasn't a lot more expensive," said Beth Hale, who moved to Rippowam Park with her husband, Adam, last October.
Monica Pratcher, a five-year resident with two children, was moved to a vacant apartment while hers was renovated. "It took about three months," she said. "The difference is humongous."
EACH refurbished apartment has a small deck and backyard, fully equipped eat-in kitchen, one or one-and-a-half baths and central air-conditioning. New roofs and siding, rebuilt interiors, plumbing and electrical systems, walkways and landscaping, are standard renovations, and the Richman Group has hired uniformed off-duty policemen to patrol nightly. An independently owned day care center will operate rent-free on the site.
The complex covers 46 acres in a pleasant residential neighborhood known as Westover, across the street from the E. Gaynor Brennan municipal golf course. The terrain, which varies from rolling and wooded to level and grassy, is dotted with playgrounds and small parking lots for residents. Soon a community center will be completed with a gym, kitchen, and meeting rooms. Next door to the complex is the public Westover Magnet School, where Rippowam Park children have priority in the citywide lotteries for admission.
For the last 20 years developers across the country have competed for work turning around distressed public housing, according to Pamela Goodman, senior vice president of the Beacon Companies. "It's nowhere near as lucrative as building $500,000 condos," she said, "and there are days when I wonder whether the risk-reward relationship is in balance. Hope VI just makes it more complicated."
But profits are to be made in public housing that is not for the poorest of the poor. "We collect management fees," said John McClutchy, a partner in Rippowam Park Associates, "and the cumulative amount longterm, paid in rents that escalate by 3 or 4 percent a year, can be substantial." There is a cap, however, on profits of 10 to 15 percent for any state or federally financed housing, he said.
Peter Wood, Beacon-Corcoran Jennison's area director, calls public housing "a niche in our case."
"People on our staff have worked at H.U.D., bringing a great deal of expertise to affordable housing redevelopment," he said.
Ten years ago Corcoran Jennison turned an almost vacant 1,400-unit public-housing project in Boston into an award-winning mixed income complex called Harbor Point. Currently, it is working on Hope VI projects in New Haven, Boston, Pittsburgh and Detroit.
"They are only part of our overall portfolio, and we don't anticipate future cash flow on these jobs," Mr. Wood said. "But they contribute positively to our reputation, and we expect to break even, at least. It's a threshold question as to whether or not we will continue to do Hope VI projects."
