HEADLINE: OLYMPICS: Purity vs. Reality;
Scandal Points Out Pressure in Quest for the Olympics

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN

DATELINE: SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 19

 BODY:
When Salt Lake City lost by only four votes to Nagano, Japan, to play host to the 1998 Winter Olympics, it became a heavy favorite to win the 2002 Winter Games.
Salt Lake City's advantages were plentiful: it would be the largest city to be host of a Winter Games. Many of its sports facilities were already under construction. The airport was 15 minutes from downtown, and major highways would carry spectators to every event in no more than an hour. 
 Essentially, all the city had to do was protect a big lead.
It did, winning in a landslide, but the manner of Salt Lake City's victory has become the focus of an investigation into charges of bribery and corruption that have further damaged the credibility of an Olympic movement already staggered this year by an unprecedented series of doping scandals.
The Salt Lake City scandal has provided the most unsparing glimpse yet of the tectonic grinding between purist ideals of the Olympics and the economic reality that the Winter and Summer Games are billion-dollar businesses. The 2002 Winter Games have an operating budget of $1.45 billion and are expected to have an economic impact of $2.8 billion for the city.
The process for obtaining an Olympics has been revealed in great, troubling detail by the scandal. Attracting the Games involves far more than simply building stadiums, hotels and highways. It also involves the providing of lavish gifts and favors to members of the International Olympic Committee and their relatives, and the hiring of consultants to make introductions and assert influence with I.O.C. members.
This process, according to Olympic officials, has frequently extended beyond expensive wining and dining into a murky area where the lines are blurred between proper hospitality and improper inducements.
"What was the saying in Atlanta? 'It's a dirty business, I hope it all washes out after it's over,' " said John Ruger, a member of the Salt Lake Olympic organizing committee's board of trustees and a prominent member of the United States Olympic Committee. "The process needs to be cleaned up, no question."
Voting on cities to play host to the Olympics is the most important function for many of the I.O.C.'s 115 members. When they came to visit Salt Lake City before the 1995 vote that determined the host city for the 2002 Winter Games, Salt Lake City offered such gifts as shotguns and skis, hunting trips, free medical care and college scholarships.
Tom Welch, who was president of the bid committee that won the 2002 Winter Games for Salt Lake City, said this courting of I.O.C. members was part of a necessary, long-established ritual to build trust and friendship with people of varying cultures and backgrounds. Salt Lake City spent $14 million in its attempts to win the 1998 and 2002 Winter Games.
"I'm not uncomfortable with the way we handled it," Welch said. "The process works."
Marc Hodler of Switzerland, the second-most senior member of the I.O.C., has another word for Salt Lake City's actions: bribery.
Last weekend, Hodler made incendiary charges that vote-buying had influenced the selection of Atlanta, Nagano and Salt Lake City as Olympic cities, as well as Sydney, Australia, which will be host to the 2000 Summer Games. Salt Lake City officials have acknowledged spending about $400,000 on scholarships and athletic training for 13 people, including six relatives of I.O.C. members, most from Africa.
They have classified the spending as humanitarian aid, not bribery.
Hodler has offered only hearsay, not proof, of his claims of vote-buying, according to Dick Pound, the I.O.C. member from Montreal charged with investigating the Salt Lake City scandal.
In an interview Friday, Pound said that Hodler had produced no direct evidence to support his contention that Salt Lake City was the victim of extortion by so-called agents who offer to deliver blocs of votes for up to $5 million and that as many as 25 I.O.C. members sold their votes in various Olympic-city elections.
"He offered no names, nothing, only what he heard other people say," Pound said of Hodler, who could not be reached for comment.
Still, many in Salt Lake City have expressed shock and anger upon learning that such extravagant -- some say inappropriate -- services must be performed to attract what is billed as the world's most unsullied form of sport.
"The Olympics have become a business," said Ken Bullock, a populist member of the Salt Lake City organizing committee, who has often said that money spent on limousines would be much better spent on youth programs. "They're not about athletes and people. It's an international business."
No city was more eager to attract the Olympics than Salt Lake City. It had been seeking the Winter Games since 1966 as the most persuasive way to demonstrate that great skiing existed in the Rockies in places other than Colorado.
Because the European vote for 2002 would most likely be divided between Sion, Switzerland, and Ostersund, Sweden, Salt Lake City officials appear to have settled on a strategy of shoring up I.O.C. votes in Africa and South America. At that time, Africa accounted for 17 of the I.O.C.'s approximately 110 votes.
Favors to African officials included providing free treatment for hepatitis to Jean-Claude Ganga, an influential I.O.C. member from Congo Republic, according to The Salt Lake Tribune. Richard Anderson, a Salt Lake City plastic surgeon, told The Associated Press that Welch had cajoled him into performing free cosmetic eye surgery for another unnamed I.O.C. member. Welch did not return a call seeking comment.
The Tribune reported today that the bid committee spent nearly $10,000 on shotguns and rifles as gifts for people associated with the Olympics.
"It's easy to sensationalize this and see it in black and white, but it's more blurred than that," Charlie Battle, who served as head of international relations for the Atlanta Olympic organizing committee, said of providing gifts and favors to I.O.C. members.
"There's great pressure to be accommodating. I'm not talking about scholarships or envelopes of money, I'm talking about being nice. Sometimes, with hospitality, you feel like you're doing more than is necessary. But you feel like you have to be as nice as you can. It's a competitive situation, and you want to keep hanging in there."
Under these circumstances, a kind of ethical vertigo can occur, Battle said.
"Are you doing this for humanitarian reasons or are you doing it to sway votes?" Battle said. "It becomes difficult."
Welch said that no one had tried to extort him and that he did not deal with agents who promised they could deliver votes.
However, the Salt Lake City bid committee paid an Egyptian-born man living in Canada, Mahmoud El-Farnawani, $58,000 for consulting services in 1994. He told The Toronto Sun in 1995 that he had "assured" the Arab vote to Salt Lake City officials.
"We have to take this opportunity to clean house and recapture the ground we hope to occupy," Pound said. "We have to show that we set a standard of conduct that is high."

HEADLINE: IMPEACHMENT: ILLINOIS;
In Conservative Town, Mostly Somber Tones

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: WHEATON, Ill. Dec. 19

 BODY:
To many of the staunch conservatives who have disdained Bill Clinton from the start, the impeachment of the President brought unwavering approval but little cheering.
"It's the right thing, but I feel very sad today," said Wyatt Waterman, 42, the assistant manager of a bookstore. "It's not good for the country, and it's not good for us as a nation to watch. But there was no alternative. He committed perjury." 
 In this sharply conservative western suburb of Chicago, the home of Wheaton College, a school that hews to the literal words of the Bible, the vote to put Mr. Clinton on trial in the Senate was greeted with quiet praise, especially for the district's Representative, Henry J. Hyde.
In a barbershop on Front Street, Doug Wicks, a 39-year-old sales manager, said, "Clinton's getting what he deserved," but he added, "I hate to see it -- this man's got a family of his own, and loyal supporters."
To be sure, not everyone was feeling sorry for Mr. Clinton.
"He's a liar, an adulterer, a bribe-taker," said Joe Maurer, 67. "The man is a public disgrace. Not only should he be out of office, he ought to be behind bars."
But most often, people in Wheaton shook their heads and spoke in somber tones. Most said Congress simply had no choice.
To Andy Pilipzcuk, 26, voting against impeachment would have lowered the standard of behavior expected of public officials. "We can't let the next generation think this kind of behavior is acceptable," he said.
Virtually no one here relishes a trial in the Senate. All of Mr. Clinton's critics, and even a defender or two, called on the President to step down.
"I just wish he'd resign," said Nancy Lewis, 46, as she shopped for Christmas presents at the college bookstore, where a book featured in the window was titled, "Tell Me the Truth," about the importance of fidelity and family values.
To Ms. Lewis, punishment was only just for a President who, in her view, had abused his power, especially when it came to women. "I'm not a women's libber at all, but he's taken advantage of women," she said.
Mr. Wicks, who also called on the President to resign, said he mostly feared that a long trial in the Senate could "ruin the economy, the stock market, the holidays."
Even in a place like Wheaton, however, there were people who registered objection to the impeachment of Mr. Clinton over actions tied to a sexual affair, and saw hypocrisy in many of the denunciations.
"Let God judge," said Sunny Hardwick, fairly trembling with anger, as she clipped the hair of a man who sharply criticized the President. Ms. Hardwick said that, as a devout Christian, she was spending her time "praying for the President" instead of throwing stones.
Ruth Volle, too, said she abhorred the actions by Congress, and the invasions into his private life. "From the beginning, he should have just said, 'It's none of your business.' "
But the overwhelming majority of people here said they welcomed the impeachment, even if they found little joy in it.
"We have to uphold the Constitution," said Scott Mathias, 40. "I'm pleased by the impeachment, but saddened. I just don't think there was any choice here."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 29; Column 6; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1341 words

HEADLINE: IMPEACHMENT: THE REACTION;
Americans Benumbed By the Crisis In the Capital

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN 

 BODY:
Many Americans voiced anger, disgust and frustration with the proceedings. Some radiated grim satisfaction. But as President Clinton's long, painful journey from scandal to impeachment ended yesterday, most Americans were just benumbed, inoculated by the seemingly endless months of lies, legalisms and disillusionment with politics, Washington-style.
As the House cast the fateful votes to send perjury and other charges against Mr. Clinton to the Senate for trial, countless Americans paid scant attention, opting for football on television or Christmas shopping, a reflection of polls that had shown that the people overwhelmingly opposed an impeachment that was a forgone conclusion and were sick of the whole mess. 
 Still, there was great drama in the day -- the bombs falling in Iraq, the stunning announcement that Robert L. Livingston would not serve as Speaker and would resign from the House after admitting adulterous affairs, and the realization by many that the impeachment of a President had happened only once before, 130 years ago.
And around the nation, Americans paused in homes, restaurants and shopping malls decked out for Christmas to watch the televised spectacle. Some endorsed the Republican-dominated vote to impeach, insisting that even a President was not above the law, and that impeachment was necessary for moral accountability. Others called on the President to resign and spare the nation months of agony.
But in interviews in New York, Seattle, Boston, Los Angeles, Chicago, Miami, Houston and other cities, most people, while deploring Mr. Clinton's behavior in trying to cover up his affair with Monica S. Lewinsky, said they opposed impeachment, calling it excessive punishment and perhaps harmful to the nation.
"It strikes me as dangerous," Greg Noonan, a law student at Harvard, said as the impeachment vote flashed on a television screen at the Three Aces restaurant in Cambridge, Mass. "And most infuriatingly of all, it strikes me as completely ignoring the will of the American people."
In Seattle, several people working out at the Olympic Athletic Club shook their heads in disgust as the vote unfolded on overhead screens. "I'm very, very saddened and I'm very, very angry," said Ross Carey, a doctor, who said the Republicans had "put politics ahead of what is best for the country."
Bob and Carol Wentink, a Chicago couple, said impeachment seemed excessive for what the President did. "It's a shame," Mr. Wentink, 54, an electronics designer, said. "I think there's too much interest in private lives. While he did wrong, I don't think he deserves to be impeached." His wife, a retired teacher, added: "I think it's a huge mistake. It's going to affect the way people around the world look at us."
Evan Ackerman, 28, a financial consultant in Miami, also called impeachment inappropriate. "But that doesn't necessarily mean I like Clinton," he added. "Even if he is a sleazebag, they should wait until he leaves office. He should be scolded, sued for millions of dollars, reprimanded."
Greater forgiveness was to be found at the Hair Place, a beauty salon in the New York City borough of Queens. "So he lied under oath," said Diane Barnett, 41, an office manager who lives in Roosevelt, L.I. "That's a petty issue. Everybody lies. It's like his wife said: there are so many other issues, like hunger and health care, to be concerned about."
Paul Trageser, 62, a silversmith from Cincinnati, said the impeachment had been motivated by pure politics. "It's partisan, it's unfair, it's a witch hunt," he said in Los Angeles, where he was visiting. "I'm sick of what the Republicans have done over the past few years -- so squeaky clean and hypocritical. It's sad and bizarre."
Around the country, however, there were many who approved of impeachment.
"Hooray," yelled Ann Jewel, who heard the news as she wheeled a cart full of grocery bags in Chicago.
A 57-year-old receptionist for an insurance company and the mother of five children, Ms. Jewel said she had voted twice for President Clinton, but had come to believe that he betrayed the country and was not sincere in his many apologies. "He put his hand on the Bible and lied," she said. "A lot of things can be forgiven, but to be forgiven a person has to be sorry. He cannot be forgiven just because he is caught."
In Houston, Monika Miura, 48, a legal librarian, said Mr. Clinton, like any citizen, had to be called to account for lying under oath. "If anyone needs to be above reproach and needs to be an honorable individual, it should be the President," she said. "This is not an issue about sex. This is an issue about honor and truthfulness."
Gertrude Jackson, 75, a retired Chicago department store cashier, also said she favored impeachment, and that it was not about sex. "Everybody knew when he was elected that he was a woman-chaser," she said. "He just got too big for his britches. He broke the law."
In Denver, John Harless, a 53-year-old retired banker, said Mr. Clinton had no one to blame but himself. "It's a somber moment, and I'm not happy about it," Mr. Harless said. "He did some good things. It's too bad he recklessly endangered the office of the President. He ruined his own Presidency."
At the Market coffee shop in Denver, Cherish Finn spoke of Mr. Clinton in the past tense, as if he were already gone, though the outcome of his trial in the Senate remains in doubt.
"I think he was a good leader," Ms. Finn said. "This has been a good time in our country. We had a great four years with him, and he had the potential to do something with this country. He should have been honest. This society is based on forgiveness, and he made a mockery of the system by lying."
Hardly anyone defended Mr. Clinton, but many expressed concern over the possible effects of his impeachment -- on the economy, on the stability of government, on the conduct of foreign affairs and on the future of the nation.
"This is dog eat dog now -- not 'of the people, for the people,' " said Vic Lysell, 50, a paint salesman who had stopped for breakfast at Johnny's diner in Seattle's waterfront Ballard neighborhood. "This is not our system at work, it's the G.O.P. at work. It's crazy."
Ed Wetzel, sitting nearby, needed a jolt of coffee to digest the news. He said he opposed impeachment, but added that now that it was a fact, Mr. Clinton should "strongly consider" resignation. "This thing would be the focus of the whole next year," he said. "The entire country would suffer for it."
The owner of Johnny's, John Khalil, disagreed. Referring to Republicans, he said: "They are pushing hard to destroy this man any way they can, and it's wrong. Now the President needs to battle back."
For many Americans, impeachment was just another occasion to condemn Mr. Clinton. "What the President did was shameful, and I think he has to pay the price," said Al Habib, 54, a Brooklyn pharmacist. "He's a very bad role model for the younger generation. The right thing to do is remove him from office."
But others denounced the forces against him. "The whole thing stinks," said Susan Macina, 35, who lives in Brooklyn and Hollywood, Fla. "What the President did was terrible, but not impeachable. It's an offense in his personal life. We elected him twice without knowing about his affairs. I think there are going to be mass protests in this country."
But there was little sign of protest yesterday. Indeed, tours of shops, cafes and other public places in a half-dozen cities found many people ignoring the telecast from Capitol Hill. Kevin James, 29, working at a juice bar in Seattle, said he was more concerned with Christmas shopping and finding a new apartment.
Cindy Carlson, a 45-year-old college English professor in Denver, called the impeachment historic, but not comparable to the Watergate proceedings that led to the resignation of President Nixon. "I cried during Watergate," she said. "I felt the American way of life was threatened. Now I think it's different. The country will survive this."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 5; National Desk

HEADLINE: IMPEACHMENT: NEWS ANALYSIS;
What Next? Don't Guess

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19

 BODY:
The only thing certain now is uncertainty.
The smart money shouts that President Clinton will never resign, and he vows to serve "until the last hour of the last day" of his second term. The smart money argues that the Senate will never muster the 67 votes needed to remove the wounded President from office, which would require the defection of 12 Democrats if all the Republicans stand against him. The smart money insists that someone will cut a deal soon to end all this. 
 Maybe so. But the smarter money whispers, "Remember."
Remember that everyone in Washington, including Representative Henry J. Hyde, the chairman of the Judiciary Committee, said the House would never, ever, vote impeachment along partisan lines. Wrong. Remember that all the pundits predicted Democratic losses in the mid-term elections, and when the opposite happened, they said impeachment was dead. Twice wrong.
And remember that in the new year the nation will travel down a road it has never traveled before. One other President, Andrew Johnson of Tennessee, has been tried by the Senate, of course. But that happened in a different country -- one with only 37 states, with primitive communications, with a simple economy based on agriculture, with minimal commitments abroad.
In the toxic politics of century's end in Washington, the inconceivable has become the commonplace.
The wholly unanticipated announcement this morning by Representative Robert L. Livingston, Republican of Louisiana, that he would not serve as Speaker and would resign from Congress, after his equally unanticipated disclosure on Thursday night of several extramarital affairs, only deepened the capital's profound sense of insecurity.
The deadly sweep of the scythe of neo-Puritanism appears unstoppable, at least for the moment, and Mr. Livingston's forthcoming resignation will increase the pressure on the President to do likewise.
"You've set before us an example," the leader of House Republican majority, Representative Dick Armey of Texas, told Mr. Livingston today. "The example is that principle comes before power."
The Democrats made the opposite point, arguing that the Livingston case showed how wrong it was to savage people for personal failings.
One transcendentally important thing remains the same: Although surrounded by judicial trappings and presided over by the Chief Justice, the President's trial will be a political process, with power residing in the hands of politicians. In addition to narrow legal issues of guilt or innocence, the senators can weigh considerations of party, the nation's future, their own political well-being and anything else they care to weigh in reaching a verdict.
The longer they take, the more numerous the appeals for resignation are likely to be. Even before today's epochal roll-calls, 4 of 10 Americans interviewed in the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll said they thought that the President should step down if he was indicted even though a large majority voiced disapproval of the impeachment proceedings.
What lies behind that seeming contradiction is the fear that Mr. Clinton, and the country with him, would be incapacitated. No one took Andrew Johnson very seriously after he escaped conviction by a single vote.
But Mr. Clinton, a man of powerful will whose whole life has been a series of comebacks, has already embarked on an effort to show that he can do the nation's business. Richard M. Nixon clawed his way back to respectability after leaving the White House; Mr. Clinton intends to re-establish his authority while still in office. He has one great advantage: two-thirds of the American public continues to voice its approval of his political stewardship, whatever it thinks of him as a man.
For those Americans and for Congress, too, Mr. Clinton, puffy-eyed, set out an agenda late this afternoon in the Rose Garden. He talked of Social Security reform, but also of negotiating "a prompt solution" that would end the impeachment crisis in "a constitutional and fair manner."
The President will press hard, despite his much-reduced leverage, for a deal on censure. Indeed, in as fine a piece of political irony as one could ask for, he has already sought to enlist former Senator Bob Dole, the Republican he defeated in 1996, as an emissary to the Senate majority. The numbers are not unpromising: with the help of 6 Republicans, the 45 Democrats could end the trial at any time and pass a censure resolution that the House would surely take up.
There are enough Republican moderates and sometime party-buckers to make that a plausible target. But the Republican Senate leader, Trent Lott, who has made his unwillingness to take the President's word evident in recent days, is determined to fight such an arrangement.
It is clear that Mr. Clinton's reputation has been stained forever, no matter what the Senate does. The spot will not out. History will remember this man who so coveted a glowing legacy not as an impresario of economic growth, not as the Moses who pointed the way to the 21st century, but as the second President ever to be impeached, if not as the first to be ousted.
That harsh word, "impeachment," will cling to his name as surely as "Teapot Dome" clings to Harding's.
But he is not alone in having suffered grievous injury in the political avalanche that was shaken loose by the disclosure of Mr. Clinton's sexual relationship with a former White House intern, Monica S. Lewinsky.
The Republicans' public support has shriveled to 40 percent in the new Times/CBS News poll, its lowest level in 14 years, and it could go lower once the fact of impeachment sinks in. Journalists are seen by many as jackals, indifferent to whatever personal suffering or national angst they may cause as long as they get the story, and none too concerned about accuracy.
In fact, the whole political culture of the 1990's, with its criminalization of political conduct and its seeming indifference to important national and international issues, has fallen into disrepute with Americans.
The last week seemed to crystallize the long-term decline in political civility. Republicans called the President a liar, even as he was committing American pilots to the skies over Iraq, and Democrats accused their Capitol Hill rivals of conducting a political lynching or coup d'etat.
Bipartisanship may have been the biggest victim of all. Party lines on today's critical first roll-call held as firm as leg irons. Almost all of the Republicans who voted against that article did so not exclusively on legal principle but at least partly because of special political circumstances -- the Democratic majority in Representative Constance A. Morella's district in the Maryland suburbs of Washington, for example, and the gratitude of Representative Peter T. King of New York for Mr. Clinton's peacemaking in Ireland.
On later ballots, the polarization was less marked, and two of the four articles voted by the Judiciary Committee were defeated, suggesting that some careful consideration of legal issues took place.
It is hard to see who has emerged from the long ordeal with reputation enhanced, except perhaps Hillary Rodham Clinton, ever staunch in the face of deception.
If some of the dire predictions uttered by House Democrats recently are to be taken at face value, the nation is entering upon an Era of Bad Feelings, the polar opposite of a second Era of Good Feelings, similar to that of the 1820's, that Mr. Clinton had hoped to preside over.
Representative Tom Sawyer of Ohio, a Democrat, compared Mr. Clinton on Friday to Sir Thomas More, executed for treason in 1535 because of his religious beliefs. Mr. Sawyer quoted More's words as an admonition for today: "What you have hunted me for is not my actions but for the thoughts of my heart. It is a long road you have opened. God help the statesmen who walk your road."
But with all the loose talk about permanent damage to this institution or that, remember: Things change with startling speed in modern American politics, and the institutions of American government have proved extraordinarily resilient. Nixon, it was almost universally agreed in 1974, had weakened the American Presidency for many decades to come. Nobody said that after 8 years under Ronald Reagan, only 15 years later.

HEADLINE: Truth, Fiction and Human Rights

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The controversy over "I, Rigoberta Menchu," cannot be fully understood without an appreciation of how its literary-polemical form, the testimonial, emerged in the 1970's and 1980's (front page, Dec. 15).
The testimonial is an epistolary form that grew out of the relationship between popular movements on the isthmus and solidarity movements in the United States and Western Europe. The goal of the testimonial was to convey sociological facts to a Northern audience through an exemplary autobiographical story -- and to thereby solicit moral, political and economic support for local struggles. 
Ms. Menchu seems to have told her story in a manner that force-fits her experiences into the social analysis she wished to dramatize. But narrative devices like the shading of events that might be acceptable in an ethnographic work or historical novel undercut the authority of a text that purports to tell the unvarnished truth.
 
ROGER LANCASTER
Fairfax, Va., Dec. 17, 1998
 
The writer is an associate professor of anthropology, George Mason University.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORTS: NEW YORK ON LINE;
Homeless Portray Their World

BYLINE: By DAVID KIRBY 

 BODY:
Give a man a fish, the old proverb goes, and he'll eat for a day. Give a homeless man a camera, Michael Rennick figured, and he will document a day on the cold, hard streets. On a Web site called Vagrant Gaze, Mr. Rennick has posted the photography of four homeless men in New York, along with text from his interviews with them.
 Mr. Rennick, a doctoral student in cultural studies at Teachers College of Columbia University, said he had found the four men panhandling in various Manhattan neighborhoods. He gave each a disposable camera, asking them to shoot images of their world and return a day later. He then interviewed and photographed the men, paying each $20. 
 "One day I was wondering what happens in subway stations late at night," Mr. Rennick said. "For a second and a half, I thought of giving cameras to the homeless to record everything. After realizing that was a stupid idea, I thought it would be more interesting to ask them to shoot their own worlds."
 He conceded that viewing the world of the homeless through a Web site "is obviously removed from face-to-face contact." Yet, he said, "Many people say it's an eye-opener to find the person behind the face that they pass by every day."

WHAT YOU SEE -- Four sets of color photographs, some banal, some hauntingly beautiful, depicting the life of the homeless with utterly unsentimental candor. It's an outdoor world of lonely streetscapes, stone facades, doorways, stairwells and remote park benches.
 The interviews bring the pictures to startling life. Michael Hartman says he "went crazy in the service -- special operations, Cambodia, Laos, Vietnam." He scraped together money to buy medicine for his sick cat, Mookie, he says, and uses military training to keep warm at night. And he says he stays away from his family to spare them his "nightmares."
 Charles Wilson used to have a wife, job and normal life. Now he's broke and on the street, unable to ever see his five children. "At Columbia," he says, "they have a grate where the heat comes up and it blows like a bubble. It gets so hot you have to take your coat off." Another man, Kevin King, whom Mr. Rennick occasionally sees near Teachers College, says he became mentally ill, and then homeless, after a fire killed his daughter.
 Mr. Rennick said he would update the site soon with photos from other homeless New Yorkers, displaying them in slide-show fashion with their own recorded voices as well as text to narrate the images. Though he'd like to expand the site to include homeless people around the world, he said: "I'm a grad student with two jobs. It's impossible."
 
LINKS -- To advocacy group sites like that of the National Coalition for the Homeless and the Homeless Homepage, and to other photo essays, including "Waste of Space," an on-line exhibition by unemployed artists.
 
WHAT YOU GET -- A poignant, brutally honest and starkly personal, if antiseptic, glimpse into the world of the homeless. DAVID KIRBY
 
VAGRANT GAZE
http://www.perfekt.net/ vagrant/homeless.htm

LENGTH: 817 words

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
Panics Always Start In Left Field

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
THINK back to late summer and early fall. Financial panic seemed the order of the day. On top of the Asian troubles came the Russian meltdown, and as investors fled these and other developing regions, lending dried up or pulled back everywhere. Even the United States seemed in danger of tumbling into recession.
All that is history now. Or is it? 
 The American economy is perking along energetically, shrugging off the Iraqi bombing and the impeachment proceedings. The year-end forecasts from many quarters are for continued good times, or at least not frightening times. East Asia and Russia are unlikely to produce new episodes of financial panic. How can they? The big investors there have either yanked their money or lost it. There is no longer the wherewithal in these regions for another round of capital flight, another round of plunging currencies and another round of economic collapse.
But the financial system that gave rise to the East Asian and Russian crises is still in place, and trouble could erupt elsewhere -- suddenly, unexpectedly -- setting off a fresh round of financial panic, with its aftermath of painful recessions. "Potential trouble is not easily calculable," said Paul Volcker, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. "When it happens, it tends to be off the charts."
The debate over what lies ahead has settled into two channels -- one traditional, the other haunting. The attention these days is focused mainly on the traditionalists, who concern themselves with standard economic forces. The consensus view, or at least the most common view among them, is that the American economy will slow next year as consumers pull back on both their extraordinary spending and their extraordinary borrowing to finance their spending. But almost no forecaster foresees a recession.
Falling prices for many goods and a very low inflation rate are squeezing corporate profits, they note. That can hurt the stock market. But with the economy holding up so well, nervousness that stock prices might really plunge has faded along with alarm about the Asian and Russian crises. True, stocks may not go higher, said James Glassman, a senior economist at Chase Manhattan Bank. They may even fall some. But "we don't think there is a bubble propping up the stock market," he said.
Above all, there is faith that the Federal Reserve has the leverage to give the economy enough stimulus, through lower interest rates, to counteract any blow from abroad.
"The worst may well be over for a battered and bruised global economy," wrote Stephen S. Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, in his latest forecast.
Mr. Roach anticipates rising economic growth around the globe by 2000 -- even in East Asia, now mired in recession. One stimulus, he says, is the $160 billion in loans and loan commitments that the International Monetary Fund has disbursed in rescue packages.
All this is rather traditional forecasting. At a less audible level, there are some haunting caveats from the less sanguine.
The worriers acknowledge that Asia, Russia, Brazil and Japan are not likely to prompt the next financial panic: Those countries' problems, while acute, are known and are being dealt with, more or less. And investors here and abroad, scared by Asia and Russia, have been paying down debt. No one knows exactly how much debt has been reduced, but it is likely that when the next panic comes, there will be fewer borrowers in danger of default or forced into hasty actions that make matters worse.
Panics, though, are responses not to known dangers but to events no one thought would happen. No one is, for example, anticipating that Argentina will default on foreign debts or devalue a currency that is pegged by law to the dollar. Neither is anyone expecting a rude shock to come from right here in the United States, said Albert Wojnilower, an economist at the Clipper Group, a Wall Street firm.
But it could. Business debt in the United States, rising for several years, jumped sharply in the third quarter, to $522 billion, the Federal Reserve reported recently. That is equivalent to about 6.5 percent of the gross domestic product, a very high level of business debt.
What if an indebted multinational, its profits squeezed by falling prices, found itself unable to keep up the payments on its loans? Mr. Wojnilower wondered. That picture is conceivable, but in today's rosy economic climate, it is certainly unanticipated. Of such surprises are financial panics made.
Nervous lenders would pull back again. In a global market where money flows freely everywhere, the blow to America would spread. Short-term loans might be called in from potentially shaky emerging markets. And a debate that has faded in recent months -- how to regulate capital flows and how to make the I.M.F. a more effective agency -- would once again take center stage.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 27, 1998, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
The Economic View column last Sunday, about the possibility of future financial crises around the world, misstated the amount of business debt in the United States at the end of the third quarter. It was $5.13 trillion, not $522 billion.

The New York Times

 

PUB-DATE: December 20, 1998

SECTION: Section 6; Page 62; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 5786 words

HEADLINE: The Anti-Trump

BYLINE: By James Traub; James Traub is a contributing writer for the magazine. His most recent article, about Cornelius Olive, a deacon in Harlem, appeared in November.

 BODY:
It would not be correct to say that jerry i. speyer has the most toys of any real-estate developer in New York; he does, however, have the best toys. Last year, in partnership with the Travelers Group and Lehman Brothers, he bought the Chrysler Building, for $220 million. Two years before that, he came within an ace of buying Rockefeller Center, and eventually settled for a small stake, in partnership with Goldman, Sachs; David Rockefeller; Gianni Agnelli; and Stavros Niarchos: it is Speyer, however, who is charged with restoring the property to its former glory. Speyer built, and owns, the second-tallest building in Europe, the 62-story Messeturm, in Frankfurt. He has also built, and still owns, a mahogany-toned granite office tower at 520 Madison Avenue, not to mention major commercial buildings in Houston, Chicago, San Francisco, Washington, Miami and Berlin. He is in the process of building two more structures in Berlin and one in Sao Paulo, a retail complex in Yonkers and an apartment building on lower West End Avenue. His company, Tishman Speyer Properties, owns a total of 36 million square feet of space; Speyer places the market value of the company's holdings at $10.5 billion. His friend Bernard Mendik, who plies the same trade at a more modest level, says, "Right now, Jerry is the No. 1 real-estate developer in the world."
 Speyer is not, of course, the most famous developer in the world. Not only is he not Donald Trump, he is the anti-Trump -- a soft-spoken, muted, secretive figure, an eminently clubbable man who keeps his ego under wraps. Speyer does not name buildings after himself. He has a second wife who is thin and attractive, but she is also a Harvard-trained architect who works on international acquisitions for Tishman Speyer. And yet, like Donald Trump, Speyer, who is 58, is a driven man with ambitions that carry him far beyond the world of real estate. It's just that it's not easy to say exactly what it is Speyer wants to be at the pinnacle of. He has played a central role on the boards of Columbia University and the Museum of Modern Art, and he is close to the Mayor. He is a major collector of contemporary art, and he has built for himself one of the very few architecturally daring private homes in Manhattan. He operates in that elite sphere in which wealth, public-spiritedness and proper table manners converge to form a colossal nexus of power, but one almost invisible to the outside world. As Speyer enigmatically explained: "One thing that sets me apart from the people who are entrepreneurs in this business is that I like to make money. But that's only part of what makes me happy." 
 In conversation, Speyer often told me how he preferred to "fly beneath the radar." And yet he agreed not only to talk to me but also to let me watch as he met with his own executives, other developers, major tenants and officials at the Modern. He even tried to get me into a private meeting at Gracie Mansion. When I asked, Speyer couldn't say why he had so opened himself up for scrutiny. Perhaps he is something of a mystery even to himself. Burt Lehman, a corporate lawyer and a friend of Speyer's since college, observes that "Jerry loves the image of being a very important man in New York without necessarily cultivating that the way a Donald Trump does." There is a kind of exalted standing that comes of not being seen to seek any standing at all.
This is a turbulent moment in the New York real-estate world. The boom of the last few years has been fueled by investment banks like Nomura Securities and Credit Suisse First Boston, which dumped billions into the real-estate market and then repackaged the resulting mortgages and sold them as securities. That market collapsed over the summer when the banks suffered heavy losses from investments in Asia and Russia. Several major developers, including Harry Macklowe, found that they had committed themselves to deals they could not finance. Capital is scarce these days. But not for Speyer: in 1997, Tishman Speyer and the Travelers Group put together an $800 million investment fund, which Speyer's company oversees. Speyer has already spent most of this amount -- on the Chrysler Building, among other properties -- and is now circulating to financial institutions an offering designed to raise another $750 million.
 Over the past several months, I spent a good deal of time sitting at Speyer's conference table while he considered deals and met with industry figures. The table itself was a beautiful slab of blond, burled wood with slender drawers for yellow pads and pencils and a little square of black marble in the center where an extra pair of Speyer's glasses always rested. A maid in a light blue uniform with an apron would come in with a glass of cold water or Diet Coke on a silver tray. It was all quite immaculate.
 Speyer himself is a pudgy fellow with a boxer's jutting chin and flattened planes; he has a way of talking out of the side of his mouth that is almost endearing in a man so self-consciously respectable. With his employees, he was casual and often jovial. Nevertheless, he had a few highly effective mechanisms of control. Sometimes he went so long without speaking as to completely unnerve the person across the table. Complicated crosscurrents were at play beneath Speyer's smooth surface: he invariably wore a dark tie and a white shirt, though underneath the starched cuff he sported a Mickey Mouse watch -- a kind of secret sign that he held himself ever so slightly apart from the corporate conventions that he otherwise scrupulously observed.
 During my visits, it often seemed as if the whole world were being parceled out at the conference table for Speyer's delectation. He pulled out of Southern California in the early 90's when things started to head south, and now he was moving back in; he kicked around a dozen or so proposals with the head of his new Los Angeles office. He brought in his wife, Katherine Farley, who was impressively crisp, and his man in South America, Hernan R. Martinez, to talk about whether the time was ripe for new investment in Brazil or Argentina. (It wasn't.) He talked with his son, Robert, who joined the business three years ago, about opportunities in New York: Alphabet City, the meat-packing district, East Harlem. He discussed deals in Japan, Spain, Palm Beach. He ducked into his office to take phone calls. A Washington lawyer called to say that the Administration was preparing a $40 billion loan package for Brazil -- this a good month before the announcement was made. Hank M. Paulson Jr., co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs, reported that the derivatives market was going haywire.
 One morning, when a friend of his whose net worth is in the high nine figures called, Speyer asked to have the call transferred to the conference room. He took the phone and, in a streetwise, real-estate-guy mode that I didn't entirely recognize, said, "You're my pal, and so I'm telling it to you straight." Speyer talked up his investment fund. He and Sanford I. Weill, the co-chairman of Citigroup, the company formed out of the merger of Travelers and Citibank, had agreed to add 75 $1 million units to the fund, to be offered to friends and favored clients. Speyer told his friend that his firm controlled the fund and that he expected profits of more than 20 percent. (Speyer says that his own company has generated a staggering 47.5 percent internal rate of return annually over the last five years.) Speyer's pal obviously didn't need either the $1 million or the profit he could earn on it, and when we talked about the call later, I described the transaction as a favor. Speyer shot me a look that implied I had a vulgar conception of behavior at the uppermost reaches of the business world. "It's not a favor," he said. "It's more about relationships." That was presumably why Speyer had taken the call in front of me; he wanted me to understand the meaning of "relationships" at his elevated level. The word "favor" apparently carried an unpleasant connotation of back-scratching; "relationships," of course, were. . .altogether different.
 In the great hierarchy of business activities, real estate is many leagues below investment banking in respectability, and only a notch or two above car dealerships. Speyer, however, has found a way of talking about his profession that makes it sound intellectually exciting. "I think of real estate as a little bit like cooking or like art," he said one afternoon. "Real estate is dependent on a way of thinking that is very different from the way that, for example, financial engineers look at a project. Financial engineers look at a piece of paper that's 8 1/2 by 11, look at a set of numbers and try to figure out how that relates to demographics or marketplace. But if you're a developer, you have to think about things that move you out of the box -- how it's going to affect its place, its landscape or its streetscape."
Speyer's greatest coup, his purchase of the Chrysler Building, was a triumph of imagination, financial engineering, relationships and nerve. The Chrysler Building is, of course, the toy of all toys -- the one skyscraper that provokes a sense of awe from even the veriest Philistines. It had also been, for almost 40 years, a neglected, underused asset. When the banks that held its mortgage put the building on the market last year, it provoked one of the greatest stampedes in New York real-estate history; virtually every major figure in the city submitted a bid. The real action, however, lay not with the banks but with the owner of the land under the building, the Cooper Union; it was understood that whoever succeeded in renegotiating the land lease with the school would then be able to reach a deal with the banks. Speyer was one of eight developers considered by Cooper Union officials. But during the final interview process, Speyer agreed to pay a significant premium in exchange for pre-emptive rights to the land. Speyer's team negotiated the new lease, and the interviews became moot. One of the other finalists, Steven C. Witkoff, says, "It was a great masterstroke on his part, and I think it's the best deal I ever missed."
 But Cooper Union might not have offered the same deal to Witkoff or the other competitors. Robert Hawks, Cooper Union's vice president, says: "We asked him to jump out of the pack. We had come to the conclusion that under the right terms, we wanted Tishman Speyer." Cooper Union is a full-tuition scholarship institution whose unique status depends on the revenue thrown off by the Chrysler Building; what the school needed, above all, was someone to safeguard the building's future value. It mattered that Speyer was part owner of Rockefeller Center, which had been built at the same time as the Chrysler Building. But Speyer's marketplace power also rests, in a strange way, on the perception that he transcends the marketplace. Hawks says: "The people who work for him, his prior involvement with Columbia University, his current involvement with MOMA have to affect one's thinking about the quality of the individual and the approach that he and his company would take to the building. The selection of the art that he has in his office also speaks to that." Or, as Jay Iselin, Cooper Union's president, puts it, "Often it's the unspoken that guides the spoken."
 Of course, the spoken mattered, too. Speyer could afford to sweeten his bid because he saw a way to squeeze more revenue out of the site. The deal included a thoroughly undistinguished structure nearby called the Kent Building; between it and the Chrysler Building lay four brownstones that the winner would purchase, perhaps constructing a low building to connect the two skyscrapers. The Kent Building was not only ugly but also inefficient, since the elevator core lay not in the center but to one side of the structure, a design that wastes space. Speyer and his team realized that they could break through one of the brownstones and extend the Kent Building 80 feet, thus placing the elevator core in the middle of the new structure; doing so would increase the amount of leasable space. Then Speyer proposed a highbrow touch: he hired Philip Johnson to design something eye-catching atop the low connecting structure, and Johnson devised what he calls "a deconstructed pyramid." Valerie Peltier, one of Speyer's daughters, who is heading up the redevelopment process, said that Johnson will also reclad the Kent Building. "In gold glass?" I asked. Donald Trump had commissioned Johnson to cover the Gulf & Western Building in gold. Peltier reeled in horror. "In smoky gray glass," she said. "What architects do depends on the client."
You can learn a good deal about Jerry Speyer from watching him eat. One morning in September, I joined him for breakfast at the Carlyle Hotel, where he had agreed to meet with P.C. Chatterjee, who runs a global-investment company. Speyer occupied the restaurant's seat of honor, on a flowered circular banquette beneath a magnificent urn brimming with white lilies and pear leaves. He and Chatterjee exchanged global-economy chitchat -- the millennium bug, the Euro conversion, the "software gap." Speyer ordered one of those bizarre breakfasts consumed almost only by powerful middle-aged men: an egg-white omelet, very well done, with seven-grain toast. As Chatterjee tried unsuccessfully to interest him in a real-estate joint venture -- too small, too much risk for the profit -- Speyer lapsed into one of his disconcerting silences. He began to consume his meal with comical fastidiousness, cutting the omelet into identical rectangles and pushing each one in turn against the edge of his toast until it rested on the center of his fork. It was a performance that seem designed either to rein in a large appetite or to impose a kind of transcendent tidiness on the act of eating. Not coincidentally, Speyer's princely demeanor had the effect of unsettling Chatterjee.
 One of the things you learn from watching Speyer is that there are ways of being powerful that don't much fit the picture of the brash tycoon celebrated in the tabloids. Speyer is related to Donald Trump the way Carlo Gambino is to John Gotti; he represents an older, and perhaps far more potent, model of the powerful man. Speyer says that when he was young he wanted to be a merchant banker, and the words themselves conjure an anachronistic ideal of propriety and probity that means a great deal to him. Sandy Weill, who has known Speyer socially for 20 years or so, says: "My feeling is one of complete trust. To feel that you don't have to dot every 'i' and cross every 't' is a great way to deal with people." Speyer is almost universally admired, especially at the upper altitudes, but his manner also has the effect of keeping people at a slightly uneasy distance. Ben Lambert, a real-estate banker who has known Speyer since the 60's, says: "Jerry's not an open person. That would suggest that he doesn't really trust people an inch closer than he can be comfortable with."
 Speyer always met me in the conference room rather than in his adjoining office. One morning, I persuaded Speyer's longtime assistant, Carol Karpel, to let me see the office. Speyer's desk was littered with toy trucks and taxis and all sorts of bric-a-brac. There was a relaxed and cluttered feel to the place that was almost the reverse of the austerely tasteful decor of the conference room -- the cozy private space of a man who arranges his public space with great care. Speyer came in and quickly led me back outside. About half an hour later, while we were talking about something else, he blurted out: "I was really shocked when I walked into the room and you were there in my office. I never meet people outside the company in my office."
 Speyer seems not altogether easy with himself, as perhaps befits a person who has crossed from another world. His mother is Swiss, and his father comes from one of the old Jewish families of Frankfurt; his father fled Germany in 1939. Speyer grew up in a cultivated and proper German-Jewish household on Riverside Drive. At Columbia University, he majored in German literature and joined Zeta Beta Thau, the right Jewish fraternity. Speyer was one of those people who were solid, and even solemn, at an age when others are still flailing and unsure of themselves. According to Burt Lehman, who was a frat brother: "Even at Z.B.T., he stood out from the rest of us. He wore a jacket and tie -- most of us hadn't worn a jacket and tie since our bar mitzvahs." After graduation, he chucked literature and enrolled at Columbia Business School. And he abandoned merchant banking for real estate.
 His decision had as much to do with personal as with business relationships. In 1963, while in business school, Speyer married Lynne Tishman, whose father, Robert, was the patriarch of the oldest, and one of the most respectable, New York real-estate families. It was, in every sense, a fortunate match. For Speyer, Bob Tishman was the living embodiment of a vanished era of simplicity and trust. "Bob's handshake was good," he said, almost reverently. "Period, end of paragraph." He joined the firm as his father-in-law's assistant in 1966; by 1970, Speyer, age 30, was made vice president and had become heir apparent. Tishman Realty was the largest "builder-owner" in the United States, but it was also one of the few that was publicly traded; family members had always had to content themselves with rather modest dividends. By the mid-70's, the Tishmans were ready to cash out, but they didn't know how to go about it. Speyer, however, straddled the old world and the new, and was instrumental, Tishman says, in figuring out how to liquidate the 75-year-old portfolio of buildings. The stock had been trading at $8 a share, but the value of the liquidation was almost four times as great. The two men created Tishman Speyer in 1978.
 The new firm came into being at the tail end of the recession and the beginning of the real-estate mania of the 1980's. Tishman Speyer built and bought properties around the country. But in 1986, with the boom in full swing, Speyer concluded that the country was getting overbuilt and quickly abandoned or sold an array of projects. This act of foresight, or appetite control, allowed Tishman Speyer to emerge from the last recession almost unscathed and to start buying again almost as soon as the market began to show signs of life. But Speyer was too restless simply to sit out the recession. In the mid-80's, he began traveling to Europe and Asia to look for investments. This was highly unorthodox behavior for New York developers, a provincial bunch who prefer to do their investing close to home. Speyer, however, was a much more worldly figure; he had traveled widely, and his German was fluent. He tried at first to build in China, and when that didn't work out he turned to Germany. He completed the Messeturm in 1990 and a building in Berlin last year. Speyer now has offices in Paris, London, Berlin, Frankfurt and Sao Paulo. He has, in effect, become the merchant banker, the global figure, he had dreamed of being. I once heard him blithely tell a meeting of his executive staff that "the European business establishment" was "furious" about the sacking of the chairman of a Swiss bank. There are any number of other guys who control more square feet than Speyer does, but none of them can tell you what the European business establishment thinks without consulting The Financial Times.
 Speyer and his first wife separated in 1987. That should have marked the end of Tishman Speyer, but the business relationship was, by all accounts, undisturbed. "It was about the most decent divorce I've ever heard of," Bob Tishman says. "There was no reason in the world to destroy what we built up over 20-something years." In fact, Tishman still has an emeritus role at the firm. Speyer, meanwhile, married Katherine in 1991. In addition to three children from his first marriage, he has a 6-year-old daughter from his second.
Speyer says that on his 40th birthday he decided that the time had come to "give back." This is about 20 years earlier than the point at which the average mogul reaches the stage of philanthropy. Speyer, of course, believed strongly in the old-fashioned tradition of public-spiritedness; he also aspired to something that could not be had around his conference table. As a young man, Speyer had served on the board of the Jewish Guild for the Blind, one of the traditional charities that the old-line families had supported. In the early 80's, he began operating at a different level. He became chairman of the Dalton School, where his children went, and then, in very rapid succession, joined the boards of Columbia University, the Modern and the New York City Partnership, an organization of C.E.O.'s.
 The most exclusive of these clubs was clearly the Modern, which Speyer was invited to join in 1982. The Rockefellers had been co-founders of the museum, and David Rockefeller remained a major force in its affairs when Speyer joined. The board had always been open to Jews, but not to real-estate men. Speyer was, however, the right kind of real-estate man. And he was eager to be of service. Soon after Speyer joined the board, Rockefeller recalls, "he asked if we could have lunch, and he made it clear that he wanted to be in the inner circle of the museum." Rockefeller, of course, had been born into the inner circle; Speyer was willing to make the effort needed to get there.
 Speyer didn't fully find a role for himself until the Modern decided in the early 90's to embark on a $650 million physical expansion plan. One reason that real-estate developers, whatever their social status, are given a place on the boards of major institutions is that they can be indispensable at such moments. The museum wanted to buy the building next door, the Dorset Hotel. Speyer had known the owner, Sol Goldman, for years, and he knew Goldman's children, who inherited the building on their father's death. Speyer spanned worlds -- the world of haggling, the world of art, the world of old money. He became the lead negotiator in a transaction that stretched over months. The heirs wanted at least $75 million, and they wanted to deliver the building half full; Speyer offered much less and insisted that it be turned over empty. It was 1994, and the market was ticking upward each month; new suitors began to appear. But Speyer persuaded the heirs to take a bird in the hand: the museum got an empty building for $50 million. Rockefeller says of Speyer, "I'm not sure that anyone else could have done it."
 Speyer has devoted an enormous amount of time to his boards, and has not been stinting with his money. He has given at least $5 million to the Modern, and he made a $10 million gift to Columbia, with no strings attached -- a university president's dream. (He also served as the university's chairman for two years.) In the aftermath of the fire that destroyed much of the historic Central Synagogue, where he has been a longtime member, Speyer telephoned Rabbi Peter Rubinstein and offered to help spearhead a fund-raising drive. At the Partnership, a business and civic organization that David Rockefeller founded, Speyer stepped in as chairman during a leadership vacuum in 1992 and took over day-to-day operations until a search committee found a new president. Speyer is widely credited with saving the partnership from irrelevance. This, too, won him the gratitude of Rockefeller, and of New York's corporate elite.
 One of Speyer's more envious competitors says, "The only way that you could knock him is that you're not really sure what his motivation is." But Speyer has never been accused of exploiting any of his positions for financial gain. The inner circle, for Speyer, is not a means but an end; it is where Speyer has always wanted to be. Being of service is, itself, a form of power and an instrument of power. Speyer is an important financial backer of Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, and he speaks of him in the most lavish terms. The same, of course, could be said of plenty of other real-estate figures. But Speyer also acts as a kind of smoother-of-the-way with the notoriously prickly Mayor. When Robert R. Kiley, whom Speyer helped install as president of the Partnership in 1995, was so foolish as to criticize publicly some of the Mayor's policies, one of the Mayor's top aides asked Speyer to give him a talking-to. Speyer, as Kiley recalls, "reminded me that he thought the best approach to the Partnership in general was to do things through quiet persuasion, which is his modus operandi." The Partnership now gets along perfectly well with City Hall.
 Several friends of Speyer's suggested that he looked to Rockefeller as a kind of exemplar -- a distant, glittering polestar of quiet power and public regard. When I asked Speyer what he thought of Rockefeller, he fell to musing, and finally said, in his softest and most silken tones, "He's one of the most thoughtful people I've ever met in my life." He thought some more. "And modest," he added, "extraordinarily modest." One can imagine Speyer wanting to have those very words carved on his tombstone. I asked if his friendship with Rockefeller included a feeling of emulation. Now there was a very, very long pause. At last, looking somewhere over my shoulder, halting to reflect every few words, Speyer said: "I would say that David is probably an absolutely unique person in this century. It would be pretty presumptuous for me to think of him as a role model. It would be absurd."
Real-estate developers do not all like their buildings, or their wives, gold-plated, but it is not a profession generally associated with good taste. Speyer's sense of refinement is an important element of his appeal, as least in the realm of the unspoken. Philip Johnson says that Speyer "has a lot more esthetic sense than any other developer I know." Speyer speaks knowledgeably about the artworks he owns, which tend to be irreverent, ironic and fairly far-out, especially compared with the owner. The dealers he buys from say that while he owns work from well-known figures like Eric Fischl and Damien Hirst, he usually pursues pieces that are too recent to have been validated by critical opinion; he buys them himself. His house, on the Upper East Side, which was built in a space formerly occupied by two brownstones, and has an arresting facade of limestone over glass, is a striking testimony to his interest in architecture and to his commitment to the modern. (It was designed by two highly regarded young architects, Billie Tsien and Tod Williams.) Like the art collection, like the elite board memberships, the house is a token of Speyer's unique status in his world.
 Developers, of course, exercise an enormous influence over what New York looks like; their crassness partly explains the stunning absence of architecturally important buildings in the city. Speyer plainly cares about the developer's esthetic responsibility. One day he took me into the Paine Webber Building, on Avenue of the Americas, to show me the modest things he had done to make the lobby less banal -- wooden bays to house the art collection, a latticework just inside the glass wall, pink granite floors. And yet the only really extraordinary structure Speyer has built is his own home. In the competition for the site now occupied by the Coliseum, in Columbus Circle, Speyer proposed a structure by Helmut Jahn that the Times architecture critic Herbert Muschamp described as "on a par with the best architecture in the world today." But the view inside the industry is that Speyer never went all-out to win the bid, and he ended as an also-ran. Speyer himself says, variously, that zoning rules and building regulations, or the economics of building on spec, preclude the creation of truly distinguished buildings in New York. Perhaps he is saying that it's not worth the trouble. Certainly one of the paradoxes of Speyer's career is that a man with a genuine affinity for the new will be remembered principally as a caretaker of the old.
Rockefeller center inspires a distinct sense of reverence in Jerry Speyer. "We don't think about the initiative that John D. Rockefeller, David's father, took to build this thing," he said one day. Rockefeller started the project in 1929 and built it straight through the Depression. It had been, as Speyer understood it, a great testimony of faith in New York at the darkest moment. And then in May 1995, Rockefeller Center was placed in receivership after its owner, Mitsubishi, failed to make its mortgage payments. Speyer, who has a broad streak of the dutiful son in him, saw the opportunity to salvage and sustain the Rockefellers' great gift to the city -- and at an excellent price. He sought and received the blessing of David Rockefeller, whose family trusts held 20 percent of the center through the Rockefeller Group. He offered Mitsubishi more than $200 million; the company accepted, and then pulled out at the last minute. "I would say I was probably devastated," Speyer said -- the only time I ever heard him use such confessional language. "We had never really gone public with anything. The notion that it had cratered was just unthinkable." The humiliation of public exposure was tangled with the loss of a precious treasure.
 But Speyer wasn't finished. Mitsubishi's default had created a crisis for the real-estate trust that held the mortgage. Goldman, Sachs was the trust's principal lender and held warrants that it could convert into effective ownership of the trust. Goldman decided to pursue ownership of Rockefeller Center, but it needed partners both to share the equity and to develop the property. Speyer was almost an inevitable choice. Goldman's co-chairman, Hank Paulson, was one of Speyer's regular sources of market wisdom, as well as a friend. The head of Goldman's own real-estate investment fund was Daniel Neidich, who had worked with Speyer on the purchase of the Dorset Hotel for the Modern. Goldman was determined to work with Rockefeller, and Rockefeller felt comfortable with Speyer. Here was an intricate web of relationships that Speyer had spent his entire career weaving, a web in which the philanthropic Speyer and the entrepreneurial Speyer were seamlessly bound. In the end, Goldman chose a group consisting of Speyer, Rockefeller, Gianni Agnelli and Stavros Niarchos to buy 50 percent of the property. Speyer and Rockefeller would each own 5 percent, and Agnelli and Niarchos 20 percent.
 There are plenty of developers in New York who would not deign to develop Rockefeller Center if they could not own it. One of the instant colossi of the 90's boom says, with majestic condescension, "Jerry's really a professional manager." Speyer can live with the epithet. He is now spending much of his time on a $100 million plan to revitalize the area. "Every project has one big idea," Speyer said, standing at the corner of Fifth Avenue and 51st Street one afternoon. "The one big idea here was to bring Rockefeller Center back to having the majesty it had when it was first built." This is a very careful piece of phrasing, because Speyer wants to make large-scale changes in this symbolically charged space. He has already lost out in a battle with the Landmarks Preservation Commission to build modern, double-height windows in the stores that look over the famous Channel Gardens that run down to the skating rink. He was, however, permitted to enlarge somewhat the windows overlooking Fifth Avenue.
 Speyer has a weakness for maxims; one of his favorites is, "If you don't change, you die." Rockefeller Center, he argues, has suffered from creeping petrification. And so, walking toward the southwest corner of the skating rink, near where a store called the NBC Experience will go, he said, "I think we can bring a new retail language to Rockefeller Center that would really change midtown." This is the language of the big, jazzy stores that have already taken over much of Fifth Avenue -- what Speyer calls "retail as theater." Banana Republic has agreed to build its flagship store at 50th and Fifth; a Reebok Sports Club, the biggest in New York, will take over the area once occupied by the passport office. Cipriani International will soon assume control of the Rainbow Room, and Christie's has agreed to move from Park Avenue.
 Speyer's ambition is nothing less grandiose than to make Rockefeller Center the heart of the city, so that New Yorkers will meet there the way they once did under the clock at the Biltmore Hotel. He plans to revamp the vast, Stygian underground shopping area, clearing out many of the current structures so that natural light from the skating rink will shine into the subterranean plaza. It is in this enclosed space that Speyer hopes locals will converge. To anyone who knows the city, this is an extremely tall order. New Yorkers may prove reluctant to adopt an underground space -- however attractively lighted -- as their Rialto. The subways may be enough. More important, Rockefeller Center is a quintessential place for tourists, the Empire State Building of urban plazas. It's hard to imagine a Banana Republic changing the dynamic. "New Yorkers don't need that kind of Biltmore clock," says Craig Whitaker, an architect and urban planner. "It's, 'I'll see you at whatever-the-restaurant-is at 7."' Rockefeller Center can become showier, but not funkier.
 Of course, this whole dialectic of constancy and change is a terribly delicate thing: rigor mortis lies on one side and vulgarity on the other. Speyer knows exactly what the world will say if he isn't careful. "There's a culture in each of these buildings that's really important to respect," he said, lest I miss the point. Yes, some of the shoe-repair guys would have to go, but he would find a new spot for the hallowed, dingy barbershop-to-the-schlockenheimer-stars. "We're staying absolutely away from anything that's faddish," Speyer said. There will be no theme restaurants.
 One afternoon, we went into the lobby of 50 Rockefeller Center; in an area where two stores once stood there was now a marble wall pierced by a frosted-glass rectangle. The glass has been carved with arcing motifs that evoke the Art Deco vocabulary of the surrounding architecture. As we stood there, Speyer asked me proudly, "If you had never been here before, would you be able to tell that the lobby was redone?" You would not, I thought. It was, like Speyer himself, a study in the artful and intricate superimposition of the new upon the old.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 13; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 745 words

HEADLINE: American Bombs Make Iraq Stronger

BYLINE: By Ronald Steel; Ronald Steel is a professor of international relations at the University of Southern California.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
President Clinton's decision to bomb Iraq, although understandable as an expression of exasperation with Saddam Hussein's deceptions, is likely to cause more problems than it solves.
In effect it solves nothing. The Clinton Administration did not claim that the bombing would remove Mr. Hussein from power, or even that it would seriously reduce his ability to produce chemical or biological weapons. Nor does anyone suggest that this attack will induce him to comply with future demands of United Nations weapons inspectors. 
 So it would seem the attack was intended to do little more than demonstrate that the patience of the United States Government had been worn out and that its frustration demanded a response.
A military operation inspired by such emotion and seeking such modest objectives can be justified only if the cost is very low. But that is far from the case here. Indeed, the political fallout is likely to be more beneficial to Saddam Hussein than to the United States.
The bombing means the end of the United Nations weapons inspection program, called Unscom. For all the roadblocks the Iraqis put in its way, the program had considerable success over its seven years. Indeed, one reason President Clinton gave for calling off last month's scheduled air strikes was that the action would have meant the end of Unscom. "We would then have no oversight, no insight, no involvement in what is going on in Iraq," he said at the time. Now, apparently, that doesn't matter.
With the loss of the inspections, the United States will be locked into a huge military presence in the Persian Gulf for years. Not only will this cost billions and embroil us even deeper into the convoluted politics of the region, but it will also strain links with friendly Arab regimes.
Leaders of Saudi Arabia and the gulf emirates may hate Saddam Hussein, but they fear being accused by their own people -- whose support of Iraq in this conflict is clear -- of being lackeys of the United States. Not a single Arab state that supported the gulf war, including Kuwait, has openly backed this raid. Egypt, Syria and even the United Arab Emirates have opposed it.
In addition, the principal restraint keeping Saddam Hussein in check -- economic sanctions -- has been seriously compromised. Although Russia and France have pushed hard to end sanctions, they have for the most part observed them, which has limited Iraq's military strength.
Sanctions were imposed not by the United States but by the Security Council. We have consistently defended our actions against Iran as justified by United Nations resolutions. But the current attack does not have that authorization, and Russia and China have denounced it. If the United States can bomb Iraq without authorization, then why won't other countries feel free to buy its oil and sell it goods?
The attack also endangers our relations with Security Council members on other issues. For example, in denouncing the attack, the Russians declared that they were shelving plans to ratify Start II -- an arms reduction treaty the United States very much wants.
Yes, Saddam Hussein is a menace to his own people and the entire Middle East. There is a case to be made for unilateral American military action -- if we have the support of our partners and the action is on a scale to be truly effective. But Desert Fox (with its curious reference to a Nazi field marshal) does not meet that standard.
A successful operation of this sort requires a certain degree of cleverness and hypocrisy. We have not been clever enough to convince our allies, other than Britain, that it is in their best interest.
Nor do we have the support of the Security Council, a fig leaf that has been highly useful in justifying American-led interventions from the Korean War to the gulf war. By declaring that the United States seeks to depose Saddam Hussein and pave the way for a new Iraqi government, President Clinton went far beyond his United Nations mandate, as Secretary General Kofi Annan reminded him.
Because the Administration made no serious pretense to play by United Nations rules, if only for show, it will be harder in the future for the United States to claim that its unilateral actions are taken on behalf of the world community.
Hypocrisy, which La Rochefoucauld called the tribute vice pays to virtue, has an honored place in diplomacy, as it does in politics. This operation lacks the virtue of its vices.
