HEADLINE: A Family Finds Shelter And Fear on Skid Row

BYLINE: By DON TERRY 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
The shower for the older boys is available after dinner, and those few minutes under the falling water are the favorite part of William Foster's long day.
For when he gets out, dries himself off and strikes a muscle-man pose or two in front of the steamed-up mirror, William, a skinny 14-year-old, knows he can escape into sleep soon. Lights out at 10:30. 
 Maybe then his dreams will carry him away from where he lives with his mother, his little brother and sister, and on some nights with as many as 38 other children and their families in an emergency homeless shelter on Skid Row. Skid Row is a bottom-of-the-barrel district on the edge of downtown to which Los Angeles has consigned its derelicts and homeless and many of the agencies that serve them, where depression, despair and wasted human potential flow through the streets. It is a place no child should have to walk through, let alone live in.
There are not many shelters in Los Angeles where a family can stay together; even fewer will take in a boy like William, over age 13. On a typical night there might be 20 or 30 children among the crowds of single men and women at the mission.
"I didn't want to come here," William said recently. "I thought there would be just a bunch of dirty, nasty adults. But my mom said it wouldn't be so bad. She said there would be a lot of other kids around. She was right. There are a lot of kids."
Most of the hundreds who stay at Union Rescue every night are single adult men and women. But last year, Union Rescue provided beds for 10 to 12 children and their families, even though on crowded nights some families had to sleep on mats. This year the mission opened an expanded space for families.
William's 16-year-old brother, Steve, lasted one night at the mission before finding a spot on a friend's couch, a two-hour bus ride from the rest of his family.
"He said the neighborhood was hell on earth," William recalled. "Then he left."
Homeless families are typically headed by a single woman, like William's 37-year-old mother, Janice.
Mrs. Foster's nightmare of being homeless was set in motion last winter when she lost her welfare check and papers that she needed to stay on welfare. She quickly began to fall behind her rent, and in July she was evicted. At different times, various members of the family lived with friends or relatives, and for a few days they were all together in a hotel, but by August, Mrs. Foster said, she had no choice but Union Rescue.
Almost any time William leaves the security of the mission, holding on tightly to his little brother, Deon, 3, and his sister, Shayla, 4, and walking beside his mother, he can see men smoking crack in dank doorways or using other drugs.
Sometimes he has to step around people sleeping in boxes or under sheets of plastic, "like the stuff they throw over dead bodies."
The other day he smelled something funny. He looked around and saw that it was human waste splashed on a wall. He hurried Deon along and told him not to look.
"I feel it's my responsibility to protect my little brother and sister," he said. "I feel I got to be a man."
But he is not a man. He spent most of the other day playing with a green yo-yo, trying to master a "cat's cradle" and talking about how tough he was and how Skid Row did not scare him any, unless it was dark, and then "I'd probably be afraid."
Of the 151 programs in Los Angeles County that serve homeless families, 69 do not accept boys over 13, and 39 have even lower age cutoffs, said Ruth Schwartz, executive director of the nonprofit Shelter Partnership. Ms. Schwartz said that the county had 4,890 beds for families but that on any given night there were about 12,400 homeless family members, most of them children.
The sight of children on Skid Row has raised some eyebrows in social service agencies and some criticism of the mission.
"Women and children are being sent from all over Los Angeles to Skid Row, which is unconscionable," said Alice Callaghan, who runs an after-school program in the Skid Row neighborhood. "If you're going to serve homeless women and children, why would anyone put those services in Skid Row?"
And for years, any time a mother and her children showed up on the row, looking for a place to stay, social service workers moved quickly to relocate them as far away as possible.
The row, everyone agreed, was no place for children.
The people who run Union Rescue agree. Skid Row is an awful place, they say. But that is the point. What better place is there for a mission to be to help relieve suffering, what better place for a mission to open its doors to say welcome brothers and sisters and your children, even if they are 14-year-old boys?
"We have not created this need by opening the family shelter," said Marty Annette Hill, superintendent of the mission's women and family ministries. "The need was there and we are simply responding to it."
Most of the women and children stay at the mission only for a week or two.
The other day, William's friend David, 13, moved out of the mission with his family to a hotel for the homeless. William felt good for David and thought to himself, "I hope it's my turn next."
"A lot of kids accept being homeless," William said. "They act like it's no big deal. Not me. I don't feel I'll be living this life style much longer. It's too negative."
 But as long as he stays at the mission, William and his family can spend their mornings in the new "Mommy and Me" room on the fourth floor. It is a large playroom, full of toys, stuffed animals and the sound of gospel music.
"You don't know you're in Skid Row when you're in here," said Bridget Wilson, a supervisor at the mission. "You don't know the devastation right outside these walls."
But the room is only open for a few hours each day. The rest of the day, William and his family wander the streets, walking a dozen blocks to the library or a fast-food restaurant. They do not go to the nearby park, a gathering place for drug dealers and their customers.
William does not go to school, though he says he wants to be a marine biologist. When the family goes to the library, he tends to play computer games rather than read.
Sometimes, William catches a bus and returns to the family's old neighborhood in the Van Nuys section to spend a night or two with his aunt. He tries to recapture his old life, to pretend Skid Row is just a dream. He plays basketball or hits the streets to sell candy and coloring books as part of an anti-gang youth program.
But he returns to the mission to be with his mother and his little brother and sister, not just to protect them, but to be protected.
His mother stepped outside to talk with a friend in front of the mission recently and William did not know where she was. He panicked and almost cried when she walked back a few minutes later.
At night, after a long day of homelessness, William's mother listens to her children sleep on bunk beds in a room they share with other families. As she lies there in the dark, her mind is flooded with if-onlys.
"If only I could, I would have done things differently," she said. "I would have saved more money, but really I didn't have any money to save."
William listened quietly to his mother's if-onlys. He listened to her say that she felt terrible, that she felt she had let her children down and now the older ones were angry with her and that was breaking her heart even more than being homeless. Teen-agers, she said, do not adjust well to change. He heard her say that once she got back on her feet she was going to get two jobs and even though she might not have time to see her children as much, at least they would have economic security.
"I don't want to dwell on what happened," William said when his mother fell silent. "I just want us to get a place. I just want to go home."
 On Dec. 14, William and his family left Skid Row. With the help of Beyond Shelter, an organization that provides vouchers for homeless families to stay in hotels until they can be moved into permanent housing, the Fosters moved into The Deluxe Inn, several miles from the row.
 Still, Mrs. Foster said she had to return to Skid Row soon. Some of the missions, including Union Rescue, were giving away toys for Christmas. "It's going to be crowded down there," she said.

GRAPHIC: Photos: William Foster, playing with his yo-yo at an emergency shelter on Skid Row in Los Angeles, has had to grow up fast. At 14, he said, "I feel I got to be a man," keeping his siblings away from the addicts and derelicts. Above, he held the hand of his brother, Deon, 3. His mother, Janice, 37, held onto Shayla, 4. (Photographs by Monica Almeida/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japanese Stocks Rise on Bond Market's Recovery

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 25

 BODY:
Japanese stocks closed higher today for the first time this week as a rise in Government bonds lessened worries that bank profits would shrink further.
The world's other major financial markets were closed for Christmas. 
 In Tokyo, the Nikkei index of 225 stocks rose 91.22 points, or seven-tenths of 1 percent, to 13,797.95. That left the benchmark index 10 percent below its level of a year earlier. The Topix index, which tracks all the issues traded on the first section of the Tokyo Stock Exchange, increased 8.78 points, or eight-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,082.96.
"We rose on the bond market's recovery and Wall Street's strong finish" on Thursday, said Mamoru Shimode, a strategist at Deutsche Securities Ltd. "But it's just a temporary rebound on very thin volume -- the trend still points down."
Some 227 million shares were traded, barely half the six-month daily average and the lightest volume in eight months. The holiday kept overseas investors away, and European financial companies have restricted trading to ease the way for the start of the euro, the common European currency, next month.
Japanese Government bond prices rose today. The benchmark bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction of the price, fell one-tenth of a percentage point, to 1.75 percent.
The bond market was lifted by the Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa, who said on Thursday that the Government, which holds about a third of the Government bonds outstanding, would not liquidate its holdings.
Bonds fell earlier in the week after the Government said it would issue a record amount of new bonds in the coming fiscal year.
Banks use profits from bond trading, and the interest they earn on their bond holdings, to help write off bad loans. A glut of debt on the market would lower the value of their portfolios.
"The market's just regaining what it lost when people panicked about a bond market glut," Junji Naiki, general manager at the Chiyoda Mutual Life Insurance Company's securities investment department, said about today's trading. "But banks' profits on their bond holdings have disappeared, and that won't change anytime soon."
The Sakura Bank Ltd. was the most active issue on the stock market today, rising 14 yen, or 12 cents, to 270 yen.
In the economic background, the Government said today that Japan's unemployment rate rose to a postwar record of 4.4 percent in November from 4.3 percent in October, equaling the jobless rate in the United States for the first time. Industrial production fell 2 percent in November from October.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: THE NEW EUROPE -- Importing the Ways of Wall St.;
For Investment Firms, Euro Spells Opportunity

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: LONDON, Dec. 24

 BODY:
It has all the trappings of a gold rush: the lure of riches, the frisson of risk, the headlong dash to stake the claims.
The euro, Europe's single currency, makes its debut in just a week, creating a vast currency zone from the Arctic Circle to the Mediterranean. And to listen to the most optimistic of those seeking profit there, the currency's birth will unlock a mother lode of wealth that has set American investment banks competing to export more of Wall Street's ways to continental Europe. 
 While these great expectations may be overblown, there is no doubt that for investors and fund managers, the euro's arrival one week from now will mean an unparalleled transformation. Trading in 11 separate currencies will disappear, creating a single financial bloc with an economic output greater than that of the United States. Many financial specialists forecast profound changes in the way continental European markets operate -- and increasing pressure on Europeans to emulate the ways of Wall Street.
"There's this wall of money waiting to come into the market," said Jeremy Isaacs, head of European equity business at the Lehman Brothers office here. "Do I think European investors are going to become more like U.S. investors? The answer is: absolutely."
Of course, it is not as if continental European countries have been slouches in positioning themselves for the coming euro zone: Think only of megamergers like DaimlerChrysler, the Deutsche Bank takeover of Bankers Trust or the pharmaceutical fusion of Hoechst and Rhone-Poulenc.
And the world's economic spiral and low growth forecasts for Europe as a whole have muted some of the more bullish voices forecasting a euro bonanza. "I don't think you are going to have a revolution," Mr. Isaacs said.
"You are going to have an evolution," he said. "The question is when, not if."
Euro coins and notes will not be introduced for two more years, but all transactions between banks in the 11 participating countries and all operations involving equities and bonds will be denominated in euros starting next week. With only one currency in play, European companies will increasingly be evaluated by equity investors and fund managers across a broad field of competition where pricing and performance are no longer disguised by national currencies or local scales of importance.
The euro zone "redefines what is a blue chip," said David Bowers, European equity strategist at Merrill Lynch & Company, arguing that, for instance, a company regarded as a heavyweight in one of the 11 countries would not necessarily make it into a euro index of top companies.
In addition, 11 separate government bond markets will be replaced by a single euro debt market in which the divergent yields of the past will be replaced by far more subtle calculations of razor-thin spreads between, say, euro-denominated bonds issued by Italy and euro bonds issued by Germany.
Cross-border acquisitions will be simplified by the euro, which will eliminate currency risk within the zone because it will have an immutable value against national currencies until they are phased out altogether in the year 2002.
Insurance companies in the 11 euro countries alone have around $1 trillion invested in their own governments' bonds, according to Crispin Southgate, an analyst at Merrill Lynch. Pension funds have a further $350 billion in the same bonds.
Both those amounts are set to mushroom as fund managers look for higher yields in the low-interest euro zone and strapped governments place an ever-larger part of the burden for pension provision on private citizens.
These prospects have sharpened competition among the big American investment banks that have their European headquarters here and see themselves as best placed to deploy expertise won in the United States. That has set alarm bells ringing for big European institutions, which have been scrambling to acquire some of the same skills -- and the same reach -- as the introduction of the euro nears.
"One of the things we have been seeing in the mergers in European banking groups is European banks trying to get the critical mass and the expertise to compete globally," said Madeleine Hall, a European fund manager at Schroders.
They have not always been successful. For all its size, the giant UBS A.G., born of Union Bank of Switzerland's merger with the Swiss Bank Corporation, lost out badly in this year's meltdown of emerging and speculative markets.
Still, big European banks such as Paribas, Deutsche Bank, ABN-Amro and Barclays are all hoping to translate strong local ties and cultural affiliations into thriving business. "These firms are pretty powerful in their own markets," said Robert Morris, a managing director at Barclay Capital. While American banks would seek to expand corporate bond and other business in Europe, he added, "it doesn't mean to say that they are quickly going to steal the market."
The competition is particularly fierce in the creation of new indices for bonds denominated in euros -- a dry-sounding business redolent of number-crunching that will still play a central role both in the evaluation of fund managers' performance in a changing market-place and, more gradually, in the way businesses raise money to finance their operations.
In the last year, American financial institutions including Morgan Stanley Capital International, Salomon Smith Barney, Lehman Brothers, Merrill Lynch, Bear, Stearns and J. P. Morgan have devised eurobond indices in anticipation of a new, performance driven approach to investment in the 11 euro countries.
By contrast, only Barclays among the European banks has devised a similar index, and that one is narrowly based on government bond performance. In the last 18 months, the overall number of benchmarks has risen to 14 from two -- a proliferation some bankers view as excessive. Such has been the rush to new indices that 1998 has become known as the year of "the battle of the benchmarks."
The institutions offering benchmarks are hoping not only for the adoption of their indices as gauges for managers' performance but also for the business that comes with it. "What distinguishes one index provider from another is the reach of services," said Richard Pagan of Salomon Smith Barney.
Most of the new euro indices are now heavily weighted toward government bonds because corporate-bond issuance, though it has grown rapidly over the last year, is still only a fraction of the United States level.
Government bonds in Lehman Brothers' United States aggregate bond index, for example, take up 47 percent of the index while corporate debt accounts for 21 percent. The same bank's euro bond index is composed of 67 percent government and 12 percent corporate debt.
According to Anant Patel, a managing director at Bear, Stearns, the government bond market in the euro zone is currently worth some 2.25 trillion euros -- more than $2.6 trillion -- compared with a corporate bond market now valued at some 690 billion euros, roughly $800 billion.
The expectation among fund managers is that those proportions will change radically as continental European banks re-examine corporate loans and companies wean themselves away from reliance on banks for financing.
At present, said Merrill Lynch's Mr. Southgate, 90 percent of corporate financing in continental Europe is provided by bank loans, compared with 50 percent in the United States. By some estimates, fewer than 10 percent of continental Europe's 1,700 investment-grade companies -- many of them in Germany -- have issued public debt. That is set to change.
"European banks are looking more closely at how much money they make," said David Munves, credit market strategist at Lehman Brothers. "Corporate loans are coming under scrutiny, due to shareholder value in general."
"It's a major opportunity for new index providers," he said.
One indication of the likely shift toward corporate issuance is the prospect of stepped-up activity by ratings agencies -- still an unfamiliar concept to many European companies.
Eric de Bodard, managing director for corporate finance in Europe at Moody's Investor Services, said the number of European companies to which Moody's ratings had been assigned grew by 100 to more than 300 in 1998.
"All the signs point to at least as active a year" in 1999, he said. "Investors are going to be looking for more yield and are going to diversify their portfolios without foreign exchange risk."
Indeed, said Mr. Patel at Bear, Stearns, with the advent of a single currency for financial transactions, the nature of portfolio management will change.
"Traditionally in Europe, the way in which portfolio managers have been able to deliver performance is to take views on relative currency performance and the performance of spread relationships between markets," he said.
With the arrival of the euro, though, "the currency component will disappear, which was one of the biggest components," while interest rate spreads will shrivel. "And now all of a sudden, you ask the question: where do I get value enhancement?"
The result, he said, will be "a very new investment dynamic for Europe."
Banks see their indices playing into a European transformation whose precise course is still unclear and may, indeed, face many regulatory hurdles.
Many fund managers are hoping, for instance, that a boom in private pensions will introduce vast new sums to the market, as happened in Britain, whose pension fund industry is bigger than all of continental Europe's combined.
Against that, continental pensions are a ticking political time bomb. Many Europeans regard a comfortable state pension as an inalienable birthright and are uncomfortable with the notion of a private pension provision familiar to an increasing number of Americans. Moreover, European private pension funds, like European mutual funds, face regulatory restrictions.
On top of that, Russia's meltdown has dampened appetites for corporate bonds, particularly high-yield bonds. That has made some assessments more cautious. Corporate bonds, said Mr. Bowers at Merrill Lynch, will provide "one of the most exciting challenges that the euro will bring about." But this year's financial problems, he said, "have left people a little nervous about rushing into this."

HEADLINE: Real Estate Investment Trusts Expect a Slower 4th Quarter

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The nation's real estate investment trusts are expected to report that earnings growth slowed to about 11 percent in the fourth quarter as slumping stock prices made it harder to finance property acquisitions.
"Growth from acquisitions and developments has definitely slowed, and that is starting to show up in earnings," said Glenn Mueller, head of real estate research at Legg Mason Wood Walker Inc. 
 The share prices of REIT's, as the trusts are known, have fallen this year because of concern about a slowing economy and a rise in construction. Unwilling to use their stock to finance acquisitions, REIT's bought $8.1 billion of property in the third quarter, down 39 percent from the second quarter and the lowest amount since the start of 1997, according to the National Association of Real Estate Investment Trusts. The figure for the fourth quarter will be even lower, analysts said.
Still, earnings will get some support from high occupancy rates and rising rents, particularly for offices and West Coast apartments. That is expected to cause quarterly profits to rise at least 20 percent at some REIT's, including Equity Office Properties Trust, Boston Properties Inc., the Mack-Cali Realty Corporation and the Apartment Investment and Management Company.
"The pace of leasing activity is still very good," said Christopher Marinac, a real estate analyst at the Robinson-Humphrey Company.
A high rate of acquisitions in 1997 and the first half of this year had kept REIT earnings increasing as much as 15 percent in recent quarters. In the third quarter, earnings rose an average 13 percent, according to Paine Webber Group. For 1999, analysts expect earnings to rise about 9 percent, the lowest this decade.
"We are taking down our '99 estimates in all cases," said David Sherman, head of real estate research at Salomon Smith Barney.
REIT's are companies that own all types of real estate, including shopping malls, apartments and even prisons. They are exempt from corporate income taxes if, among other things, they distribute at least 95 percent of net income to shareholders as dividends.
Office REIT's, the leaders in earnings for more than a year, are expected to lead the industry's earnings in the fourth quarter. Occupancy rates are less than 10 percent for the first time since the early 1980's, and rents are rising as much as 20 percent annually in some cities, including San Francisco, Boston and New York.
"On average, the office sector is still able to put up some strong rent growth numbers," said Mark Benson, an analyst at Jefferies & Company.
Apartment REIT's, as in past quarters, are expected to see rents grow only about 3 percent. An increase in construction activity has added new supply to the market.
The biggest apartment REIT's include Apartment Investment, Equity Residential Properties Trust and United Dominion Realty Trust.
Among the apartment REIT's, those on the West Coast, where tough zoning laws restrict new development, are expected to show the biggest earnings growth. Avalon Bay, BRE Properties Inc. and Archstone Communities Trust have large West Coast apartment holdings.
Mall and shopping center REIT earnings will depend on the outcome of the holiday sales season. In addition to base rents, these landlords are also entitled to part of their tenants' sales.
The biggest mall REIT's include Simon Property Group Inc., General Growth Properties Inc. and the Rouse Company. REIT's with large strip shopping-center holdings include the Kimco Realty Corporation, the Developers Diversified Realty Corporation and Federal Realty Investment Trust.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

New Loan Losses Found At Japan's Largest Banks
Japan's 17 biggest banks had $427 billion in problem loans as of March, a Government audit has found -- 12 percent more than they had reported. The Financial Supervisory Agency said it had found 49.5 trillion yen, or $427 billion, in problem loans, 5.4 trillion yen more than the banks had calculated. 
 The biggest problem uncovered in the audit was that some banks applied more lenient write-off rules for loans to their financial affiliates than to other borrowers. Page C3.
 
Russian Oil Output Down Slightly
Russian oil production fell 1 percent this year, less than expected, as the ruble's plunge offset low world oil prices and provided producers with cash to maintain output, a Government official said. C2.
 
Nikkei Closes 91 Points Higher
Japanese stocks closed higher for the first time this week as a rise in Government bonds lessened worries that bank profits would shrink further. The world's other major financial markets were closed for Christmas. In Tokyo, the Nikkei average of 225 stocks rose 91.22 points, or seven-tenths of 1 percent, to 13,797.95. C3.

Airlines Expect Lower Earnings
Several major airlines, including the UAL Corporation's United Airlines, U S Airways Group and Continental Airlines, are expected to report lower earnings for the fourth quarter because of competition from discount carriers, a reduction in corporate travel budgets and an increase in the number of seats they had to fill. In addition, generally warm weather has reduced the number of people taking ski trips or vacationing in Florida. C4.
 
Oil Industry's Annus Horribilis
The oil industry has unexpectedly suffered through a year that some are calling a "blood bath." Oil prices averaged $13.13 in the fourth quarter, down 34 percent from a year earlier. The biggest American oil companies are expected to report earnings declines of between 32 percent and 90 percent for the quarter. C2.
 
Hitachi Signals Strategy Shift
Hitachi, Japan's largest electronics manufacturer, may have signaled an effort to quicken its decision-making process when it named a new president, Etsuhiko Shoyama. Unlike many previous presidents of Hitachi, Mr. Shoyama has worked extensively in audiovisual products and in the company's information and media businesses. C3.
 
Growth Slows at Real Estate Trusts
The nation's real estate investment trusts are expected to report that earnings growth slowed to about 11 percent in the fourth quarter as slumping stock prices made it harder to finance property acquisitions. The share prices of REIT's have fallen this year because of concern about a slowing economy and a rise in construction. C4.
 
Marketing Gimmicks in Hong Kong
The use of promotional gimmicks is mushrooming in Hong Kong as companies try to bolster depressed sales amid the territory's severe recession. The marketing efforts are especially strong in the most troubled areas of the economy, including real estate, retailing and telecommunications, where demand has been falling. C3.

HEADLINE: Baghdad Journal;
Holiday Prayer: Thanks for Survival

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER 

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 25

 BODY:
Probably no priest or pastor outside Iraq opened a Christmas sermon today the way the Rev. Gabriel Marie did at the Church of Our Lady of Assumption here.
"Thanks be to God that we have survived the bombing," Father Marie told Catholic parishioners who filled his church to overflowing for two Masses this morning. 
 He went on to lament modern technology that allows warriors "to push a button on a computer and kill people," and said it was the duty of all Christians "to build a new world full of peace."
As Iraqi Christians gathered for Christmas services today, the sounds of the American and British bombing raids last week were still echoing in their heads. Their spiritual leaders used the occasion to remind them that, as Father Marie said, "no bomb is powerful enough to kill the spirit of Christianity."
Parishioners at Our Lady of Assumption joined loudly in singing hymns and listened attentively to Bible readings that told the age-old story of the Nativity.
As they were filing out into the midday sunshine, the choir of about 35 young people, evidently unable to restrain its exuberance, broke spontaneously into an Arabic-language version of "Jingle Bells." When it was finished, members of the choir hugged and kissed each other.
"Because of Christmas, I am very happy," said Anman George, 19, who was among the most enthusiastic singers. "We believe in Jesus, and that his spirit will prevail to resolve these difficulties. His teachings are the way to peace in this country."
Christians who attended Catholic and Protestant services in Baghdad today said in interviews that they live and worship freely here. The Chaldean Catholic community, by far the largest Christian denomination in Iraq, has roots in the earliest days of Christianity and is widely accepted as part of this country's spiritual heritage. Perhaps its most prominent member is Deputy Prime Minister Tariq Aziz.
"Some Muslims with backward minds don't like Christians," said Wasan Wadia, 28, who attended a Catholic Mass with her family today. "But most of them, especially the more educated, are friendly to us or even envy us because our tradition is very open-minded. They like talking and mixing with us."
As recently as 20 years ago, Christians constituted nearly 10 percent of the Iraqi population. But many worked for foreign companies and began emigrating in the 1980's as the companies shut down after the outbreak of war with Iran. Today they make up about 6 percent of the country's 22 million people.
Iraq's Christian academies, run by Jesuits and Presbyterians from the United States, were shut down when the Government expelled most foreign missionaries in the late 1960's. Many young Christians now attend selected public schools where the history of Christianity is taught alongside that of Islam. Their community is known as highly educated and relatively prosperous.
Leaders of Christian denominations here have issued statements condemning last week's bombing and the economic sanctions that the United Nations imposed on Iraq after the invasion of Kuwait eight years ago. The bombing and sanctions are intended to force changes in the Iraqi Government and curb what the United States describes as Iraq's threat to neighboring countries.
As a sign of the friendly ties between the Government and Christian denominations here, the Minister of Religious Affairs, Abdul-Muneim Ahmed Saleh, visited several churches today. At the Baghdad National Presbyterian Church, founded by American missionaries in the 19th century, he told the parish council that Christians "are not a minority, but an integral part of our nation."
The Presbyterian pastor, the Rev. Ikram Ibrahim, referred obliquely to the country's troubles in his sermon today. "Jesus, we are praying to you," he said. "You are the Prince of Peace, and you are the one who can lift the sanctions from our country."
Later the chairman of the parish council, Georges Hormis Sada, said Iraqi Christians shared the widespread anger and puzzlement here over the West's hostility.
Mr. Sada is a retired military officer who fondly recalls his two years of pilot training at Randolph Air Force Base in Texas during the 1960's, when Iraqi-American relations were still friendly.
"We don't say anything about politics," he said, "but when we see aggression against children, women and old people, we think this should not be. We don't think Jesus would like it. We feel sad that Christian countries are doing this to us. Christians should be able to solve these problems in a different way."
Mr. Sada said the council had decided to cancel traditional church parties. There will be prayer services instead.
"You can't be very happy when people are being killed, when people are depressed and suffering," he said. "How can you have parties and sing and dance? We feel we should share the sadness of our people and only worship."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Catholics preparing for a Christmas Eve Mass at Maree-Yousuf Church in Baghdad. Christians, 6 percent of Iraq's population, are widely accepted as part of Iraq's heritage, and they say they worship freely. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Offices Plan for Possible Strike By Building Workers

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Managers of office buildings throughout New York City are making contingency plans for a possible strike on New Year's Day, when the union contract covering 30,000 maintenance workers will expire.
Neither side is predicting a strike, but both sides fear that if negotiations break off, the city could see a painful replay of the monthlong strike three years ago, when janitors and elevator operators walked out, creating major inconveniences in hundreds of commercial buildings. 
 That strike created chaos as building managers asked tenants to help carry their office trash to a central collection point. And without their normal maintenance crews on hand, some managers had to hire outsiders to shovel snow off sidewalks.
The Realty Advisory Board, which handles labor relations for about 1,000 office buildings, is focusing on holding down labor costs and winning more flexibility in work rules. Officials of the union, Local 32B-32J of the Service Employees International Union, said their focus will be on gaining higher wages and resisting management's demands for concessions.
The two sides have held only informal talks thus far, but are scheduled to begin intensive negotiations today at the Sheraton New York Hotel and Towers in midtown Manhattan.
"From our standpoint, we'll be asking for improvements in a lot of areas, including the starting rate" for new employees, said James F. Berg, the chief negotiator for the real estate industry. "We hope to hold the economics down, to be as reasonable as possible. But we're hoping we don't have to have a strike."
The main cause of the strike three years ago was management's demand for a lower starting salary and the union's resistance to the idea. Ultimately, management and the union's president, Gus Bevona, compromised on a starting salary 20 percent lower than the $32,000 a year earned on average by experienced building maintenance workers. Under the current agreement, new workers' salaries rise to the level of experienced workers' after 30 months. In the negotiations three years ago, the industry initially sought a 48 percent lower starting salary that would rise to the level of the salary of experienced workers in six years.
Both management and the union declined to give details about their current bargaining positions because neither side has yet presented the other with a formal proposal. Nonetheless, Mr. Berg said the industry would seek more flexibility, that is, the ability to maintain buildings with fewer workers.
"We want to adjust work rules and methods of operations so they'll be more efficient," Mr. Berg said. "Does that translate into the ability to change the size of the work force? Yes."
Dennis Sheehan, a spokesman for the union, said, "Gus Bevona, as he always has done, will negotiate the best contract possible for his membership."
The real estate industry contends that Mr. Bevona's members are among the best-paid unskilled workers in the city and that their salaries are far higher than those of building maintenance workers in most other cities. Industry officials said that the salaries are costing union workers their jobs because many building owners, to avoid the union rates, have been turning to low-wage nonunion maintenance companies.
But union officials maintain that New York is an expensive place to live, and the $32,000 average pay is barely enough to support a family there.
The union officials are expected to fight efforts to shrink their work force, partly because many workers complain that they are required to clean too many square feet of office space each day.
The negotiations are complicated by the situation of Mr. Bevona, who with a salary of more than $400,000 is the city's highest paid union official. Opponents in the union have sued him for $2.5 million, asserting that he wrongly used union funds to defend himself against lawsuits and to publish a union anniversary album that they say was primarily a campaign vehicle for him.
Arthur Z. Schwartz, a lawyer for Mr. Bevona's political opponents, said he predicted that if Mr. Bevona loses the case, the parent union might impose a trusteeship, assert direct control over the local and force Mr. Bevona aside.
Some members of the union predicted that Mr. Bevona might push for a strike to show he was firmly in command. But others said that after the strike three years ago, when workers were on picket lines during weeks of bitter cold, Mr. Bevona would be reluctant to send his members back onto the street.

HEADLINE: In the Region / Connecticut;
The Privatization of Public Housing in Stamford

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

DATELINE: STAMFORD

 BODY:
LAST year a private developer bought one of the Stamford Housing Authority's most distressed properties; next year another one will be sold to a different developer. The first is now being rehabilitated and the second will be replaced.
Ninety-four buildings with 430 two-story apartments at Rippowam Park are undergoing redevelopment and 500 units at Southfield Village will be demolished and replaced by 330 apartments and town houses. 
 The program under which Rippowam Park is being redeveloped represents a departure in the financing of public housing. It was approved by the State Legislature last year as a two-year pilot program introduced by Representative Christel H. Truglia, a Stamford Democrat. Up to three municipalities may participate. So far Stamford is the only one to do so.
The $36-million cost of the project was raised through $16 million in tax-exempt bonds issued by the Housing Authority, a $6.6 million low-interest loan that the developer will repay to the city and the rest from private investment in low-income housing tax credits.
Under the pilot program, developers and housing authorities may apply as partners to the state's Department of Economic and Community Development for approval of plans to renovate deteriorated public housing. Once approval is granted the developer takes over ownership of the buildings and proceeds without further oversight by the state or the housing authority on construction, maintenance, management and rentals.
The housing authority retains ownership of the land through a 99-year ground lease, which restricts its use to low- and moderate-income housing for the entire term. After that the buildings revert to the Housing Authority.
The terms of the tax-exempt bonds also insure that the low- and moderate-income status of the project continues for 99 years in the event that the developer, in this case Rippowam Park Associates L.P., a division of the Richman Group of Greenwich, exercises its option to buy the entire property within three years, provided that the renovations are complete.
Mayor Dannel Malloy calls the rehabilitation of the complex, now a third of the way completed with 150 refurbished two- to four-bedroom apartments rented to former tenants or newcomers, "trail-blazing."
"This is the trend," he said. "The state won't put the money in that's required to rebuild public housing, which has been allowed to decline over a long period. Rippowam Park has been very successful. The crime statistics have dropped through the basement. Resident satisfaction is high, and people who never would have considered living there are renting apartments."
He said he preferred the state program to Hope VI, a 1993 Federal Housing and Urban Development program that is helping to finance the demolition and reconstruction of Southfield Village. "It's a big country," said the Mayor, "and there's a limit to the number of Hope VI grants." Only 20 a year are awarded nationwide in a highly competitive application process.
BY next August the transformation of Rippowam Park -- a state-subsidized moderate-income housing project formerly known as Ward Homes that was owned and operated by the Housing Authority for 45 years -- is expected to be completed. To date, 20 of the former Ward Homes tenants have been evicted for nonpayment of rent and disqualified from renting one of the new units.
The plans for Southfield Village, which is a federally financed low-income complex, will take at least five years to complete. The result will be a mixed-income, garden-apartment and town house neighborhood with backyards and parking areas, a community pool and a fitness center.
Beacon-Corcoran Jennison Partners, a joint venture of the Beacon Companies and Corcoran Jennison of Boston, will develop half of the 330 new units as federally subsidized rentals for low-income tenants. The other half will be rented to moderate-income tenants, except for 15 town houses, which will be sold.
The 24-acre project received a $26.4 million grant from the Hope VI program, which, like the state plan at Rippowam Park, allows housing authorities to redevelop deteriorated properties by forming partnerships with private developers. The housing authorities turn over ownership, rehabilitation and management of the properties to the developer, but retain the land on a 99-year lease. Other Hope VI projects are under way in Hartford and New Haven.
According to Edward Schwartz, executive director of the Stamford Housing Authority, H.U.D.'s grant will provide leverage for the $80 million that the project will cost. The city provided $3 million as leverage for the Federal grant and, according to Peter Wood, area redevelopment director for Beacon-Corcoran Jennison Partners, "we are applying for low-income housing tax credits and seeking some gap funding from the state."
"Since there is no purchase option for Hope VI projects," added Mr. Schwartz, "we are obligated to supply rent subsidies for the low-income units during the entire 99-year term of the ground lease."
His office oversees 18 public-housing properties in the city, some federally subsidized, others, like Rippowam Park, whose tenants' income may not exceed 60 percent of the area median of $89,300 for a family of four. "People pay 30 percent of their income or the minimum rent, whichever is higher," said Mr. Schwartz. "There are no rent subsidies."
Typically, a single individual earning a minimum of $17,550 pays $508 a month for a two-bedroom apartment, or $585 with a maximum income of $21,875. A family of four at Rippowam Park may earn between $46,620 and $53,580 and pay the minimum $1,415 or the maximum $1,554 a month for a four-bedroom apartment. A two-bedroom market rate apartment in Stamford rents for $1,800 to $2,200 a month.
"We saw nothing in Stamford that was as nice as this that wasn't a lot more expensive," said Beth Hale, who moved to Rippowam Park with her husband, Adam, last October.
Monica Pratcher, a five-year resident with two children, was moved to a vacant apartment while hers was renovated. "It took about three months," she said. "The difference is humongous."
EACH refurbished apartment has a small deck and backyard, fully equipped eat-in kitchen, one or one-and-a-half baths and central air-conditioning. New roofs and siding, rebuilt interiors, plumbing and electrical systems, walkways and landscaping, are standard renovations, and the Richman Group has hired uniformed off-duty policemen to patrol nightly. An independently owned day care center will operate rent-free on the site.
The complex covers 46 acres in a pleasant residential neighborhood known as Westover, across the street from the E. Gaynor Brennan municipal golf course. The terrain, which varies from rolling and wooded to level and grassy, is dotted with playgrounds and small parking lots for residents. Soon a community center will be completed with a gym, kitchen, and meeting rooms. Next door to the complex is the public Westover Magnet School, where Rippowam Park children have priority in the citywide lotteries for admission.
For the last 20 years developers across the country have competed for work turning around distressed public housing, according to Pamela Goodman, senior vice president of the Beacon Companies. "It's nowhere near as lucrative as building $500,000 condos," she said, "and there are days when I wonder whether the risk-reward relationship is in balance. Hope VI just makes it more complicated."
But profits are to be made in public housing that is not for the poorest of the poor. "We collect management fees," said John McClutchy, a partner in Rippowam Park Associates, "and the cumulative amount longterm, paid in rents that escalate by 3 or 4 percent a year, can be substantial." There is a cap, however, on profits of 10 to 15 percent for any state or federally financed housing, he said.
Peter Wood, Beacon-Corcoran Jennison's area director, calls public housing "a niche in our case."
"People on our staff have worked at H.U.D., bringing a great deal of expertise to affordable housing redevelopment," he said.
Ten years ago Corcoran Jennison turned an almost vacant 1,400-unit public-housing project in Boston into an award-winning mixed income complex called Harbor Point. Currently, it is working on Hope VI projects in New Haven, Boston, Pittsburgh and Detroit.
"They are only part of our overall portfolio, and we don't anticipate future cash flow on these jobs," Mr. Wood said. "But they contribute positively to our reputation, and we expect to break even, at least. It's a threshold question as to whether or not we will continue to do Hope VI projects."

HEADLINE: Neckties at Work: Untangling the Knot

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Foulard and Rep, Rest in Peace? Not So Fast!" (The Culture of Money, Dec. 6): 
 In discussing the declining use of neckties in America, and the backlash against the trend, the column stated that "there is no substitute" for a necktie in a man's wardrobe. "Without neckties to channel decorative instincts," it said, "men are left to flounder uncertainly in a sea of corduroys, khakis and 'dressy casuals.' "
For years, I and other men have found that the use of bola ties can channel decorative instincts without projecting an image of formality. (A bola tie, of course, is a string tie held in place by an ornament that is called a bola; the ends of the string are tipped in silver or other material.)
Bolas encourage a feeling of informality. They can be worn with the top of the shirt buttoned or unbuttoned and can be loosely or tightly fitted.
Unfortunately, bolas are not common outside the Southwest and West. Perhaps their greater use across the country would solve wardrobe problems for both men and women. I have worn them on business trips to Baltimore -- and have received compliments.
 
TERRY TORZALA
Tucson, Ariz., Dec. 6
 
The writer is a regulatory-affairs consultant for the medical equipment industry.

HEADLINE: WORKING;
The Job To Forget

BYLINE: By MICHELLE COTTLE; Michelle Cottle is a Washington writer.

 BODY:

Q. After taking night courses in business and finance over the last three years, I have moved from office support to management and now work at an entertainment services company. My resume shows that I'm not one to hop from place to place, yet after just four months at my new employer, I'm deeply unhappy and want to move on. How do I explain my desire to leave so soon?
 
A. Don't torture yourself over one bad decision. And don't bother trying to concoct a complicated cover story for why you want to flee after such a short time. It's time to face your mistake, admit it and move on.
"Just tell your employer that you were mistaken as to what being in the job would be like and that you now see that it's not a good fit for your talents," said Edward Emde, chief executive of Blessing/White, a consulting firm in Princeton, N.J. 
 Take responsibility for your mistake, agreed Marti D. Smye, author of "Is It Too Late to Run Away and Join the Circus?" (Macmillan, 1998). "Often people blame the organization, instead of saying, 'I didn't do a good assessment for myself,' "she observed.
No matter how miserable you are, don't just drop your two weeks' notice on the boss's desk. Express your regret over any problems your departure may cause and offer to stay long enough to help find a replacement, Ms. Smye advised. Promise to make your successor's transition as painless as possible. "How you leave is more important than staying in a job you don't like," she said.
Of course, before breaking the news to your employer, you should determine exactly what the problem is. Do you hate the bureaucratic nature of the company? Or its unstructured work style? Or do you dislike being in charge? Your boss will want to know why you are leaving, and you should be prepared to offer a more thoughtful explanation than simply, "I'm unhappy."
More important, in seeking other jobs, you will need to articulate how they will suit you better than your last position, Mr. Emde said. That can assure hiring managers that you've learned from your mistake and are now far less likely to repeat it.
Just because you're being straightforward, however, don't forget the first law of job-hunting: Accentuate the positive. Don't emphasize your recent career fiasco when calling on prospective employers, advised Tom Jackson, author of "Guerrilla Tactics in the New Job Market" (Bantam, 1991).
Four months wasn't really enough time to get settled, so you might not even want to update your resume to include your last job, he said. You need to be honest, however, so mention in your cover letter that the job hasn't proved a good fit. And in all correspondence, he said, focus less on your last position and more on the type of environment where you think you'd be most productive. "Put forward what it is you want and what you can do," he said.
Just make sure you know what that is. Your next employer is likely to be much less understanding if, come spring, you decide you've made another horrible mistake.
 
Michelle Cottle is a Washington writer. Each week, she will respond to readers' questions about career and workplace issues. Send them by E-mail to working@nytimes.com or by mail to Working, Money & Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

LENGTH: 1100 words

HEADLINE: THE YEAR IN REVIEW: FILM;
War Stories, on the Beach and in the Home

BYLINE: By JANET MASLIN

 BODY:

1. 'SAVING PRIVATE RYAN' -- Steven Spielberg took the enormous risk of recreating the experience of World War II combat and reminding contemporary audiences of all the patriotism, shock and horrific sacrifice that it entailed. And in a film year otherwise devoted to the darkest visions of American life, he touched a long-buried, fundamental nerve. This wrenchingly visceral war epic was also a bravura visual achievement, with the swiftness and economy of its storytelling and the terrifying, furious immediacy of its battles. Audiences were rightly stunned by so fierce and meaningful a re-examination of the American character under fire. 

2. 'HAPPINESS' -- Todd Solondz turned out to be no mean stunner himself. His merrily outrageous, expertly written ensemble piece was a true original, able to achieve the most perverse insights with unnerving empathy, and without the slightest straining for effect. This filmmaker seems to come naturally by the skewed, murderously funny world view that yielded the biggest and best of the year's pitch-black comedies. And his wicked screenplay plumbed the collective misery of its lonely characters with dazzling finesse. As structurally elegant as it was taboo-shattering, "Happiness" arrived at just the right moment. The worst excesses of tabloid culture paled before Mr. Solondz's matter-of-fact glimpses of family life.
 
3. 'THE BUTCHER BOY' -- Delving into the mind of a troubled young hero might have been solemn business from a filmmaker less imaginatively offbeat than the director of "The Crying Game." But Neil Jordan filled this study of the boy's disintegrating sanity, based on Patrick McCabe's equally daring novel, with ever more chilling ebullience as it began to inhabit the boy's mind. Brilliantly juxtaposing external and subjective reality, Mr. Jordan created a wildly fanciful mental landscape within a workaday Irish town and melted the boundaries between madness and reason to electrifying effect. Eamonn Owens, whose only previous international exposure had been marching with his youth band in New York's St. Patrick's Day parade, gave an unforgettably blistering performance in the central role.
 
4. 'HENRY FOOL' -- None of Hal Hartley's earlier films matched the ambitions of this deft cultural allegory, with its wry tale of art and fame in a tug of war. Minimalist in style yet sweeping in vision, Mr. Hartley's story centered on a Queens janitor with a resemblance to a young Samuel Beckett and a previously untapped genius for rousing the populace with his written word. When he fell into the hands of a literary shaman with enough overweening pretensions for the two of them, Mr. Hartley had a field day with the possibilities. Beautifully meticulous despite the occasional needless gross-out, it featured Parker Posey at her most divinely petulant and the best of this filmmaker's shrewdly deadpan style.
 
5. 'SHAKESPEARE IN LOVE' - Mischievously literate Elizabethans, hilarious backstage farce and the sultry teamwork of Joseph Fiennes and Gwyneth Paltrow (as passionate prototypes for Romeo and Juliet) made this the most enchanting entertainment of the year. With a sparkling screenplay by Tom Stoppard and Marc Norman, John Madden's film had the temerity to speculate about Shakespeare's life on the basis of his work. Rarely has such presumptuousness paid off so shamelessly well. Amid a splendid supporting cast, the stars shone even more brightly than Sandy Powell's spectacular costumes.
 
6. 'A SIMPLE PLAN' -- The sleeper of the year, this finely calibrated thriller brought out the best in Scott Smith's novel about the poisonous effects of a windfall on small-town characters in a stark, snowbound setting. Its biggest surprise, beyond the way Bill Paxton and Billy Bob Thornton outshone even their acting collaboration in "One False Move," was the transition made by Sam Raimi from cult horror films to such adroit, subtle storytelling. Modest as it looked, this drama built inexorable momentum as it weighed the consequences of its characters' every misstep, and created a shockingly smooth continuum between good and evil. The stars, cast as brothers, played their last scene together like the instant classic that it is.
 
7. 'THE CELEBRATION' -- Thomas Vinterberg made this boisterous Danish film under an exacting set of creative restrictions, which made its freewheeling brio that much more triumphant. The camera swiveled and soared through an elaborate family reunion, with a skeleton in every closet and an irrepressibly robust quality to the whole gathering. For its sheer vigor without tricks, stunts, makeup or fancy lighting, Mr. Vinterberg's film was a refreshing change and a remarkable achievement.
 
8. 'BULWORTH' -- In a year that cried out for political satire, Warren Beatty delivered one with sharp claws. He played a senator driven to despair by his own lack of conviction until, uproariously, candor set him free. If the idea of a 60-year-old white rapper raised a few hackles, it also embodied the anything-goes spirit that turned a potentially broad, partisan comedy into a bona fide breath of fresh air. Mr. Beatty's panache, vaporized in films like "Love Affair," made a welcome re-emergence. And Oliver Platt's supporting turn (as a slick aide trying to keep the Senator looking respectable) was one of the funniest performances of the year.
 
9. 'THE OPPOSITE OF SEX' -- Family values, 1998-style, as Christina Ricci's evil minx exploited everyone in her path. Sour as this show of nonstop cynicism appeared, it made for an unexpectedly generous, conciliatory comedy from the writer-director Don Roos, not to mention a delectably funny one. And it delivered some of the year's most knowing ideas about the making of sexual connections in these endlessly complicated times, as it intermingled gay and straight characters, innocent and scheming ones, with fearless aplomb. Ms. Ricci and Lisa Kudrow were outstanding as diametrically opposed characters trading acid-dipped repartee.
 
10. 'WESTERN' -- Major themes and high drama were nowhere to be found in this misleadingly titled French road movie. But its humor and tenderness, combined with the slyest of deadpan timing, made it one of the high points of my moviegoing experience this year. Shot in wide-screen format amid a series of tranquil Brittany landscapes, it watched two gentle drifters form a rueful friendship, explore their surroundings and try amusingly and dismally to beguile women. It's on this list only because I smile at the memory of it and remember every frame.
