SECTION: Section 6; Page 41; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 3755 words

HEADLINE: Apocalypse Now. No, Really. Now!

BYLINE: By Alex Heard and Peter Klebnikov; Alex Heard, an editor at Wired magazine, is the author of "Apocalypse Pretty Soon," to be published in February by W. W. Norton. Peter Klebnikov, a New York writer, is at work on a book about American doomsday groups.

 BODY:
With 1999 almost on us and the year 2000 starting to awaken, growl and plod fatefully toward the camera lens, you can count on 12 months of panicky millennial excitements. The personnel are certainly out there, ready to go. According to a 1997 Associated Press poll, nearly 1 in 4 adult Christians -- upward of 26 million people -- expect Christ to return in their lifetimes, fulfilling the complicated End Times scenario that many people glean from prophetic Bible texts like Revelation and Daniel. The Christians are joined by lesser but impressive numbers of apocalyptic others, with their own scripts of doom and redemption. Ted Daniels, a folklorist in Philadelphia whose Millennium Watch Institute has monitored millennial activity for years, says that his database alone holds the names of more than 1,200 self-proclaimed prophets.
 In light of disasters like Heaven's Gate, that sounds alarming, and millennialism can be troublesome, as some people in the pages that follow vividly demonstrate. But despite their extraordinary flash and strangeness, apocalyptic movements have a long, relatively peaceful history in American life. The meaning of the Greek word apokalypsis is "to uncover," and the motive force for believers has usually been a hunger for the fulfillment of revelatory knowledge -- a conviction that through the willed application of belief, the flaws of this world will be swept away, with the faithful ushered to a brighter place. None of it is very logical, but so what? Religion often isn't. The Judeo-Christian belief that disaster must precede salvation has radiated outward from the events described in the Book of Revelation -- home to the Four Horsemen, the Battle of Armageddon -- but the Bible doesn't say anything about when these calamities will start. Jesus even warns his disciples against trying to figure it out, saying, "of that day and of that hour knoweth no man." 
 Contemporary millennialists know all this, but the date still gets people worked up, whether they specifically believe 2000 is the magic number or (more often) see it as a flash point, a symbol of what someday might be. As an excited prophecy commentator named David Allen Lewis wrote: "2000! . . . You see it everywhere, like a universal logo!"
 
U.F.O. Deliverance
 1. Unarius Academy of Science, El Cajon, Calif. Founded in 1954 by Ernest and Ruth Norman (pictured), Unarius is housed in a lovingly decorated old Post Office, where a few dozen regulars study a complicated mix of flying-saucer theology and past-lives therapy, the idea being that Earth is a "kindergarten" for spiritually debased souls. While the students work out negative karma earned in ancient civilizations like Atlantis, they await a mass landing in the year 2001 by wise Space Brothers from 32 other planets; they will join the Academy and usher in a new age of enlightenment.
 
New Age
 2. Morningland, Long Beach, Calif. Housed in a fortified compound and led by an aging priestess, Sri Patricia, Morningland teaches that Christ will someday descend to Long Beach in a U.F.O. the size of Texas, piloted by Patricia's deceased husband. It currently recruits members through yard sales. Morningland is a multiservice sect, dispensing tarot readings, Zen meditation classes and Ufology. As a special feature, it charges people to cure them of AIDS -- Sri Patricia, a self-proclaimed messiah, claims she can change people's DNA with a wave of a hand. The group's 40 or so members are taught that humans are responsible for the coming destruction because of their irresponsible stewardship of earth's resources.
 
Y2K Chaos
 3. Ted Hall, McKenna, Wash. Hall is the author of "Beat the Beast," described as the only upbeat Y2K preparedness book. Hall and other believers in Y2K survivalism -- arguably the hottest area of contemporary millennialism -- fear that the world's computers will fail at midnight on Jan. 1, 2000, leading to anarchy, blackouts and global chaos. He also contends that the feared computer shutdown fulfills Bible prophecies of the End Times arrival of a beast whose "number is 666." The good news: You can win out over "cyber-beast 666." The book is mainly about practical tips for surviving. Step 1: Create cooperative farms. "Mother Earth is one big free lunch," says Hall.
 
Christian Doomsday
 4. Chuck Missler, Coeur d'Alene, Idaho. Christian millennialists aren't usually interested in U.F.O.'s -- that stuff is for New Agers -- but Missler is different. A former C.E.O. who heads a large media ministry called Koinonia House, he believes extraterrestrials are real, but they're not from other worlds. "They pose as aliens," he says in a taped lecture, "but what are they really?" Missler says they're beings called Nephilim, the lingering spirits of "supernatural monstrosities" created eons ago when fallen angels mated with human women. Their existence inspired God to cleanse the earth with the flood, but now they're coming back -- as ET's, reseeding earth women for dark purposes that predicate the imminent final battles. Missler has sponsored "Israel Cruises," tours of the Holy Land with a focus on apocalyptic ports of call. The 1998 edition included stops at the Isle of Patmos (where the Book of Revelation was written in the first century A.D.); the Mount of Olives (where Jesus thrilled and chilled his disciples with doomsday discussions); and the "Valley of Armageddon," where Christ is to defeat the forces of Satan once and for all. There was also a spot of cruise-ship boogieing, including a Saturday night "Biblical Character Masquerade Party."
 
New Age
 5. Church Universal and Triumphant, Corwin Springs, Mont. Led by Elizabeth Clare Prophet, this New Age church gained fame in 1990 when Prophet predicted an imminent nuclear holocaust. The sect assembled a cache of weapons, and disciples hunkered down into a network of bomb shelters. When the planet survived, many became disillusioned and moved away, ushering in a rocky period for the church. Prophet has acknowledged that she has Alzheimer's, and the church is selling much of its land. (Shelters are on "special sale" at $5,000 each.) The world will end anytime soon, Prophet still maintains.
 
Christ Figures
 6. The True and Living Church of Jesus Christ of Saints of the Last Days, Manti, Utah. James Harmston, 58, a former real-estate agent, claims he was ordained by Moses and is, according to his followers, the reincarnation of Joseph Smith, the long-dead 19th-century founder of the Mormon Church. Harmston predicts that a period of violent, apocalyptic turmoil will start within five years. In preparation, he started a Mormon survivalist community in the town of Manti, where some 300 armed, food-storing polygamist followers plan to ride it out. (Harmston denies there are arms and food.) Several former members of the sect are suing Harmston, alleging that he duped them for $250,000, and the church has been excommunicated by Mormon authorities in Salt Lake City for"undue preoccupation with Armageddon." Harmston says he is planning a countersuit.
 
Christ Figures
 7. Concerned Christians, current location unknown. Monte Kim Miller, 44, is a Colorado-based cult leader who has told followers he is one of the two witnesses who is fated to announce the destruction of the earth and coming of the Lord -- and then be slain by Satan in the streets of Jerusalem. Earlier this year, he predicted that Denver would be ground zero for the apocalypse this fall. Taking 78 people with him, he later disappeared in the middle of the night, leaving behind abandoned houses and hundreds of frightened relatives. Several of the members have since appeared in Jerusalem, generating official worry that the group is gathering there for a climactic moment.
 
Y2K Choas
 8. High 54 Ranch, near Concho Lake, Ariz. High 54 is an in-the-works Y2K survivalism community. The rural retreat is still under construction, but soon hopes to offer amenities like underground living quarters, 24-hour armed security, perimeter guards, wind- and solar-power sources and a barter economy. Potential members are required to arrive with at least a one-year supply of food and at least one rifle and one handgun per family, preferably with 1,000 rounds of ammo per weapon. Gas masks, though not required, are highly recommended.
 
Asteroid!
 9. Lori Adaile Toye, Payson, Ariz. Toye channels information from New Age "ascended masters" who have laid out the future geography of the planet after an already-in-progress period of tribulation that will last a thousand years. Called "Freedom Star," the new earth wins a few and loses a few. Much of the Western U.S. will sink underwater after a giant asteroid strikes Nevada. On the plus side, an entirely new continent called New Lemuria will form west of South America, and the world will be graced by golden cities with names like Wahanee, Gandawan and Mesotamp. Sad news for New York: The city disappears underwater, too, but the Statue of Liberty survives as "the Island of Vision."
 
Avenging Planet
 10. Floyd (Looks for Buffalo) Hand, Pine Ridge Indian Reservation, S.D. Hand, 59, a healer from the Oglala Sioux tribe, points to ancient Sioux and Hopi prophecies that speak of the imminent arrival of "Star People," wise extraterrestrials who will remove Indians and chosen others from a planet that will soon be deviled by a 1999 drought, followed by floods and earthquakes. "The reason is that humans have not been taking care of the land, have been chopping trees and polluting the air," says Hand. A further warning: "Get the hell out of New York in seven years! That's when the earth plates will shift and tall buildings will sway."
 
Christian Doomsday
 11. House of Yahweh, Abilene, Tex. Yisrayl Hawkins, the assumed name of a former rockabilly singer named Bill Hawkinshas convinced some 3,000 followers that he is the "witness" who will announce Christ's Second Coming before being murdered by Satan. From an armed compound in scrublands near Abilene, Hawkins and his followers are building a ragtag "holy city," where followers are to wait for the return of Christ in the year 2000. "Thankfully, we only have a year left of this madness," he says.
 
U.F.O. Deliverance
 12. Outer Dimensional Forces, Weslaco, Tex. Based in a weedy, fenced-off compound near the Mexican border, O.D.F. is a secretive doomsday sect whose members believe that the U.S. is heading for heaven-sent punishment that was set in motion when the C.I.A. allegedly "attacked" O.D.F. two decades ago. In a TV interview broadcast after the Heaven's Gate suicides, a bearded, intense O.D.F. spokesman named Daniel Hoverson said the Creator will soon rattle and flood the U.S., with the O.D.F. surviving by being spirited to safety in flying saucers. The group was founded by Orville T. Gordon -- better known as "Nodrog" -- a 90-something man who is rarely seen in public.
 
Angry Separatists
 13. Elohim City, Muldrow, Okla. Elohim City is an armed compound guided by Robert Millar, 73, a former Mennonite who based his revelations on an eclectic mix of fundamentalist Christianity, racism, pyramidology and astrology. Millar teaches his followers that the Great Tribulation is upon us and that "worse is to come"when "Asiatics" invade America. "I abhor war," Millar says, "but it is a foregone conclusion." He says he believes that Jesus has been revealing himself for 2,000 years and that disasters will strike, possibly by 2006, at which time the "wicked will be removed" and Elohim City will enjoy an age of peace.
 
Y2K Chaos
 14. Bob Rutz, Kingston, Ark. Rutz, 67, an engineer and entrepreneur, is another "builder" on the Y2K survivalism scene. Rutz and his wife, Joan, are constructing Prayer Lake, a 700-acre Christian community in the hills of northwest Arkansas. Rutz hopes 100 families buy three-acre plots and get back to simple ways of living: plowing with mules, reading by kerosene lamps, drinking from springs and wells. "I look at this as Judgment Day," he says.
 
Christ Figures
 15. Kenna E. Farris, Savannah, Mo. In 1967 Farris, then a restaurateur, received what he describes as a direct call from God to serve as "the Forerunner Prophet of the Apocalypse," designated to spread the word that Christ will return in the year 3000, not 2000. Great things must happen before then, though: for starters, a "prophet President" must arise soon to create a 24-nation "barter-banking" trade center that promotes "Horse Sense Economics" and world unity. Now 73, Farris spreads his ideas via large, insistent, hand-lettered signs and self-published books like "The Greatest Unsolved Mysteries of All Times of Biblical Prophecy Wisdom."
 
New Age
 16. Dolores Cannon, Huntsville, Ark. Cannon is a cheerful, elderly "reporter of lost knowledge" who has used hypnotized human intermediaries to travel back in time and speak directly to Nostradamus, the 16th-century French seer who supposedly predicted violent upheavals in our day. The results, contained in her three-volume "Conversations With Nostradamus," are gloomy: Nostradamus calls the 1990's "the Time of Troubles" and says the Antichrist, identity unknown, is in hiding now in the Middle East. Luckily, the dire prophecies can be staved off if mankind radiates enough good will. "Nostradamus thought that if people knew what was going to happen," Cannon explains, "we could keep it from happening."
 
Christian Doomsday
 17. The Rev. Clyde Lott, Canton, Miss. Lott, a Pentecostal minister, interprets passages of the Bible to say that a third Jewish temple must rise in Jerusalem before the Second Coming can happen. Some messianic Jews think the Messiah won't come (for the first time) until the temple is restored. In an improbable partnership with a Jerusalem-based rabbi named Chaim Richman, Lott is producing perfect red heifers, virginal cows "without spot" that could be sacrificed to produce ashes for ritual use in the future temple. For that to happen, Muslim shrines like the Dome of the Rock would have to be knocked down. Neither Lott nor Richman advocates destructive violence, but both men are convinced that God will attend to this impediment in due time.
 
Asteroid!
 18. Wake Up America Seminars, Bellbrook, Ohio. Founded by Larry Wilson, a Vietnam veteran and prophecy student, the Wake Up America ministry has a particular fascination with asteroids. Wilson's reading of Scripture (like Revelation 8:7, which speaks of "hail and fire mixed with blood") has him convinced that two giant rocks will bash the earth during periods of Tribulation and Wrath that precede the Last Judgment. Rejecting the popular millennialist notion of a rapture, a grace-giving moment when the faithful are whisked safely into heaven, he believes people will have to tough out calamities that he identifies with eerie labels like "Volcanoes Cause Darkness" and "Devil Appears." When? "As best as I can tell," Wilson says, "the Tribulation starts somewhere between 1999 and 2017."
 
U.F.O Deliverance
 19. Chen Tao, near Buffalo. Previously based in Garland, Tex., Chen Tao entered the national spotlight last winter, when its leader, a Taiwanese emigre named Chen Hon Ming, predicted that God would appear on March 25. Overcoming this setback, he has since moved 80 of his Taiwanese followers to a place just outside Buffalo. Dressed in regulation white smocks and cowboy hats, Chen Tao faithful expect Armageddon to start next month, when China invades Taiwan and precipitates a nuclear holocaust. Eventually a third of the world's population will die, but God will arrive in a"Godplane" to deliver the sect's believers from doom.
 
Avenging Planet
 20. Gordon-Michael Scallion, Chesterfield, N.H. Scallion is a psychic and booster of "Earth Changes," a New Age prophecy belief that predicts violent planetary shakings in the years ahead, marked by escalating earthquakes, hurricanes, rising oceans, ubiquitous volcanoes and other unpleasantries. Some Earth Changes believers think the planet itself is willing these punishments; Scallion sees them as part of a "natural" astrophysical cycle worsened by man's sloppy environmental caretaking. His "Future Map of the World" shows major portions of all the continents underwater, including much of the American West. For 1999 he predicts "calamitous melt-offs at the poles" and a regional conflict in Turkey that will later lead to World War III.
 
Christian Doomsday
 21. The Brethren, Boston. This nomadic, Old and New Testament doomsday group maintains a temporary clandestine base near Boston University. From there, some 100 college-age followers of "Brother Evangelist" Jim Roberts roam the country in robes meant to hide the human form, preaching that Americans are doomed by their materialism and fated to perish in the Great Tribulation. Targeting disaffected kids, the Brethren requires joiners to abandon all material goods and prior family connections. For years, the sect was called "the Garbage Eaters" for its members' habit of eating out of dumpsters.
 
Angry Separatists
 22. Twelve Tribes of Israel, New York. A separatist group with U.F.O. themes, with branches in half a dozen cities, Twelve Tribes is led by a mysterious, disciplinarian-prophet named Rawhab (left, in dark shirt). Its goal is to "prepare" followers for the End Times, in which chosen blacks, Hispanics and Native Americans will survive earthquakes, floods and a huge race war that commences sometime in the near future. Followers believe that black space brothers are now circling earth in spaceships that will rescue their human counterparts in a "marvelous miracle," levitating them to a world where persecution and white people will be no more.
 
Asteroid!
 23. Kabbalah Learning Center, New York. Philip Berg is rabbi to the stars -- he has long taught mystical texts like the Zohar to a celebrity clientele, including Madonna and Roseanne. He has also proclaimed, quite seriously, that the End might arrive on Sept. 11, 1999, when "a ball of fire will descend . . . destroying almost all of mankind, all vegetation, all forms of life." If mankind takes to "sharing more" and studying cabalistic texts, the species will most likely be spared.
 
Angry Separatists
 24. Thomas Chittum, Lake Hopatcong, N.J. "America was born in blood, America suckled in blood . . . and America will drown in blood." So writes Thomas Chittum, author of "Civil War Two," an influential far-right tract that says the U.S. is headed for an explosive crackup, as regional wars break out along racial lines. Chittum is notably fretful about the Southwest; he thinks that unchecked immigration will make it a de facto part of Mexico by 2020. Chittum says he plans to relocate someday to the northern reaches of New York State, where he figures Caucasians will still be in charge.
 
Christian Doomsday
 25. James BeauSeigneur, Rockville, Md. BeauSeigneur is a two-time Congressional candidate (he lost to Al Gore in 1980) who has written a lively three-part novel dramatizing the End Times events described in Revelation. Such novels are quite popular among prophecy-believing Christians, who often work out pent-up energies about Christ's imminent return through potboiler fiction that is heavy on horror and rapine. BeauSeigneur's "Christ Clone Trilogy" livens things up with a sci-fi premise: cells scraped from the Shroud of Turin are used to clone a new version of Christ. And? "The clone," BeauSeigneur says ominously, "goes sour."
 
U.F.O Deliverance
 26. The Center for the Study of Extraterrestrial Intelligence, Asheville, N.C. Dr. Steven M. Greer is an emergency-room doctor who, in his spare time, takes squads of U.F.O. buffs out for nighttime vigils, during which they wave flashlights and think positive thoughts in an utterly serious attempt to entice flying saucers to land. Greer, who has a sizable national following, believes extraterrestrials are here to share a new-paradigm millennial consciousness. He is also convinced the Federal Government wants to harm them. He once told Art Bell, host of a talk-radio show on the paranormal, that a "covert" and "extra-extra secret supersecret" Government team has coldbloodedly blasted flying saucers out of the sky.
 
Avenging Planet
 27. Richard W. Noone, Ellijay, Ga. Many apocalyptic theorizers shy away from precise date-setting, but not Noone, author of the book "5/5/2000," which states that on May 5, 2000, the earth's crust will "shift" horribly as part of a series of cataclysmic changes that usher in a new ice age. The mechanics are complicated -- factors include an extraordinary alignment of the planets -- but the results are clear enough. Three-quarters of the human race will be killed. "The last shift like this occurred 9,000 years ago," Noone says grimly. "It turned the oceans into maelstroms of death." An ardent survivalist, he lives in the mountains of north Georgia.
 
Christ Figures
 28. Arthur Blessitt, North Fort Myers, Fla. Blessitt, a strapping Christian evangelist (above, with his wife, Denise), has spent the last 29 years carrying a 12-foot cross-on-a-wheel through every nation. It started in 1969, when Blessitt -- then the proprietor of a Sunset Strip coffeehouse-for-Jesus called His Place -- decided to traverse America with a cross as a one-time faith statement. That led to more ambitious travels, and in 1988, the Lord officially told him to drag a cross through 277 nations, island groups and territories before 2000, for reasons relating to the Last Days. "I don't know what the time-date will be," he says. "I just know this is part of God's End Time plan." The deed is done: this year he knocked off his last two countries, Iraq and North Korea, having covered, by his count, a whopping 32,762 miles.
 
Christian Doomsday
 29. Meade Ministries, Lake City, Fla. Years ago, Charles Meade was told by God that Lake City would be the only place on the planet to survive Armageddon, which the octogenarian Meade predicts will come in his lifetime. The world will soon be engulfed in a sticky white substance, Meade has said, leaving his church standing as a beacon of light. In recent years, some 2,000 followers have left their homes in at least 14 states and moved into a guarded subdivision. The Meade-ites have prospered in local businesses, and the church has built a stunning $10 million worship center shaped like an overturned Noah's ark -- a design that is meant to attract new members.

LENGTH: 1348 words

HEADLINE: Nassau County Tries to Fix Budget Problem

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER

 BODY:
EMBARRASSED by a bond rating agency report that showed Nassau County's budget in disarray despite the strong economy, Nassau officials are scrambling to restructure county finances to solve the problem.
But some officials said last week they were unsure whether the county could solve its budget problem anytime soon, and if an economic downturn came, they said, it would have to be met without benefit of financial reserves that should have been set aside during the boom times of the past seven years. 
 Officials and financial analysts said the recent announcement by Standard & Poor's, a bond-rating agency, that it was placing county bonds on its credit watch list because of a looming $100 million deficit in the county's $2.3 billion budget underscored a problem that had been growing worse for several years.
In interviews last week, the officials and analysts said the county needed urgently to end a disturbing reliance on one-time infusions of cash to balance annual budgets, a practice most traced to County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta, the county's chief budget architect.
They said there has been a recurring pattern in which so-called one-shot revenues projected for county land sales, Medicaid payment refunds and other one-time-only items were used to balance budgets. When these revenues failed to materialize, came in at lower amounts than projected or arrived late, they said, the county was compelled to borrow to close budget deficits and meet day-to-day expenses.
"One-shots work one time," said Bruce Nyman, the Democratic minority leader of the Nassau County Legislature. "If you keep using them, eventually you're going to run out, and that's what we are seeing now."
The result, Mr. Nyman said, was a wealthy county in financial crisis when most governments were on easy street.
"The whole state of New York, the whole country, is awash in surplus money except for one place, Nassau County," Mr. Nyman said. "Doesn't that tell you something about our fiscal practices?"
Mr. Gulotta said in a statement that the issues raised by Standard & Poor's would be addressed swiftly, but declined through a spokesman to be interviewed.
Bruce A. Blakeman, the Republican presiding officer of the County Legislature, defended the Republican majority's budget actions and appeared to lay blame on Mr. Gulotta, also a Republican.
"We have been far more conservative than the executive branch and we have continually eliminated questionable revenues from the budget," Mr. Blakeman said. "I can assure the rating agencies that we are absolutely determined to get the financial house in order."
Joseph N. Mondello, the chairman of the Nassau County Republican Committee, said he was "hopeful something can be done" before conditions worsened.
"We're getting to the point where we can't consider one-shots," Mr. Mondello said. "We need sustainable revenue sources. Those are the things that are going to put this county on an even keel."
One source of such revenues, Mr. Mondello said, would be increased county property taxes.
As Nassau struggled, neighboring Suffolk County was finishing the year with a modest budget surplus and a sales tax a quarter percentage point lower than Nassau's. "We don't rely on one-shots to fund our budget," said James J. Spero, the deputy director of the Suffolk legislature's Budget Review Office.
Analysts for rating agencies spoke bluntly about Nassau's fiscal straits.
Diane P. Brosen, director of public finance ratings for Standard & Poor's, said the decision to put the bonds on credit watch was prompted by a glaring structural imbalance in its $2.3 billion annual budget.
"Ongoing revenues do not meet ongoing expenses and the county continues to rely on one-time revenues to balance it's budget," Ms. Brosen said. "And when those revenues aren't received as budgeted, the county has to borrow to pay it's bills.
"We are at the peak of the economic cycle and the county's financial situation is stressed," she said. "From a rating perspective, what we would expect at this point in the cycle would be that the county was beginning to save for a rainy day, which could be the next recession."
Helen Cregger, an assistant vice president at Moody's Investors Service, another bond rating agency, said that the county's short-term borrowing was up 30 percent this year, a sign of financial strain. "Obviously, the county's current fiscal situation is tenuous," she said.
The current crisis involves $60 million the county was to receive from the sale of the Nassau County Medical Center and other county-owned health facilities to a public benefit corporation.
With the year ending, the sale has been stalled by negotiations over the amount of the subsidy the county would pay to the corporation and the contract for county employees who would work for the corporation but continue to be paid by the county.
Ms. Cregger said that the county needed to resolve the negotiations to protect the county's credit from slipping further. "We are down to the wire on this and time is running out," she said.
The public benefit corporation would operate the 615-bed Nassau County Medical Center, an acute-care hospital with 2,821 employees, a county-owned nursing home with 900 employees and nine health clinics now operated by the Nassau County Department of Health. Nassau has 14,780 employees, including the police.
In a broader view, problems facing the county reflect the extreme reluctance of Mr. Gulotta and the county's legislative branch to increase property taxes, the surest and most predictable way to produce revenues in a county whose $95 billion tax base is among the highest for any county in the nation. County property taxes account for about 20 percent of total property taxes paid by an average Nassau homeowner.
The situation is further exacerbated by high costs to the county for services it provides as well as rising county personnel costs driven by collective-bargaining agreements and, in the case of the county police, arbitration awards. The police budget accounts for nearly three-quarters of the tax levy in the current county budget.
Even surging sales tax revenues, which have grown by at least 4 percent annually for the past several years, have been insufficient to lift the county out of trouble when one-shots failed.
"You can't continue to have rising costs and a high level of services and reductions or stability in the property tax without something giving way," said the County Comptroller, Frederick E. Parola.
Mr. Parola said property taxes accounted for about $550 million of current revenues, while sales taxes -- more heavily relied on by the county in recent years but highly sensitive to economic changes that affected retail sales -- accounted for about $730 million.
The county keeps 4 percent of the 8.5 sales percent sales tax charged in Nassau, the highest rate in the state and one of the highest in the country.
Mr. Parola said that "overly sanguine" budget projections of sales tax revenues had also added to fiscal woes. But it was reliance on one-shots, he said, that had hurt the most.
"What Nassau really needs to implement is a pay-as-you-go financial program so we rely less and less on these nonrecurring one-shots," Mr. Parola said.
In his statement following the Standard and Poor's announcement, Mr. Gulotta said that issues raised by agency would be resolved by an agreement on operation of the public benefit corporation.
Mr. Gulotta also said in his statement that property taxes had been cut or frozen for seven years, while crime was at record lows and welfare rolls were down sharply. He said he would join with Mr. Parola's office and the Legislature to address issues raised by the agencies.
The leader of a group that follows Nassau budget practices applauded the Standard and Poor's rating for prodding county officials into action.
"It was well deserved," said Phoebe Goodman, executive director of the Nassau Citizen's Budget Committee. "I can't think of anything else that would awaken them. I just hope they pay attention."

HEADLINE: OUT OF ORDER;
Anxiously Looking Ahead to 1999

BYLINE: By DAVID BOUCHIER; The author is an essayist and commentator on public radio.

 BODY:
THIS is the week when newspaper columnists traditionally offer predictions for the coming year. But columnists, like everyone else, are battle-scarred and hung over from the past week's festivities, so their prophecies tend to be gloomy and apocalyptic.
Pessimistic guesses about the future are the growth industry of the modern age. Financial advisers, multimillion-dollar think tanks, TV pundits, market researchers, sociologists and fundamentalist preachers are all eager to tell us just how bad it will be. We can safely ignore them all. Only your mother knows the future. She says, "If you go out without your scarf, you'll get a cold," and you do. But the world isn't run by mothers who would save us from all kinds of foolish choices. So we stumble about in darkness and ignorance, anxiously listening to false prophets. Ever since the anonymous author of Psalms predicted that "The meek shall inherit the earth," prophets have got nothing right. 
 The secret of being a successful prophet is to speak in very vague terms and to forecast only those things that are absolutely guaranteed to happen. This is the time-honored technique of fortune tellers and astrologers, who can assure you with perfect truth that "Troubles lie ahead" or "Relationships will be full of difficulty."
If I wanted to gain a reputation for clairvoyance, I would make the following predictions for Long Island in 1999. There will be more traffic. The HOV lanes will be opened to all drivers, and thousands of new vehicles will instantly materialize out of the fourth dimension and bring them to a standstill. The L.I.R.R. will respond by taking trains out of service, slowing down the ones that are left, and sabotaging the few remaining air-conditioning units. There will be more subdivisions, more strip malls, more pollution scares, more taxes, and many complaints about all of the above. Elected officials will deplore the situation and blame each other. Absolutely nothing will be done.
On the world scene, there will be trouble in the Middle East, trouble with Iraq, trouble in Africa, trouble in Ireland, trouble with China and violence in the Balkans. All of these have been daily headlines since 1899 and can be relied upon to come around again next year. In Washington, a special prosecutor will be appointed to investigate Vice President Gore's campaign finances. Newt Gingrich will make a comeback, and Brad Pitt will never go away.
One thing we can be sure of is that 1999 will be a year of widespread and pointless anxiety. Prophets of doom will descend on us like the proverbial plagues of Egypt -- religious prophets, scientific prophets, economic and sociological and ecological prophets, all crying out that "the sky is falling." These professional Chicken Littles have been predicting the apocalypse in the year 2000 ever since it so annoyingly failed to happen in the year 1000.
In the runup to the millennium, we won't be allowed to think about anything else. Our lives will be put on hold, as we try to cope with the deluge of books, movies, TV specials, newspaper articles and Web pages proclaiming the end of the world. CBS Radio has already run the first of what will be many millennium scare series. In California, the nervous inhabitants of paradise have launched the "Cassandra Project," hoarding gold, arming themselves and moving into the mountains. In Texas, response to millennium chaos is being simulated by the police and emergency services. Even the British Government has advised its citizens to begin stockpiling food.
This silly neurosis is based on the expectation that, in January 2000, millions of computers will become confused by the year 2000 and go catatonic. This is called the Y2K problem. Compared to the stuff predicted in the Book of Revelations, the Y2K problem is nothing. We've only had computers for a few years. If every single one of them crashes, how bad can it be?
Accountants and the I.R.S. may be put out of business, causing universal woe and lamentation. Air-traffic control may collapse at midnight on Dec. 31, 1999, leading to a revival of ocean-liner travel and long-distance buses, and perhaps even encouraging people to stay at home. The Pentagon computers may forget who or where the enemy is and start churning out messages of peace and goodwill. Centenarians will start receiving child support payments, people will be surprised by very early or very late retirements, credit cards will become useless, and your local library will start claiming fines for books a hundred years overdue.
Just a year and four days from now, your home computer may go dark, forcing a painful renewal of family life and personal relationships. On the first day of the year 2000, called the "drop dead point," every gadget we take for granted will be in jeopardy: automatic gasoline pumps, telephones, traffic signals, and even the sacred television itself. Service at malls will be even slower. Getting through the supermarket checkout may take days. But, without work or television, what else will we have to do?
This prospect of traveling back to an earlier and simpler time seems wonderfully attractive. But remember that you can never trust a prophet, especially when he brings good news. The fact is that none of these things will happen, and 2000 will be exactly like 1998. All our worry and anxiety will be wasted.
What I propose is that we just skip the next worrying year, go straight to the millennium and get it over with.

HEADLINE: Long Island Retailers Discover The Selling Power of the Web

BYLINE: By CAROL STEINBERG

 BODY:
CRISTINA SAGUIN navigated a long distance to buy her husband, Patrick, the perfect Christmas gift this year. Determined to surprise him with a custom fishing reel, Ms. Saguin of Anchorage scouted all the shops around her home town. No luck.
Then, with the shopping days counting down, Ms. Saguin did what many consumers have done this holiday season. She went shopping on the Internet. 
 After 15 minutes of surfing the Web one afternoon, she struck gold: The Fly Fishing Store, situated -- approximately 3,450 miles from Anchorage -- in Bohemia.
It not only stocks, but it also manufactures, the Bill Ballan Heirloom Classic reel that caught her interest. Within one week, she received the $390 order.
"It was very convenient," Ms. Saguin said.
As the number of on-line consumers continues to swell, more Long Island retailers are setting up shop or increasing their presence on the Internet. What they've found is that it typically costs relatively little to reach audiences way beyond their suburban doorsteps.
In 1998, 8.7 million households in the United States will have spent $7.8 billion on-line on travel services and retail goods, other than automobiles, according to Forrester Research, a Cambridge, Ma., research company. By 2003, on-line commerce is expected to involve 40 million households and generate $108 billion, or 6 percent of total retail sales in the United States.
"More small retailers are getting on line primarily because they're hearing so much about it," said James McQuivey, an analyst in on-line retail strategies at Forrester.
Richard DiSilvio, president of Digital Vista, a graphic and Web design company in Massapequa, is seeing more interest among companies.
"As time goes by, they're getting more serious about it," he said. "They see that it's here to stay."
Adding to the appeal is tumbling Web design prices. In general, a Web site can cost as little as $1,500, Mr. DiSilvio said.
When Bill Ballan, owner of the Fly Fishing Store, tackled the Web in 1995, sales were flat at his 3,100-square foot store next to Connetquot River State Park. So he set his eyes on customers outside this fly fisherman's paradise.
"A small retailer today just can't survive on local traffic," said Mr. Ballan, a fishing buff who opened his store six years ago. "You have to be innovative to increase sales."
He took computer training and spent about $8,000 for someone to construct the site (the site is www.flyfishingstore.com). It includes details and photos of rods and reels and a bulletin board for enthusiasts to swap information and used goods.
Thanks to the Internet and the strong economy, sales rose 10 percent his company's first year on the Internet; 20 percent in year two, and 38 percent in year three. In 1998, Mr. Ballan traces $100,000 of $600,000 in total revenues to the Web, including orders from Florida, Mexico, Ireland, and Japan.
Other retailers here also have experienced surprising results. Some are good, some problematic.
The owners of the Capezio Dance Theater Shop in Rockville Center had not really thought about the Internet when Pagelinx, a Web designer in Patchogue, solicited them two years ago. Although store revenues were steady, they figured it would be a good way to advertise and "fun," said Lisa Spagnola, who is co-owner of the store with her mother, Linda. They paid $2,500 and spend $3,600 annually for Pagelinx to maintain the site.
Day one, orders filtered in. The site (www.capeziorvc.com), which displays 500 items, from $6 tights to $62 tap shoes, draws customers worldwide. The home page even plays classical music. Hot spots are the Midwest, where selection is limited, and Japan, where, Ms. Spagnola said, "I heard a $20 leotard here is $80 there."
Items sell for 20 to 25 percent below retail. Ms. Spagnola said that the cost usually evens out for walk-in customers because of a 10 percent discount and no shipping charges.
These days, Ms. Spagnola is holed up in a back room, responding to E-mails and readying orders for shipment. The site captures 4,000 to 7,000 hits a month, and 3 to 12 orders a day. Internet sales compose about $100,000 of its $500,000 in annual revenues, generating enough profit to cover store overhead and then some.
At the Ski Stop Warehouse in Plainview, the Internet has not proven "a real selling tool," said Al Weisinger. The site (www.skistop.com) draws about $3,000 in orders annually, accounting for a mere 2 percent of total revenues.
According to Mr. Weisinger, a major stumbling block is that many of his manufacturers have enforced dealership contracts that prohibit merchandise sales outside one's market. "That's putting a crimp in my sales," he said.
Still, Ski Stop is remaining on the Web because it is a "great informational center" and entices local residents who want "to touch and feel" to come in, Mr. Weisinger said.
George Lang, a former computer consultant and owner of the Good News Book Store and Religious Gifts in East Northport, blames two factors for the mediocre performance of a folksy Web site (www.goodnewsbooks.com) he created four years ago.
First, he believes the majority of his target market are not computer users. And he has barely advertised the virtual store.
Then there's the trust factor in cyberspace.
At the Fly Fishing Store, sales don't always come easy, Mr. Ballan said. He noted that Internet shoppers ask a tremendous amount of questions. He makes four replies to a customer for every sale.
"It's kind of hard to build up the rapport," he said.
Diane Clark-Pitura, a dance educator in Bedford Hills, N.Y., shopped on the Capezio Dance Theater Internet site only after the owner of a defunct local dancewear store said she had heard of the retailer.
"I wasn't raised in the computer generation," said Ms. Clark-Pitura, who has since opened a dance boutique because of the easy access to inventory through Capezio Dance Theater. "This is a whole new world to me, so there is always a little bit of hesitation."
One big question merchants face is whether to make local customers aware of the Web sites.
One Long Island retailer intentionally keeps his year-old Web site a secret from the community in which he has operated a home improvement and design product store for 30 years. For that reason, he spoke only on the condition of anonymity.
"I am not looking to cannibalize local retail business with a Web presence," he said.
He said he can afford to sell products on the Web at 20 percent to 40 percent below retail because of lower overhead and it is not as sales- and people-intensive.
Despite his secrecy, some local customers have stumbled upon the site. In those cases, he will honor the lower prices. "It has not become an issue yet," he said. Meanwhile, Internet sales are growing at a rate of 5 percent a month.
Graffiti, a clothing retailer, does not consider the Web a separate entity. It wants to reach girls worldwide who do not have access to similar fashion merchandise, plus those who frequent its stores in Commack and Dix Hills. So it features its Web address (www.graffiti-online.com) on business cards and marketing material. The Web accounts for 30 percent of sales.
Adam Herman, the company's controller and Web manager, figures residents will visit the stores anyway to avoid shipping costs. But making them aware of Graffiti on-line builds customer loyalty.
"When the girls go away or go away to school, they will take this store with them via the Web,' he said.
Now, some companies that initially tested the Internet are moving forward more aggressively.
Mr. Lang, for example, said he soon plans to market his bookstore's site. Graffiti is adding contests and a chat room where teen-agers can discuss styles or get fashion advice.
When computer-savvy Tracey Gera of Gera Gardens in Mount Sinai designed the store's Web site (www.geragardens.com) two years ago, for about $500, it only provided limited information and did not accept orders.
Now realizing the Web's power, Ms. Gera -- an addicted cyberspace shopper herself -- recently hired someone to upgrade the site for $1,000. The revamped pages will display about 40 percent of the store's lawn furniture, fountains and garden ornaments, and will be encrypted to accept credit card purchases.
Tom Jakab and Todd Morena are reversing the traditional retail-to-Internet path. In a cost-saving move, Mr. Jackab, a graphic artist, and Mr. Morena, a personnel executive, went on the Internet in November 1997, to introduce their product -- socks that snap together to avoid lost sock syndrome. It is linked to quirky sites, like the Bureau of Missing Socks.
SnapSock (www.snapsock.com), run out of Mr. Jakab's garage in Merrick, averages $700 to $1,000 in weekly revenues, or 140 pairs of socks, from the Web and a toll-free number.
Bolstered by this success, the entrepreneurs plan to open a store in Nassau County this spring. Mr. Morena expects some local customers to swap on-line orders for shopping the old-fashioned way.
But, he said, "It doesn't matter which way the sales come in, as long as they come in."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Bill Ballan, owner of the Fly Fishing Store in Bohemia, has seen revenues rise since he started a Web site in 1995. (Maxine Hicks for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 14LI; Page 1; Column 4; Long Island Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 2222 words

HEADLINE: Immigrants Find the Island a Mixed Blessing;
A Life Looking Over Shoulders In a Land Of Freedom

BYLINE: By MARY REINHOLZ

 BODY:
AT first glance, the one-story East Patchogue house where Jose and Rosa Ramos live with their son is the picture-perfect love nest of a young couple pursuing the American dream. But an air of anxiety pervades their $950-a-month rental, which they share with two other relatives. Mr. Ramos is subject to arrest at any time.
Mr. Ramos, a 28-year-old cook in Middle Village, fled his native El Salvador in 1993. Soon after being taken to San Diego by a smuggler who charged $3,500 for the service, Mr. Ramos was detained by immigration officials and then released to be united with his brother on Long Island while he challenged the Government's case for deporting him. 
 Mr. Ramos's argument for asylum was that he feared he might be killed by former guerrillas who killed two of his uncles and grandfather during the Salvadoran civil war of the 1980's. He also argued for an exception because of the congenital heart disease suffered by his 3-year-old son, Jonathan. But he lost his fight in November, 1997, when an immigration panel rejected his last appeal, ruling that he had no reason to flee a war that is over.
"You can't sleep well, you can't eat well, and when you open the door, you know they can come at any minute and take you away," Mr. Ramos said in an interview conducted to the beat of his right foot, which drummed nervously on the hardwood floor of his brightly decorated living room. Mrs. Ramos, 24 and also an undocumented Salvadoran immigrant who first met her husband on Long Island, sat nearby with Jonathan, an American citizen by birth.
Variations on Mr. Ramos's case are repeated over and over again among the Central Americans who live on Long Island, who are estimated to number 100,000 and to be the third largest population of Central American immigrants in the United States, behind Los Angeles and Washington.
Hundreds of Central Americans are clustered in Brentwood, Carle Place, Freeport, Glen Cove, Hempstead, Inwood, Port Washington, Westbury, Deer Park, Central Islip and Riverhead. Most work as landscapers, nannies, porters, factory and construction workers. Others have started their own businesses. Franklin Street in Hempstead, where the Salvadoran government briefly set up an office in 1996, has so many Salvadoran restaurants and clothing stores that it has been nicknamed Little El Salvador.
Many of the Central Americans on the Island arrived in the 1960's and have become American citizens, or at least have received the green card that signifies legal residence in this country. But among a new wave of people who began fleeing the human rights abuses in El Salvador and Guatemala in the 1980's and wound up on Long Island are thousands who remain illegal immigrants.
The undocumented immigrants -- 20,000 to 30,000, according to Patrick Young, director of the Central American Refugee Center, a Hempstead-based advocacy group -- occupy the bottom rung of Long Island's economic and political ladder. Living outside the law and with few skills, they must take menial jobs that pay cash under the table and are easily exploited by employers, landlords and merchants who can abuse their rights with virtual impunity, knowing that the immigrants are unlikely to go to the authorities. Many undocumented immigrants are afraid of being deported or put in detention centers if they call official attention to themselves.
Michael Hoffman, director of the Workplace project in Hempstead, a nonprofit center that helps to organize undocumented Central American workers, said the coyotes, or people smugglers, are just "the first in a series of exploiters and abusers that immigrants come in contact with. After the coyotes, they meet with people who give them highfaluting promises of green cards after they pay X number of dollars and employment agencies where they're offered jobs, and very often never get them even though they've put up money to get them. Very often women domestics get $1.50 an hour, below the minimum wage," from employers who know that the immigrants "come without documents and won't complain."
What disturbs Mr. Ramos most is his belief that immigration judges and officials from the Immigration and Naturalization Service don't seem to understand or care that his being deported would break up his family and affect his ability to provide for Jonathan, who underwent surgery last year.
"I told the judge I want to stay here because in El Salvador it's difficult to get the kind of medication that my son needs," Mr. Ramos said. "Maybe there are doctors in a special hospital there, but we can't pay for that."
Mr. Ramos said he makes about $250 a week in salary, plus as much as $100 more in tips.
"Maybe immigration thinks I can leave and my son can follow me," he continued. "But that's not the point. We are a family. He's half of my life. I can't understand why these people think like that. They don't seem to care."
Asked whether the child's condition had a bearing on the father's immigration case, an I.N.S. spokesman, Russ Bergeron, said Mr. Ramos "has the right to ask for extraordinary relief based on the extraordinary medical circumstances of his child."
Mr. Ramos's lawyer, David M. Sperling of Huntington, does not view Mr. Ramos's case as particularly unusual, although he describes the I.N.S.'s treatment of Mr. Ramos as "very shabby."
"This is a case that cried out for a humanitarian response," he said, "and the cold-hearted response that Jose has received doesn't make me optimistic.
"The I.N.S. has this enforcement mentality, and they're not looking at the individual factors," he continued. "In many cases families are being torn apart, with mothers and fathers deported and children who have no one taking care of them."
Mr. Ramos and other Central American immigrants facing deportation have won a breather from the I.N.S. in the form of a moratorium on deportations of citizens of Honduras, Nicaragua, El Salvador and Guatemala, the countries hardest hit by Hurricane Mitch in late October. But the moratorium ends on Jan. 7.
Mr. Young said that the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act, which went into effect in April, 1997, further limits the Central Americans' chances of obtaining legal residence. The statute requires that applicants seeking a "cancellation of removal" must have been in the United States continuously for 10 years and prove that deportation would create "unusual hardship" for American citizens, such as a spouse or relative. Under the old law, applicants had to be in the country seven years and were required to prove that deportation would result in "extreme hardship" only for themselves.
George Fishmond, chief counsel of the House subcommittee on immigration, said that one of the aims of the 1997 act was "making it more difficult for illegal aliens to have jobs in this country."
"Another method was to make the standards for illegal aliens to stay in this country less lenient," Mr. Fishmond added. "It is not the duty of the U.S. to take in every one of the billions of people in the world who have economic difficulty. We just can't accommodate all these people."
But the new act still leaves a confusing array of legal statuses for the Central American immigrants:
*Undocumented people, who have no protection.
*Those with asylum applications pending, who often get work authorization from the I.N.S. Many in this group are beneficiaries of a legal settlement involving the American Baptist Church, which filed a class action in 1990 to stave off mass deportations of Salvadorans and Guatemalans and to permit those immigrants to apply for asylum.
*Those eligible to apply for protection against deportation under the 1997 Nicaraguan Adjustment and Central American Relief Act, which gives blanket amnesty to Nicaraguans and Cubans who arrived in the United States before December, 1995, and offers Salvadorans and Guatemalans the opportunity to apply for suspension of deportation under the more relaxed regulations in effect before the immigration reform of 1997.
Central Americans who win their cases under the Baptist Church settlement or the relief act, noted Mr. Young, are in the "best position" to win permanent residency because they can then apply for a green card and five years later (three years if a spouse is a citizen) can apply for United States citizenship -- provided, he said, that they have "good moral character and can pass a civics and English test."
A 33-year-old Honduran woman living in Westbury described in an interview the game of chance she plays as a working mother who could be picked up at any time by the I.N.S. for having overstayed a Sept. 3 deportation order.
The woman, who insisted that she not be identified, said that she came to America in 1989, after her husband "disappeared" in El Salvador when she was pregnant with her third daughter. She said she left the children with her mother and wound up swimming across the Rio Grande, later taking a bus to live with relatives on Long Island.
Now she works at a cleaners and has an apartment in Westbury, a third-floor walkup that rents for $1,100 a month. The five rooms house seven people, including the woman's daughters, who joined her last year, and her pregnant 27-year-old sister, a recent arrival who was given six months to leave the country after I.N.S. officials caught her illegally crossing the border.
"I don't want to go back home," she said. "There are no jobs there. My children are here and I don't have money to bring them back. I trust in God, so I have no fear."
"The myth is that undocumented people come here to get on welfare, to get benefits," said Sister Judy Mannix, a Roman Catholic nun who works with Spanish-speaking people at St. Bridget's Church in Westbury and acted as an interpreter for the Honduran woman. "The reality is they're here because they want to work. They're ineligible for most benefits unless there's an emergency situation like a heart attack."
Mr. Bergeron of the I.N.S. noted that the traumatic experiences of undocumented immigrants were often the consequence of entering the United States illegally. "That," he said, "is why we have a formal system of immigration designed to insure that people who come to the U.S. have the necessary legal and social systems, which insure that they can resettle here without fear of exploitation." Legal immigration, he said, allows them to be admitted to the United States "either because of a petition filed by a family member or employer."
Many undocumented immigrants have achieved a measure of middle-class success. Marcelino Moreira, 29, a Salvadoran who came to the United States in the 1980's, and his wife, Daria, 33, who arrived in 1990, make a combined $33,000 a year -- enough to support their four children in a rented Brentwood house on a tree-lined street.
Mr. Moreira, who has worked for eight years as an operator at a paper factory in Hauppauge, making $8 an hour on a day shift, owns his own car. His wife works an eight-hour shift in a Syosset factory at night. In halting English, she said, "I want to go to school and get a good job that pays well."
But the couple, both of whom have temporary work authorization papers from the I.N.S., still could be deported if they fail to win their asylum cases.
"My children would suffer in El Salvador," Mr. Moreira said. "The food is not the same as it is here. You've got health inspectors here that check the food. They don't have that in El Salvador. Every time we have the children visit relatives in El Salvador, they have come back with some kind of illness. And when they come back, they don't want to return."
Mrs. Moreira, whose first job was as a live-in housekeeper in Port Washington, said she believes some people in her neighborhood regard her as a welfare recipient.
"A woman in the laundromat said that," she said. "But I never take welfare."
In a decade of work, Juan Alfero, a 27-year-old Salvadoran immigrant, saved up enough money from his 60-hour-a-week job as a busboy in a Lindenhurst restaurant to make a $23,000 down payment on a $189,000 house in Brentwood.
"It was a big dream to come to this country to work," Mr. Alfero said, adding that he worked in Long Island restaurants as an undocumented immigrant for two years, receiving cash from his employers, before he applied for political asylum and obtained work authorization.
"After I got that card from immigration, it was like starting a new life," he said. "I got a driver's license. It's hard to live in this county without any I.D. And you have to learn a different language."
His wife, Dina, works 40 hours a week at a Deer Park factory, manufacturing guitar cords and bringing work home. "We're planning to take a vacation if we get residency," Mr. Alfero said. "We're going to save our money and send our kids to college."
"Salvadorans have resourcefulness," said Juan Carlos Murillo, 30, a Salvadoran who works as a counselor in the Brentwood office of the Central American Refugee Center while fighting his own deportation case. "They have kids in the schools, they're circulating money, they're part of the community. Some of them live the American dream."
But for people like Mr. Alfero, he said, "it's temporary." If Mr. Alfero is deported, "he could lose everything, his house, his dream."

SECTION: Section 2; Page 38; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1051 words

HEADLINE: THE YEAR IN REVIEW: ART/ARCHITECTURE;
Public Space, Private Space And Anti-Space

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP

 BODY:

1. KIASMA -- Steven Holl's new museum of contemporary art in Helsinki takes its name from a neurological configuration that links perception and conception. That's a good point of departure for an art museum, and Holl has turned his into a major urban event. He has carved a set of powerfully sensuous galleries within a curving shell that animates what was formerly a dead zone in the Finnish capital's core. 

2. HOUSE IN BORDEAUX -- A physically disabled client has inspired Rem Koolhaas to create a shelter from shelter: a house of concrete, glass and steel that evades conventional ideas of refuge, comfort and normalcy. The building's central feature, a 12-foot-square moving platform, enables the client to move freely among the house's three levels as it alters the flow of space inside.
 
3. COMPETITION -- Phyllis Lambert, founding director of the Canadian Center for Architecture, in Montreal, has begun a program aimed at urban revitalization. Every three years, she will sponsor a juried competition in a different city. The first, to be held in New York next year, will invite six architects to develop ideas for the west side of midtown Manhattan, a district dominated by tunnels, highways, overpasses and other fragments of urban infrastructure. If ultimately approved, this would be the first wide-ranging urban project New York has seen in 30 years.
 
4. PAPER PLANT -- Think how much fun it would be to read the newspaper if you knew that the paper it was printed on had been made in a plant designed by the brilliant young architect Maya Lin. Ms. Lin's plan, as yet unrealized, would draw on the most advanced recycling technology and could produce about 50 percent of the newsprint consumed in New York City. Also, you would be able to look down on the plant from the Triborough Bridge and see a fountain, using the water required by the recycling process, glinting in the sun.
 
5. ZAHA HADID -- The selection of Zaha Hadid's design for the Cincinnati Museum of Contemporary Art brings further glory to a city already enriched by recent buildings by Peter Eisenman, Frank Gehry, Michael Graves and Harry Cobb. Hadid's design recalls one of Klee's magic-square paintings rendered into three dimensions. A broad ramp-way switch-backing up one side of the building will convey visitors past a honeycomb of galleries, while quirky cuts in the floor will punctuate the 10-story structure with exclamations of light and space.
 
6. GRAND CENTRAL -- The great mother of infrastructure, back in all her Beaux-Arts glory. But with all the fuss being made over the Grand Concourse and its jade-green astrological ceiling, let us not overlook that architectural and gustatory gem, the Oyster Bar. With its beautiful ceiling of vaulted tiles, designed and built by the Guastavinos, this spot is second only to the Four Seasons in architectural distinction. James Bond thought it the best restaurant in New York. Here he first uttered his immortal instruction to the barman: "Shaken, not stirred." Or was it the other way around? Bless the architects of the restoration, Beyer Blinder Belle, for uncovering the ramps that lead the weary traveler down to a warming, briny dish of oyster stew.
 
7. ELLSWORTH KELLY -- The best architecture show of the year was Matthew Marks's presentation of "Sculpture for a Large Wall," a 65-foot piece designed by Ellsworth Kelly in 1957 for the Transportation Building in Penn Center, the massive urban-renewal project in downtown Philadelphia. Mr. Kelly was paid $200 for his services, and when Mr. Marks encountered the piece, some 40 years after its creation, the Transportation Building was boarded up. The work represents a moment when Kelly was committed to an entirely Utopian idea of collaboration between artists and architects. And even wrenched loose from its architectural setting, the sculpture retains Kelly's optimistic view of the power of abstract art.
 
8. JENNIFER RAAB -- The low point of this and many other years was reached when Jennifer Raab, chairwoman of the Landmarks Preservation Commission, instructed the developer Donald Trump to build a 1930's skyscraper on the site of the St. Moritz Hotel on Central Park South. A person who could say such a thing has no business being in landmarks preservation, because she has no sense of history. She is unable to distinguish between a landmark and an ersatz version of one, and she evidently conceives of architecture as a practice tantamount to arranging throw pillows on a sofa.
 
9. COLISEUM -- Skidmore, Owings, Merrill's design for the Coliseum site on Columbus Circle perfectly epitomizes the architecture of denial. Modeled after the Majestic and the Century, Irwin S. Chanin's great apartment towers on Central Park West, this design represents an utter lack of awareness that New York today differs dramatically from the city in the 1930's, and that this difference demands architectural interpretation. In particular, the design denies the extent to which the city is now governed by congestion, density and bulk. Should this building rise in its present form, we will all hate ourselves for tolerating structures so flagrantly out of touch with the imagination we came here to exercise.
 
10. CITY HALL PARK -- At a time when the discourse of architecture revolves around the issue of public space, the mayor of the world's greatest city has seen fit throughout this year to turn New York into a demonstration project of anti-public space. Giuliani Stadium has a nice ring, but the likelihood is that this mayor will be remembered for the barricades, bollards and fences that he and his police commissioners have caused to be placed around the town. The hurricane fences, the dirty concrete barricades that now surround City Hall, do bristle with a certain Gehryesque charm. But this is no Bilbao. Thick walls and thin skins: this is the driving sensibility emanating from a public official who had, and lost, the opportunity to create great public works. In reviewing the record of this administration, one is tempted to paraphrase something Edmund Wilson once wrote: There is something going on, on the higher plane, that halfway compels his respect, but he does not know what it is, and in any case he can never get up there himself.

GRAPHIC: Photos: The renovated Grand Central Station, in all its Beaux-Arts glory, above, Steven Holl's new museum of contemporary art in Helsinki, left, and Ellsworth Kelly's "Sculpture for a Large Wall" (installed at the Matthew Marks Gallery, New York, in April), below, were among the year's architectural highlights. (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times; Paul Warchol; Matthew Marks Gallery, New York); If you don't like a space in this Rem Koolhaas house, just wait a minute. (Hans Welemann/Office for Metropolitan Architecture)
